questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of unpleasant taste progressing to moderate loss of taste in the past week. She was treated with oral cephalexin for a urinary tract infection several weeks ago and finished her course of treatment before the onset of symptoms. She has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows white plaques on the buccal mucosa, palate, and tongue. The physician can scrape several plaques using a tongue depressor that reveals underlying erythema with light bleeding. The scrapings are prepared for pathological examination. Which of the following is most likely to be observed on microscopy?

choices.text: Budding yeasts with and without hyphae
Hyperkeratosis overlying a thickened, acanthotic mucosal epithelium
Dysplasia with inflammation and vascular dilation
Lymphocytic infiltrate along the dermo-epidermal junction

questions.solution:
This patient, who recently completed a course of oral antibiotic therapy, presents with white, scrapable plaques on her oral mucosa suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush). Candidiasis is an opportunistic infection caused by the fungus Candida albicans that most commonly occurs in immunosuppressed hosts (e.g. AIDS, hematologic malignancies). However, this condition can occur in healthy patients who wear dentures, patients with xerostomia (dry mouth), and those treated with antibiotics or inhaled corticosteroids.    

Most patients with oral thrush are asymptomatic. However, when symptomatic, patients typically experience a “sensation of cotton in their mouth,” along with a loss of taste. In some cases, pain during eating and swallowing occurs. Oropharyngeal examination typically reveals white plaques on the buccal mucosa, palate, tongue, or the oropharynx that is easily scrapable with an instrument like a tongue depressor. Confirmatory diagnosis can be made by scraping the lesions and performing KOH preparation on the scrapings, which will reveal budding yeasts with or without hyphae.   

Treatment for oral thrush involves antifungal therapy (e.g., clotrimazole, fluconazole) for several days. If no inciting event is known (e.g. prior antibiotic use), further investigation should be pursued, such as HIV testing.

Option Analysis

✅ Budding yeasts with and without hyphae:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hyperkeratosis overlying a thickened, acanthotic mucosal epithelium :
Incorrect: This answer describes leukoplakia – a benign (although precancerous) lesion of the tongue secondary to hyperplasia of the squamous mucosa. Leukoplakia may resemble thrush, appearing as white patches or plaques on the oral mucosa; however, unlike thrush, these lesions cannot be easily removed via scraping.
❌ Dysplasia with inflammation and vascular dilation:
Incorrect: Erythroplakia is a red, velvety lesion found on the oral mucosa and is associated with atypical epithelial changes, including an atrophic epithelium and prominent vasculature (giving this lesion its red, erythematous appearance). Erythroplakia is not easily scrapable with a tongue depressor.
❌ Septate hyphae with acute-angle branching:
Incorrect: These findings suggest an infection with the fungus Aspergillus. Invasive aspergillosis preferentially affects the lungs and manifests with necrotizing pneumonia. This patient has no clinical features to suggest a pulmonary or systemic infection, making this etiology unlikely. 
❌ Lymphocytic infiltrate along the dermo-epidermal junction:
Incorrect: This histologic description suggests lichen planus, which appears as a symmetrical white lace-like pattern on the buccal mucosa. It can be caused by certain drugs (antibiotics, NSAIDs), infections (hepatitis C), and cigarette smoking. This patient’s white, scrapable plaques are suggestive of a different condition.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man presents to the cardiologist's office for a follow-up visit after placement of a dual chamber pacemaker three weeks ago for heart failure. The patient’s hospital course was uncomplicated, but the patient is now complaining of worsening dyspnea on exertion, malaise, and fevers. He has a history of mitral valve replacement due to rheumatic heart disease at the age of 55. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 146/73 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. There is a surgical incision site over the lateral chest wall without evidence of erythema, discharge, or swelling. Small, subcutaneous, tender nodules on the left hand are demonstrated below:  

 
Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Blood is drawn and sent for culture. Three days later, 3 of 4 blood cultures obtained on admission grow Gram-positive, coagulase-negative bacteria. Which of the following virulence factors of this organism is implicated in this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Pilus allowing adherence to colonic epithelium
Formation of adherent water-soluble glycans from the disaccharide sucrose in dental caries
Anchoring adhesion proteins for oral epithelial tissue

questions.solution:
Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of endocarditis in patients with previously damaged or prosthetic heart valves, and infection often occurs in patients that have recently undergone invasive cardiac procedures. The patient in this vignette recently underwent surgery for placement of a dual chamber pacemaker, the likely nidus for exposure of infection. The history and physical examination are consistent with infective endocarditis (IE), given the presence of fevers, a new murmur, and Osler nodes, as seen in the image.  

Patients with subacute bacterial endocarditis present with a chronic history of nonspecific symptoms. Fever is the most common symptom in IE, and it is often associated with chills, anorexia, and weight loss. Relatively uncommon clinical manifestations, yet pathognomonic of IE, include Janeway lesions (nontender erythematous macules on the palms and soles), Osler nodes (tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes), and Roth spots (exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina).  

S. epidermidis is a part of normal human skin flora and generally has low virulence. However, when the bacteria gain access to the heart or blood stream through indwelling devices, they can cause significant infection. The ability of the bacteria to form biofilms on devices makes treating the infection with antibiotics alone a difficult endeavor. The nidus for infection, the indwelling device or line, should be removed to ensure resolution of the infection.   

Option Analysis

❌ Enzyme converting fibrinogen into fibrin:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus carries the coagulase protein, which helps to clot plasma and enhance its adherence within the cardiovascular system. This bacteria is a common cause of endocarditis due to IV drug use as well as during the initial months following a cardiac procedure, and it tends to cause acute endocarditis. However, this patient’s blood culture grew coagulase-negative bacteria, making S. aureus unlikely.   
❌ Pilus allowing adherence to colonic epithelium:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a potential cause of endocarditis in patients with underlying colon cancer and inflammatory bowel disease. The bacteria carries a pilus which allows for its adherence to colonic epithelium as well as other host cells.  
❌ Formation of adherent water-soluble glycans from the disaccharide sucrose in dental caries:
Incorrect: Streptococcus mutans is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. It is able to form water-adherent glycans, allowing it to preside as dental flora causing dental caries. This patient has had no recent dental procedures, making this causal pathogen unlikely.   
❌ Anchoring adhesion proteins for oral epithelial tissue:
Incorrect: Streptococcus sanguineous is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. These bacteria contain anchoring adhesion proteins, allowing them to exist as oral flora. This patient has had no recent dental procedures, making this causal pathogen unlikely.   
✅ Biofilm formation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the primary care physician with fevers, cough, and night sweats. He is accompanied by his aunt, who reports the patient has been coughing non-stop at night and has even had small specks of blood in his sputum. The patient is otherwise healthy and recently moved to the United States from the Philippines. Temperature is 38.3 °C (101°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 123/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam reveals a malnourished patient and is notable for faint rales over the right lower lung field. Which of the following radiographic features is most indicative of this patient’s primary infectious process?

choices.text: Hilar lymphadenopathy and a primary focus of infection in the mid-lower lobes
Fibrocaseous cavitary lesion in the upper lobes

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient who recently immigrated from the Philippines presents with night sweats, fevers, and cough. Physical exam is notable for a cachexia, malnourishment, and diminished breath sounds over the right lower lung. Together, the history and exam findings are most concerning for primary pulmonary tuberculosis, of which the most common radiographic feature is hilar lymphadenopathy and a Ghon focus in the mid-lower lobes.    

Primary pulmonary tuberculosis describes a new tuberculosis infection or active disease in a previously naïve host. In primary disease, mycobacteria take up residence in lung tissue, typically the right lung in the mid/lower lobes due to a higher density of lymph nodes and anatomic preference given the longer length and smaller internal caliber of the right bronchus. Mycobacteria then form a primary focus of granulomatous infection, referred to as a Ghon focus, which along with hilar lymphadenopathy is referred to as a Ghon complex.     

The majority of patients with primary tuberculosis are asymptomatic. However, as the infection establishes, symptoms including fever, weight loss, anorexia, chills, cough, and night sweats may occur. Of these symptoms, fever, cough, and dyspnea are the most common. In the chronically ill or immunosuppressed patients, primary tuberculosis can lead to progressive primary tuberculosis, wherein the disease becomes widespread, and the bacteria seeds multiple organ systems. However, the vast majority of patients with primary tuberculosis have either spontaneous resolution of infection or progress to latent infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hilar lymphadenopathy and a primary focus of infection in the mid-lower lobes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fibrocaseous cavitary lesion in the upper lobes:
Incorrect: An upper lobe lesion is more indicative of secondary or reactivation tuberculosis. Patients with secondary tuberculosis typically have a history of untreated tuberculosis with recrudescent symptoms. 
❌ Cavitary caseating lesion :
Incorrect: Cavitary necrotic tuberculous lesions are more commonly seen in secondary tuberculosis. 
❌ Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates:
Incorrect: Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates can be seen radiographically in the setting of primary pulmonary tuberculosis infections. However, it is not the most common radiographic finding associated with primary tuberculosis. 
❌ Unilateral pleural effusion:
Incorrect: Pleural effusions are commonly seen in primary tuberculosis (approximately one third of cases). However, it is not the most common radiographic finding associated with primary tuberculosis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner due to high fever and severe headache accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The partner reported that the patient was fine until 2 days ago, when she started complaining of a headache and rapidly became confused. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is obtunded and responds only to noxious stimuli. Pupils are equal and responsive to light. When the neck is flexed, the patient flexes the lower limbs. A thorough skin examination reveals no rashes, petechiae, or purpura. CSF analysis shows elevated WBC count with polymorphonuclear predominance, low glucose, high protein, and numerous RBCs. A wet mount is performed and reveals the following:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons    
Further review of this patient's history will most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with rapidly progressive headaches, fever, and altered mental status. The physical examination shows nuchal rigidity, while the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) results imply bacterial meningitis with numerous RBCs. Finally, the wet mount test of the CSF reveals motile trophozoites, favoring the diagnosis of primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) caused by Naegleria fowleri.   

Naegleria fowleri is a protozoan parasite that can be found in fresh water sources worldwide. The most common risk factor for infection is recreational water activities. Trophozoites from the water penetrate the olfactory mucosa, cross the cribriform plates, and eventually reach the olfactory bulb and brain. PAM is an acute hemorrhagic meningoencephalitis with an extremely high mortality rate. Patients often present with high fevers, severe headache, photophobia, nausea, vomiting, behavioral changes, seizures, and altered mental status. Smell and taste abnormalities may occur early and imply the migration of the parasite through the olfactory mucosa. Eventually, severe intracranial hypertension develops, leading to herniation and death within days. CSF analysis typically shows high WBC count with marked polymorphonuclear predominance, low glucose, elevated protein, numerous RBCs (due to hemorrhage) but negative routine bacterial cultures and gram stain. Diagnosis is based upon the clinical suspicion and is established by observation of motile trophozoites on CSF wet mount. Conventional treatment includes amphotericin B as well as other agents.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hiking in the woods:
Incorrect: Lyme disease is caused by the bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted via the Ixodes deer tick. Neurologic involvement typically occurs later in the course, though lymphocytic meningitis or encephalomyelitis can present in early disseminated Lyme disease. However, Lyme disease is diagnosed through serology (e.g., Western blot), rather than a wet mount. 
✅ Swimming in freshwater:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent travel to Africa :
Incorrect: Malaria is a mosquito-borne disease caused by a parasite that is endemic to central Africa. Patients with malaria typically present with fever, chills, headache, anemia, splenomegaly and flu-like illness. Malaria is diagnosed by viewing the parasite on thick blood smears, rather than a wet mount. 
❌ Army service:
Incorrect: Neisseria meningitidis (meningococci) is a gram-negative diplococci and is the second most common cause of meningitis in adults below the age of 60 years. Infections typically occur in the settings of weakened immunity or crowded areas with infected patients (army recruits). Diagnosis is made via culture-based tests or PCR, rather than a wet mount.
❌ Ingestion of uncooked food:
Incorrect: Cysticercosis is a parasitic infection caused by larval cysts of the cestode (tapeworm) Taenia solium. Humans acquire the larvae encysted in undercooked pork (intestinal larvae) and later pass the eggs in food contaminated with human feces (cysticercosis). Patients with disseminated disease present with multiple cystic CNS lesions and seizures. Diagnosis is made through serology and imaging, rather than a wet mount.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female preschool teacher presents to an urgent care for evaluation of right eye discharge and foreign body sensation for the past 2 days. One week ago, the patient had a sore throat and low-grade fever that self-resolved after several days. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 11/min, blood pressure is 102/84 mm Hg. Right eye examination demonstrates a follicular appearance of the tarsal conjunctiva and profuse watery discharge. Cervical lymphadenopathy is also present. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young teacher, who presents with a history of a viral syndrome and subsequent symptoms of unilateral conjunctival injection and associated watery discharge, likely has viral conjunctivitis. The most common viral etiology of conjunctivitis is adenovirus.   

Distinguishing between bacterial, viral and allergic conjunctivitis is primarily achieved on the basis of history and physical examination. Viral conjunctivitis should be suspected in patients with a viral prodrome (e.g., pharyngitis, low-grade fever, upper respiratory infection), whereas allergic conjunctivitis should be suspected in patients with a history of seasonal allergies or atopy. The character of ocular discharge is also helpful in determining the etiology of the conjunctivitis. Viral and allergic conjunctivitis typically have a watery consistency with strands of mucus, whereas bacterial conjunctivitis results in thick purulent discharge. Allergic conjunctivitis is nearly always bilateral, whereas viral and bacterial conjunctivitis tend to be unilateral (although the presence of bilateral conjunctivitis should not immediately rule out these etiologies).

 

Option Analysis

✅ Adenovirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Allergens:
Incorrect: Allergic conjunctivitis is caused by airborne allergens that trigger a type I immunoglobulin E (IgE)-mediated hypersensitivity response. In the eye, this condition typically manifests with bilateral conjunctival injection, watery discharge, and itching (the cardinal symptom of an ocular allergic response).
❌ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Incorrect: Although bacterial conjunctivitis can result in unilateral ocular discharge, it is more often purulent. This patient’s history of a viral syndrome (e.g. low-grade fever, pharyngitis) are suggestive of a different etiology. 
❌ Neisseria gonorrhoeae :
Incorrect: Although bacterial conjunctivitis can result in unilateral ocular discharge, it is more often purulent. This patient’s history of a viral syndrome (e.g. low-grade fever, pharyngitis) are suggestive of a different etiology. 
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: S. aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults, which more commonly presents with purulent discharge. Additionally, this patient’s prodromal viral symptoms (e.g., low-grade fever, pharyngitis) are suggestive of a different etiology.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to an infectious disease specialist after recently contracting a bloodborne pathogen. She uses intravenous drugs, and she became acutely ill with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting after using heroin several weeks ago. She has a past medical history of HIV and hepatitis B. Work up reveals she is currently infected with an RNA delta virus. Infection with this virus is dependent on the presence of which of the following cofactors in host cells?
questions.solution:
This patient who uses intravenous drugs and has a history of HIV and hepatitis B presents with a new infection with an RNA delta virus, consistent with hepatitis D infection. Hepatitis D, unlike other forms of viral hepatitis, requires co-infection with hepatitis B, since the virus is dependent on HBsAg for viral entry.  

Hepatitis D is an RNA delta virus that is transmitted sexually and parenterally; however, most cases occur via contamination with infected blood products. The virus is composed of a single strand of RNA, without cellular machinery to mediate its own replication and information encoding viral capsid proteins for its progeny. Therefore, the virus is completely dependent on the hepatitis B surface protein HBsAg for viral entry. If universal vaccination against hepatitis B were present, hepatitis D would have no portal for entry, since the vaccine generates antibodies against HBsAg.  

Often, co-infection with hepatitis B and D occurs at the same time, or it may occur at a later time in patients that are already chronic carriers of hepatitis B. In the latter case, a superinfection can result, which portends a worse prognosis in terms of developing cirrhosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ HBsAg:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HBeAg:
Incorrect: The hepatitis E antigen is an intracellular protein that is secreted by hepatitis B. It is not needed for viral entry by hepatitis D.
❌ gp120:
Incorrect: HIV uses the surface glycoprotein gp120 for docking onto host T-cells. It is not utilized in coinfection with hepatitis D, an RNA delta virus.
❌ Neuraminidase:
Incorrect: Influenza virus utilizes neuraminidase, which cleaves glycosidic linkages of neuraminic acid and serves as an important virulence factor in the spread of influenza. It has no role in the co-infection with hepatitis D, an RNA delta virus.
❌ E1 glycoprotein:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C utilizes two surface glycoproteins to mediate entry into the hepatocyte—E1 and E2. These glycoproteins have no role in the infection of hepatitis D virus, an RNA delta virus.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by EMS after being found unresponsive in her apartment. An accompanying friend recalls the patient was at home sick for several days. The patient is unable to provide any medical history. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 76/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination is notable for a diffuse purpuric rash and cool, clammy skin. The patient’s IV, which was established en route, begins to bleed spontaneously. She is aggressively resuscitated with IV fluids, antibiotics, and peripheral vasopressors without improvement in her clinical status. Initial laboratory findings are demonstrated below:  



Which of the following organisms is most likely implicated in this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic features of Neisseria meningitis including fever, altered mental status, and signs of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). In addition, she has signs of adrenal insufficiency given the hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and unresponsiveness to resuscitation measures. Therefore, she likely has Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.  

Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome refers to bilateral adrenal hemorrhage and insufficiency in the setting of severe septic shock, most commonly due to endotoxic shock from the gram-negative diplococci Neisseria meningitidis. Clinical manifestations include headache with neck stiffness, altered mental status, fever, shock, a diffuse purpuric or petechial rash, and features of adrenal sufficiency such as persistent hypotension or hypoglycemia.  

Laboratory findings may include evidence of volume contraction, anemia, thrombocytopenia, significant leukocytosis, as well as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. If features of DIC are present, a prolonged PT and PTT are likely to be observed. Confirmatory diagnosis is achieved via isolation of the organism via lumbar puncture or blood cultures, and treatment involves broad spectrum antibiotics and administration of intravenous hydrocortisone.



Option Analysis

✅ Gram-negative diplococcus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gram-positive diplococci:
Incorrect:Streptococcus pneumoniae has been implicated in cases of Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome. However, it is an overall uncommon etiology, and case reports have only documented this organism in elderly patients.
❌ Gram-positive spore forming rod:
Incorrect:Bacillus anthracis is implicated in the pathogenesis of pulmonary anthrax. In contrast, this patient’s findings of hypotension refractory to intravenous fluid resuscitation, hyperkalemia, and hyponatremia raise concerns for adrenal insufficiency secondary to Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome. Bacillus anthracis is not a cause of Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome.  
❌ Gram-negative coccobacilli:
Incorrect:Haemophilus influenzae, like Streptococcus pneumoniae, has been implicated in case reports of Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome. However, it is an overall uncommon cause. Furthermore, Haemophilus influenzae is likely to manifest with clinical features of epiglottis.
❌ Gram-negative rod:
Incorrect: Escherichia coli (E. coli), particularly enterohemorrhagic E. coli serotype O157:H7, can cause hemolytic uremic syndrome, which manifests with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. However, this patient’s findings of hypotension refractory to intravenous fluid resuscitation, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and hypoglycemia are more concerning for adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of dyspnea for the past 2 days and is determined to have a COPD exacerbation. She has a 25-pack-year smoking history. Despite appropriate medical management, endotracheal intubation is required in the emergency department. On the fifth day of hospitalization, the patient develops a fever and increasingly purulent oral secretions. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 111/65 mmHg. A chest radiograph reveals new right middle lobe infiltrates. Sputum microscopy is notable for Gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient developed fevers, productive cough, and lung infiltrates several days after undergoing endotracheal intubation. These findings are concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia, which is a subtype of hospital-acquired pneumonia.  

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is diagnosed when a patient develops pneumonia 48 hours or more after being hospitalized for another condition. HAP tends to be more serious because these patients often have weakened immune systems, and the microbes in hospitals are often resistant to common antibiotics. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), which is commonly found in hospitals, and Legionellia pneumophila, which can be found in water systems, are common causes of HAP.  

A subtype of HAP is ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP describes pneumonia that develops after a patient has been intubated for more than 48 hours. Often, the condition is caused by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a Gram-negative bacillus, and Staphylococcus aureus. These organisms can form biofilms on the endotracheal tube and are subsequently able to move from the tube directly into the lungs, resulting in pneumonia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative coccobacillus that can cause community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient’s current pneumonia developed several days following endotracheal intubation, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP is commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus. 
❌ Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive coccus that can cause secondary bacterial pneumonia following an initial viral respiratory illness, as well as ventilator-associated pneumonia. However, this patient’s sputum culture demonstrated growth of a Gram-negative organism. 
❌ Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive cocci that can cause secondary bacterial pneumonia following an initial viral respiratory illness, as well as ventilator-associated pneumonia. However, this patient’s sputum culture demonstrated growth of a Gram-negative organism.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive cocci and is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient’s current pneumonia developed following endotracheal intubation, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP is often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus. 
✅ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man goes to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and dry cough for the past week. He has also become progressively more dyspneic, and walking a single block makes him short of breath. He underwent a liver transplantation 4-months ago for treatment of autoimmune hepatitis and is currently taking several immunosuppressant drugs. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 122/88 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral crackles and rhonchi. Chest radiograph reveals bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates extending from the perihilar region. Leukocyte count is 13,000/mm3 and serum lactate dehydrogenase level is 460 U/L. Further testing is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Detection of bacterial antigen in urine
Presence of organisms in sputum that stain positive for methenamine silver
Growth of bacteria on cholesterol-rich agar
Identification of Gram-positive diplococci on sputum analysis
Visualization of acid-fast organisms on sputum microscopy

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, cough, and dyspnea in the setting of an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level and immunosuppression. He likely has pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii, which can be stained with silver methenamine.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (which goes by the abbreviation PCP based on its former genus-species name Pneumocystis carinii) is an opportunistic fungal lung infection occurring almost exclusively in immunocompromised individuals. On board examinations, PCP is classically seen in patients with untreated HIV. However, other populations at risk include transplant recipients as well as patients on chronic glucocorticoids or other immunosuppressive therapy.  

Patients with PCP typically have a gradual onset (days to weeks) of symptoms. When symptomatic, patients present with low-grade fever, nonproductive cough, malaise, and dyspnea. Lung auscultation can reveal bilateral crackles and rhonchi.    

Laboratory testing can demonstrate elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels secondary to lung injury and inflammation caused by P. jirovecii. Chest radiography will classically show bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates (see below). Finally, methenamine silver staining allows for visualization of disc-shaped P. jirovecii cysts, which is necessary to make a definitive diagnosis.  



Image reproduced from Radiopaedia

Option Analysis

❌ Detection of bacterial antigen in urine:
Incorrect: Legionella pneumophila and Streptococcus pneumoniae infection can be diagnosed using urinary antigen testing. However, this patient’s elevated lactate dehydrogenase level and history of immunosuppression are more concerning for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. 
✅ Presence of organisms in sputum that stain positive for methenamine silver:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Growth of bacteria on cholesterol-rich agar:
Incorrect:Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common bacterial cause of community-acquired pneumonia in young adults and is transmitted from person to person primarily via respiratory droplets. The pathogen can grow on a type of cholesterol-rich agar known as Eaton agar. However, this patient is taking multiple immunosuppressants and has an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, which are more concerning for infection by a different pathogen.
❌ Identification of Gram-positive diplococci on sputum analysis  :
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive diplococci and is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. However, pneumococcal pneumonia typically presents with more rapid onset and often causes lobar consolidation, as opposed to diffuse, bilateral interstitial infiltrates.
❌ Visualization of acid-fast organisms on sputum microscopy:
Incorrect: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an acid-fast organism that can cause respiratory infection. Since Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an aerobic organism, it preferentially colonizes the upper lobes of the lungs, where oxygen concentration is highest. Patients can present with hemoptysis, night sweats, and weight loss.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman goes to an urgent care center for evaluation of left ear pain. The patient recently travelled to Las Vegas for a friend's bachelorette party, and upon returning, noticed her ear had become red, itchy, and painful. She also has difficulty hearing out of the left ear. Past medical history is notable for chronic ear infections as a child. The patient takes only birth control pills. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination reveals an erythematous ear canal and the presence of yellowish-grey cerumen. The tympanic membrane is mildly erythematous but nondistended. Pain is elicited with manipulation of the pinna. Further discussion with the patient will most likely reveal which of the following historical features?
questions.solution:
This patient has left ear pain, itching, and erythema. The physical examination demonstrates the presence of erythema and cerumen in the external ear canal. These findings are consistent with otitis externa. Additional history is most likely to reveal recent hot tub usage, as water exposure is a known risk factor for the development of this condition.

Otitis externa refers to inflammation of the external auditory canal or auricle. Clinically, it presents with ear pain, pruritus, erythema, and discharge. Patients will often have reproducible pain with pressure or manipulation of the auricle.

The most common infectious cause of otitis externa is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is primarily a water-borne pathogen. Otitis externa can also be caused by Staphylococcus species and other bacteria, and less commonly by fungi (e.g. Aspergillus) and viruses (e.g. varicella-zoster virus).

The greatest risk factor for developing otitis externa is prolonged exposure to water (e.g., swimming pools, hot tubs), and hence the condition is colloquially termed “swimmer’s ear.” Other risk factors include recent trauma or manipulation of the outer ear, usage of devices such as hearing aids, and skin conditions such as atopic dermatitis and psoriasis that damage the skin’s integrity in the external ear.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recent hot tub usage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eustachian tube dysfunction:
Incorrect: Eustachian tube dysfunction is a known risk factor for the development of acute otitis media. However, this patient’s physical exam demonstrates erythema as well as cerumen in the external ear canal, which is more consistent with otitis externa.
❌ Application of new sunscreen:
Incorrect: Any new topical exposure to the skin can cause atopic dermatitis, but this condition would likely present with an erythematous pruritic rash without evidence of involvement of the ear canal. In contrast, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with otitis externa.
❌ Recent upper respiratory tract infection  :
Incorrect: A recent upper respiratory tract infection can cause eustachian tube swelling and dysfunction. It can predispose patients to acute otitis media. However, it is not a known risk factor for the development of otitis externa.
❌ Exposure to tobacco smoke:
Incorrect: Exposure to tobacco smoke is a risk factor for the development of acute otitis media, along with air pollution, family history, and age. However, this patient has erythema as well as cerumen in the external ear canal, which is more consistent with otitis externa.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent because of a rash. She reports that yesterday, a rash appeared on his face that has now spread over his entire body. The patient has also been having cough, rhinorrhea and pink eyes for the past 3-4 days. The patient lives with his parents and 2 cats. He has not received vaccinations due to parental preference. Approximately 2 weeks ago, the patient returned from a trip to the Philippines after visiting his grandparents. Temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 27/min and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a tired and restless child. The patient has a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash all over the body except the palms and soles. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Which of the following is most commonly associated with this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of flu-like symptoms (cough, rhinorrhea and pink eyes), followed by high grade fever and maculopapular rash, is consistent with measles (rubeola), most likely due to the lack of childhood vaccination.  

Measles is a highly contagious viral disease caused by the “measles virus,” of the family Paramyxoviridae. It spreads by respiratory droplets which can remain airborne for several hours in a closed space (e.g., schools, physicians’ offices, etc.). It can also spread via direct contact of respiratory particles with a mucosal surface. Non-immunized patients are at high-risk. The incubation period is ~10 days to fever onset and 14 days to rash onset.  

Clinically, it is characterized by a prodromal illness of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by Koplik spots (small white spots on the inside of the cheeks opposite the molars). After 2-4 days, a red, blotchy, maculopapular rash appears and spreads in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing palms and soles).


Reproduced from wikipedia

The rash then coalesces and may develop into a non blanching dark reddish brown rash. It usually fades after 4 days, leading into the recovery phase which can last for another 10-14 days, with the final symptom usually being a persistent cough. Recovered patients develop life-long immunity.  

Short term complications associated with measles include pneumonia, diarrhea, and acute encephalitis. Pneumonia is the most common cause of measles-associated death in children. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare complication that appears several years after apparent recovery from initial infection.


Option Analysis

❌ Ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products:
Incorrect: Ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products is associated with Salmonella, E. coli, Listeria, Campylobacter and other foodborne organisms. Patients usually present with diarrhea, fever, and stomach cramps. In this case, a maculopapular rash following a viral prodrome is suggestive of measles.
❌ Chronic exposure to cat feces:
Incorrect: Chronic exposure to cat feces is associated with the development of Toxoplasma gondii. The patients usually present with mononucleosis-like symptoms (pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy). In immunocompromised patients, it may progress to cause brain abscesses, which are seen as multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI. A maculopapular rash following a viral prodrome is instead suggestive of measles.
✅ Lack of childhood vaccinations:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Vitamin A deficiency:
Incorrect: Although vitamin A supplementation has been shown to improve mortality in patients with measles, its deficiency does not predispose to the development of the illness.
❌ Tick bite:
Incorrect: Lyme disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi is transmitted by the Ixodes deer tick. It is common in the northeastern United States. Patients initially present with erythema migrans (typical “bulls-eye” configuration) and flu-like symptoms, which may be followed by facial nerve palsy (typically bilateral), arthritis and heart block.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of a sore throat and fever. The patient’s parent states, “She has been having a sore throat for three days now, and she’s also had some difficulty eating.” Past medical history is unremarkable, and she is up to date on all vaccinations. Physical examination demonstrates bilateral tonsillar swelling with exudate and submandibular lymphadenopathy. Additional physical examination findings are demonstrated below.


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following substances synthesized by the causative pathogen is most likely responsible for this patient’s dermatologic findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has findings consistent with scarlet fever, including a diffuse scarlatiniform rash, strawberry tongue, and exudative pharyngitis. The condition is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. The virulence factor responsible for the dermatologic findings is streptococcal erythrogenic exotoxin.

Scarlet fever refers to a constellation of symptoms due Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis that includes sore throat, fever, lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse erythematous rash. The rash is a consequence of streptococcal erythrogenic exotoxin, which acts as a superantigen that induces inflammation by nonspecifically activating T-cells and stimulating inflammatory cytokine production.

The rash is frequently described as small, red papules that give the skin a “sand-paper like” texture. The rash typically begins at the skin folds and spreads to involve most of the body’s surface area. After approximately one week, the rash begins to desquamate (shedding of the outer layer of skin). In addition, this rash can manifest on the tongue, giving a characteristic strawberry appearance.

Option Analysis

✅ Erythrogenic exotoxin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cord factor:
Incorrect: Cord factor is a pathogenic factor associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis and aids in granuloma formation. However, it is not associated with Streptococcus pyogenes or the pathogenesis of scarlet fever.
❌ Toxin B:
Incorrect: Toxin B is produced by Clostridium difficile and results in destabilization of the actin cytoskeleton. The pathogen can result in abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. However, Clostridium difficile is not involved in the pathogenesis of scarlet fever.
❌ IgA protease:
Incorrect: IgA protease is a virulence factor synthesized by organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, as well as Neisseria gonorrhoeae. IgA protease allows these pathogens to adhere to and proliferate on mucous membranes. In contrast, IgA protease is not implicated in the pathogenesis of scarlet fever.
❌ Streptolysin O:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O is a virulence factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. It can cause beta-hemolysis and cell membrane degeneration. However, it is not involved in the pathogenesis of scarlet fever.

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department in winter for evaluation of increased work of breathing. According to his parents, the patient developed a runny nose and congestion earlier in the week. However, over the past day, he also began experiencing cough, fever, and shortness of breath. The patient is otherwise healthy, was born full-term, and is up-to-date on all vaccinations. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 90/52 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have nasal flaring, subcostal retractions, and bilateral end-expiratory wheezing. Bedside nasal suctioning is performed and leads to symptomatic improvement. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with congestion progressing to cough, wheezing, and increased work of breathing. In the pediatric population, particularly infants less than 2-years-old, these symptoms are most consistent with viral bronchiolitis. It is most often caused by the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

Bronchiolitis is a respiratory illness usually affecting children aged less than 2-years-old. It is characterized by upper airway disease (e.g., cough, runny nose) followed by lower airway involvement (e.g., wheezing, rales) several days later. The most common precipitant is respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), which belongs to the family of paramyxoviridae. Less common causes include the parainfluenza virus, influenza virus, and adenovirus. The disease is usually observed in the winter or fall given the virus’s enhanced ability to survive in colder, drier conditions.

Bronchiolitis is diagnosed clinically, and treatment is primarily supportive via administration of antipyretics, fluids, and suctioning of secretions. However, infants with cardiopulmonary comorbidities, immunosuppression, or preterm birth are at risk for severe disease requiring non-invasive ventilation or mechanical ventilation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Respiratory syncytial virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Parainfluenza virus 1:
Incorrect: Parainfluenza virus types 1 and 2 are the most common cause of croup. These viruses are occasionally implicated in the development of bronchiolitis, which manifests with wheezing and increased respiratory effort. However, the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the most common cause of bronchiolitis.
❌ Adenovirus:
Incorrect: This patient presents with wheezing and increased respiratory effort, which are concerning for bronchiolitis. The condition is most commonly caused by the respiratory syncytial virus. In contrast, adenovirus is more often associated with pharyngitis, pneumonia, and hemorrhagic cystitis.
❌ Rhinovirus:
Incorrect: Rhinoviruses are the most common cause of the common cold, which can manifest with cough, nasal congestion, sore throat, and malaise. Although this patient has some cold-like symptoms, he also has bilateral wheezing and increased work of breathing, which are suggestive of bronchiolitis. Rhinoviruses are not the most common cause of bronchiolitis.
❌ Orthomyxovirus:
Incorrect: Orthomyxoviruses can cause influenza-like illness, which is characterized by fever, myalgia, rigors, and fatigue. In contrast, orthomyxoviruses are an uncommon cause of bronchiolitis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician for evaluation of skin lesions. The patient’s mother noticed several bumpy skin lesions on her daughter's arm earlier this week. The patient is currently attending daycare and scraped her knee last week but is otherwise healthy. She has not been exposed to any sick contacts, and none of her family members have similar lesions. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for the following finding:

 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

These lesions are nontender to palpation. The pathogen responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation was most likely transmitted in which of the following manners?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with umbilicated papules that are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum. The condition is caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus, which is transmitted via direct contact (e.g, skin to skin contact, fomite to skin contact).

The molluscum contagiosum virus is a DNA poxvirus that generates characteristic skin lesions, most commonly in pediatric patients. These lesions are identified by skin-coloured, dome-shaped papules that average 3-5 mm in diameter and have an area of central umbilication. The lesions are painless and non-tender to palpation. Molluscum contagiosum lesions are most commonly found on the trunk, but they can also be found on the extremities and face.

The presence of molluscum contagiosum papules on or near the groin should prompt concern for sexual transmission. In addition, recurrent or extensive lesions should prompt concern for underlying immunodeficiency (e.g. HIV infection).

Option Analysis

✅ Direct skin to skin transmission:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Respiratory droplets:
Incorrect: This patient has several painless lesions with central umbilication, which is concerning for molluscum contagiosum. It is spread via direct skin contact, not via respiratory droplets. Organisms transmitted via respiratory droplets include paramyxoviruses, orthomyxoviruses, and rhinovirus.
❌ Vector borne transmission:
Incorrect: The molluscum contagiosum virus is not a vector borne virus, meaning it is not transmitted through vectors such as mosquitos or ticks. In contrast, the West Nile virus is an example of a vector borne disease.
❌ Fecal-oral transmission:
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is not transmitted via the fecal-oral route but rather direct skin to skin contact. Adenovirus and hepatitis A are examples of viruses transmitted via the fecal-oral route.
❌ Blood-borne transmission:
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is not transmitted via blood borne transmission but rather direct skin to skin contact.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of vaginal bleeding immediately after sexual intercourse for the last 3 weeks. The patient has taken oral contraceptive pills for the past three months. Her menstrual cycles are regular and occur every 28 days and last for five days. Past medical history is significant for a gonococcal infection four years ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg.  On speculum examination, the cervix appears friable with mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os. Cervical motion tenderness is present. Vaginal swabs are sent to the lab and are pending. This patient should be empirically treated for which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of cervical motion tenderness, a friable cervix, mucopurulent discharge, and vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse. This presentation is consistent with acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis are the leading causes of acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease in patients with female genitalia who are sexually active. In addition to the aforementioned symptoms, associated symptoms may include dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and nonspecific pelvic pain or cramping. Diagnostic evaluation of suspected cervicitis includes a pelvic exam (including a speculum evaluation of the cervix) and nucleic acid amplification tests for both Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhea.

The presence of symptoms suggestive of PID or acute cervicitis requires prompt, empiric antibiotic treatment. Because coinfection with Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis is highly common, first-line outpatient therapy includes both intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline, in order to cover both pathogens.  

Option Analysis

✅ Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
Incorrect: Treatment for acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) should always cover both Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, given the high rate of coinfection. Treatment for one organism (e.g. with ceftriaxone alone) would be inappropriate.  
❌ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Incorrect: Treatment for acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) should always cover both Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, given the high rate of coinfection. Treatment for one organism (e.g. with doxycycline alone) would be inappropriate.  
❌ Candida albicans:
Incorrect: Symptoms of vaginal candidiasis include currying white vaginal precipitate, as opposed to mucopurulent cervical discharge. In addition, this patient’s cervical motion tenderness and cervical friability are characteristic of a diagnosis of acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which are not caused by Candida albicans.  
❌ Trichomonas vaginalis:
Incorrect: While patients with trichomoniasis often present with vaginal discharge, the discharge is characteristically malodorous, and patients often have the additional findings of dysuria and an erythematous, “strawberry” cervix (i.e. punctate hemorrhages). In contrast, this patient’s cervical motion tenderness and cervical friability are characteristic of a diagnosis of acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which are not caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by family for evaluation of muscle pain. The patient is a construction worker and stepped on a rusty nail two weeks ago. The patient did not seek medical care after the incident. A few days ago, the patient noticed painful muscle spasms and difficulty with mouth opening. Temperature is 37.5 °C (99.5 °F), blood pressure is 137/73 mmHg, pulse is 70/min and respirations are 12/min. On physical examination, the patient is unable to open his jaw, and facial expression appears fixed. There is also backwards arching of the neck and head. A deep purulent wound is observed on the sole of the right foot. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of glycine and GABA release into the neuromuscular junction
Reduction of acetylcholine release from intracellular vesicles
Progressive destruction of upper and lower motor neurons

questions.solution:
This patient presents with painful muscle spasms, lockjaw, as well as backward arching of the head, and neck (opisthotonos) after stepping on a rusty nail. These symptoms are concerning for tetanus, which is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani (C. tetani).

C. tetani is an anaerobic Gram-positive bacterium that is ubiquitously present in the soil. Injuries such as deep puncture wounds or crush injuries can enable bacterial spores to enter the body. Afterward, the bacteria are able to proliferate under anaerobic conditions and produce neurotoxins that reach the central nervous system via retrograde axonal transport. The neurotoxins cleave SNARE proteins and block vesicles containing the inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) from being released into the neuromuscular junction. The end result is muscle overactivation and development of muscle spasms.

Symptoms of C. tetani infection (tetanus) include lockjaw, risus sardonicus (persistent smile-like expression due to facial muscle contractions), and opisthotonos (hyperextension of the neck and/or back). In more advanced stages, patients can develop autonomic dysfunction and eventually respiratory arrest (due to diaphragm failure).  

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulation of actin depolymerization:
Incorrect: Toxins produced by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile can enter cells lining the intestinal walls and cause actin depolymerization, thereby increasing epithelial cell permeability and inducing apoptosis. C. difficile infection causes watery diarrhea, not the neuromuscular symptoms seen in this patient.  
❌ Inhibition of elongation factor 2:
Incorrect: The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae inhibits elongation factor 2 (EF-2), leading to the formation of pseudomembranes in the oropharynx. In contrast, this patient has painful muscle spasms, lockjaw, as well as backwards arching of the head, and neck.  
✅ Inhibition of glycine and GABA release into the neuromuscular junction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Reduction of acetylcholine release from intracellular vesicles:
Incorrect: Clostridium botulinum produces a toxin that prevents intracellular vesicles containing acetylcholine from fusing with the cellular membrane, thus preventing acetylcholine release into the neuromuscular junction. Botulism would cause flaccid paralysis, not spastic paralysis.  
❌ Progressive destruction of upper and lower motor neurons:
Incorrect: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is characterized by progressive destruction of upper and lower motor neurons. The condition typically affects individuals in their 50-60s. In contrast, this patient has spastic symptoms after stepping on a rusty nail, which is more concerning for tetanus.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female with a history of Crohn disease is admitted to the hospital with worsening cough, fevers, and night sweats. She is a medical student and recently returned from a mission trip to Honduras. She is otherwise healthy, does not smoke or use illicit drugs, and takes infliximab for management of the inflammatory bowel disease. She subsequently undergoes a lung biopsy, which demonstrates the following microscopic finding:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following cell types is responsible for the development of the observed microscopic lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is currently taking an immunosuppressive agent (infliximab), presents with worsening cough, fevers, and night sweats after returning from a medical mission trip to Honduras. The above microscopic slide demonstrates caseous necrosis, which is consistent with primary pulmonary tuberculosis.

The development of caseous necrosis is mediated by the chemical and immunological responses of both macrophages and T-helper 1 cells. Approximately 3 weeks after infection, tubercular cord factor triggers a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, wherein macrophages housing mycobacteria in phagosomes travel through the pulmonary lymphatics and present mycobacterial antigens to naive CD4 T-helper cells.    

The macrophages also secrete IL-12, which differentiates the CD4 cells into T-helper 1 cells. The T-helper 1 cells then migrate to the site of infection, where they release interferon-gamma and activate additional macrophages. As more macrophages become activated, they recruit even more macrophages and neutrophils via release of TNF-alpha. These cells surround the bacteria and form epithelioid histiocytes, multinucleated Langhans giant cells, and granulomas. Over time, the center of granuloma becomes laden with cellular debris, resulting in the appearance of caseous necrosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ T-helper subtype 1  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eosinophils :
Incorrect: Eosinophils are responsible for fighting parasitic infections, as well as mediating the mechanisms associated with allergies and asthma. Eosinophils are not involved in granuloma formation.   
❌ T-helper subtype 2 :
Incorrect: Th2 cells activate eosinophils and promote IgE production for defense against parasitic infections. Th2 cells are induced by interferon-gamma secreted by Th1 cells. However, Th2 cells do not play a role in granuloma formation.   
❌ B-lymphocytes:
Incorrect: B-lymphocytes are responsible for the development of humoral immunity and antibody production. They are not involved in the formation of caseous granulomas in mycobacterial infection. 
❌ Natural killer cells:
Incorrect: Natural killer cells are members of the innate immune system. They are responsible for triggering apoptosis and death of virally infected cells and tumor cells. However, natural killer cells are not involved in granuloma formation.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male college student is brought to the emergency department by his roommate due to confusion and altered mental status. His roommate says that the patient was in his usual state until 2 days ago, when he started complaining of headaches and fatigue. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented, and nuchal rigidity is noted. Examination of the patient’s left leg is shown below, and similar lesions are seen on the contralateral leg and bilateral arms:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely point of entry of the pathogen responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with headache, confusion, and fever, raising concerns for meningitis. The presence of risk factors (i.e. student dorms), along with petechial rash on the lower limbs, favors the diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis infection.  

Neisseria meningitidis (meningococci) is a gram-negative diplococci that is capable of a variety of clinical manifestations ranging from transient fever and bacteremia to fulminant fatal disease within hours. The bacteria is transmitted through respiratory and oral secretions, whereby it attaches to the mucosal surfaces via pili (fimbriae) and colonizes the nasopharynx. In the nasopharynx, it produces IgA proteases that assist it to evade opsonization and destruction. Through the nasopharynx, the bacteria access the bloodstream, where it utilizes specialized proteins and enzymes to survive within neutrophils, neutralize complement activation and ultimately reach the brain.    

N. meningitidis can be found in the nasopharynx of healthy individuals; however, infection and bacteremia occur more commonly in crowded settings (e.g., dormitories, military barracks) and weakened immunity. Besides meningitis, other possible outcomes of infection include Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (which presents as an acute adrenal insufficiency), disseminated intravascular coagulation, and shock. Diagnosis is made via culture-based tests or PCR. Treatment includes ceftriaxone or penicillin G. Prophylaxis with rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone should be given immediately to all close contacts.  



Option Analysis

❌ Skin wound :
Incorrect: Traumatic skin injury can inoculate bloodstream infections from common pathogens found on the skin. These include bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus or fungi like Candida albicans. Neisseria meningitidis does not spread through skin wounds. 
❌ Gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: Listeria monocytogenes can enter through the gastrointestinal tract; however, this usually occurs in immunocompromised patients or in the context of pregnancy, liver disease, alcoholism, and malignancy. This patient’s presentation is consistent with another diagnosis. 
❌ Ear :
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumonia are a common cause of acute otitis media which can spread to the brain; however, this complication is very rare in developed countries. This patient’s presentation is consistent with another diagnosis. 
✅ Nasopharynx:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Lungs:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumonia can enter the blood through the lungs and result in bacteremia and meningitis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a severe headache, vomiting, and fever. The patient is a military recruit who is three weeks into bootcamp. His friend states that he appeared normal 12 hours ago. Temperature is 39.5 °C (103.1 °F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. The patient is markedly disoriented and unable to answer questions. Physical examination shows positive Kernig and Brudzinski signs. Serum glucose concentration is 90 mg/dL. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid gram stain is shown below:  

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is most likely to reveal which of the following sets of findings?
questions.solution:
This young military recruit is presenting with a severe headache, vomiting, and high-grade fever. In addition, he has altered mental status and positive meningeal signs, which are all consistent with meningitis. Based on the patient’s risk factors, the most likely causative organism is Neisseria meningitidis, which is prevalent in crowded areas like military bases or college dorms, where it can spread quickly via respiratory droplets and oral secretions.  

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is often useful in differentiating the causes of meningitis. Normal CSF glucose concentration is approximately 75% of the serum glucose concentration. The CSF associated with fungal or bacterial meningitis tends to be <40% of blood glucose concentrations, as these microorganisms require glucose for survival and growth. The rapidly dividing bacteria also cause elevated protein and markedly high neutrophil predominant leukocytosis (polymorphonuclear). As opposed to bacterial etiologies, viral and tuberculous meningitis lead to lymphocyte predominant leukocytosis. Next, gram stain of the CSF can help identify the bacterial cause in order to direct the appropriate treatment. In the picture above, gram-negative diplococci can be seen within the neutrophils, which is characteristic of Neisseria meningitidis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)110030015:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)806020:
Incorrect: This cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is consistent with Cryptococcus neoformans, Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease), and Rickettsia meningitis, which tend to exhibit reduced glucose concentrations with a moderately increased lymphocyte count. 
❌ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)704065:
Incorrect: This CSF analysis is consistent with viral meningitis, as characterized by a slightly elevated lymphocyte count, normal glucose, and normal protein levels. 
❌ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)5050020:
Incorrect: This CSF analysis is consistent with tuberculosis (TB) meningitis, as characterized by slightly elevated lymphocyte count, markedly elevated protein level, and usually low glucose. Routine bacterial cultures would be negative.
❌ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)43050:
Incorrect: This cerebrospinal fluid analysis is consistent with normal findings in a healthy person.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic due to burning urination for the past 3 weeks. The patient recently returned from a trip to Egypt, where he hiked and swam in freshwater. During that time, the patient developed an itchy rash over some parts of the body, which self-resolved after a few days. Medical history is unremarkable besides a gonorrhea infection 3 years ago, which was successfully treated with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count shows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40% 
 Leukocyte count  12,100/mm3 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils, segmented  54% 
 Neutrophils, banded  5% 
 Eosinophils  12% 
 Basophils  0% 
 Lymphocytes  25% 
 Monocytes  7% 
Urine sample is obtained and the specimen under light microscopy is shown below:    


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
If left untreated, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has a history of traveling to endemic areas (i.e., Egypt), an itchy rash that appeared after swimming, followed by dysuria, as well as eosinophilia and consistent urinalysis findings, most likely has schistosomiasis. His urinalysis shows the classic appearance of Schistosoma haematobium.  

These parasites live in certain types of freshwater snails. Cercariae, the infectious form of the parasite, emerge from the snail and contaminate the water. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin. After entering the body, the cercariae shed their tails, and become schistosomula, which migrate through the circulation to the liver, where they mature into adults. The adult worms migrate against portal blood flow to the mesenteric venules of the intestine, the mesenteric venules of the colon, or the vesical venous plexus. The males form a groove in which the females reside and deposit the eggs. The eggs travel to the lumen of the intestine (S. mansoni and S. japonicum) or bladder and ureters (S. haematobium) and are excreted in feces or urine.  

The entrapped eggs secrete proteins and carbohydrates that induce a host TH2 immune response, which results in an eosinophilic granulomatous reaction and subsequent tissue inflammation and fibrosis. In the bowel, this inflammation can result in ulceration, blood loss, and scarring. In the liver, the infection can cause periportal fibrosis, portal hypertension, and subsequent esophageal varices. In the bladder, it can result in the development of pseudopolyps and cancer. Specifically, S. haematobium is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Treatment includes praziquantel.    

Option Analysis

❌ Aortitis:
Incorrect: Aortitis, inflammation of the aorta, is a complication of untreated syphilis infection. The first sign of syphilis infection is the appearance of a nontender chancre on the genitals. Aortitis is a late complication seen years later. Syphilis spirochetes can only be visualized under dark-field microscopy, not light microscopy. Also, syphilis causes leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance, not eosinophilia.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 
❌ Rapidly fatal meningoencephalitis :
Incorrect: Rapidly fatal meningoencephalitis is a complication of the protozoa Naegleria fowleri, which is also acquired through swimming in warm freshwater. The protozoa enter the CNS via the cribriform plate.  Diagnosis is made through CSF analysis. This patient’s presentation and findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Bladder cancer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Liver abscess:
Incorrect: Liver abscess is a complication of the GI protozoa, Entamoeba histolytica, which is acquired through ingestion of cysts found in water. It is prevalent in tropical areas with poor sanitation. Infection can be asymptomatic or can lead to fulminate dysentery, bloody diarrhea, weight loss, fatigue, and abdominal pain. Diagnosis can be made by serology, antigen testing, and/or visualizing trophozoites (with engulfed RBCs in the cytoplasm) or cysts containing 4 nuclei in the stool.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Trophozoites with engulfed RBCs  
❌ Swelling in skin :
Incorrect: Swelling of the skin (elephantiasis) is a complication of the parasitic worm Loa loa found in certain rain forests of West and Central Africa. It can also cause blindness. It is transmitted by deer fly, horse fly, and mango fly to the human host through the bite wound. Diagnosis is typically made by visualizing microfilaria of Loa loa in a thin blood smear.


Reproduced from: CDC  
Microfilaria of Loa loa in a thin blood smear

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for a routine health maintenance visit. The patient reports feeling well, and she has been meeting all developmental milestones. She has no chronic medical conditions. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 112/71 mmHg. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. A vaccine that is protective against genital warts and cervical cancer is recommended by the pediatrician and administered during the visit. Which of the following best describes the characteristics of this vaccine and the pathogen that it protects against?
questions.solution:
In the United States, there is a human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine called Gardasil. It is a subunit vaccine, meaning it only includes the antigens that best stimulate the immune system. This vaccine targets 9 HPV strains; the 7 high risk strains, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58, as well as 2 low-risk strains, 6 and 11. Low-risk strains are responsible for causing common warts (verruca vulgaris) and anogenital warts (condyloma accuminata). The high-risk strains are most commonly the cause of cervical cancer. The vaccine is generally administered between 11-12 years of age. 

Option Analysis

❌  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics Inactivated  DNA Virus :
Incorrect: Inactivated vaccines use a pathogen that has been killed by heat or chemicals. Examples include the hepatitis A, polio, rabies, and influenza vaccines. However, none of these vaccines are protective against cervical cancer or genital warts, both of which are caused by HPV.
❌  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics Inactivated  RNA Virus:
Incorrect: Inactivated vaccines are protective against many RNA viruses. These include the hepatitis A, polio, rabies, and influenza vaccines. However, the vaccine protective against cervical cancer and genital warts is a subunit vaccine against HPV.
✅  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics Subunit DNA Virus :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics Subunit RNA Virus:
Incorrect: The HPV vaccine, which protects against genital warts and cervical cancer, is a subunit vaccine. However, HPV is a DNA virus.
❌  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics  Live-attenuated DNA Virus :
Incorrect: Live-attenuated vaccines can protect against conditions caused by DNA viruses, such as varicella and smallpox. Cervical cancer and genital warts are both caused by the DNA virus HPV. However, the vaccine used to prevent HPV is a subunit vaccine.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman at 23 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician for routine follow up. She recently underwent perinatal screening and tested positive for hepatitis B. The pregnancy has otherwise been uncomplicated, and she has no other significant past medical history. During the visit, the patient asks, “How likely is it that I am going to give this disease to my baby?” Her hepatitis panel is demonstrated below:

Which of the following serologic markers indicates a high degree of transmissibility to the fetus?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with serology consistent with chronic hepatitis B of high infectivity, as indicated by her positive serologic test for HBeAg. Of the serologic tests listed, a titer positive for HBeAg confers a high degree of transmissibility and viral replication.  

Multiple serologic tests are used in the diagnosis of hepatitis B infection including: HBsAg, anti-HBs, HBcAg, anti-HBc, HBeAg, and anti-HBe. Hepatitis B s antigen (HBsAg) is a surface antigen that is most commonly used to indicate active infection. Once the body develops antibodies to HBsAg, termed anti-HBs, the patient is deemed recovered or to have complete immunity to the virus.  

The hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is an intracellular antigen that is expressed in infected hepatocytes and indicates active viral replication within hepatocytes. Anti-HBc comes in two distinct forms: IgM, which indicates acute infection or recent infection, and IgG, which indicates resolved or chronic infection.  

Hepatitis E antigen (HBeAg) is a secretory protein that is processed from the precore protein and is considered to be a marker of high HBV replication, infectivity, and transmissibility. The presence of HBeAg is associated with high levels of HBV DNA in serum and thus higher rates of transmission of HBV infection from carrier mothers to their babies and from patient to patient. Antibodies to this protein, deemed anti-HBe, indicate low infectivity.

Option Analysis

✅ HBeAg:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HBsAg:
Incorrect: The hepatitis B surface antigen is most commonly used to screen for evidence of active infection, and antibodies to this antigen indicate active immunity.
❌ HBcAg:
Incorrect: The hepatitis B core antigen is another surface antigen like HBsAg that indicates active viral replication and that the infected person is currently infectious. It does not confer information regarding the degree to which a person is infectious.
❌ Anti-HAV (IgG):
Incorrect: Anti-HAV (IgG) indicates previous infection against hepatitis A. This test does not confer significant information regarding hepatitis B.
❌ Anti-HBc (IgG):
Incorrect: This serologic assay is used to detect for antibodies against HBcAg. IgG indicates that the immune system is mounting a response to a chronic infection.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with a past medical history of COPD and hypertension is brought to the emergency department because of dyspnea over the past 2 days. He has a 25-pack year smoking history. On arrival, the patient has altered mental status and impending respiratory failure. Endotracheal intubation is performed in the emergency department. A chest radiograph demonstrates lung hyperinflation but no consolidation or infiltrates. The patient is started on bronchodilators, antibiotics, and corticosteroid therapy. On the fifth day of hospitalization, while still intubated, the patient develops a fever as well as yellowish, purulent secretions. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 151/85 mmHg. Repeat chest radiograph reveals new right middle lobe infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has fevers, productive cough, and lung infiltrates several days after undergoing endotracheal intubation. He most likely has ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is a type of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) that develops after a patient has been intubated for more than 48 hours.  

Common causes of VAP include bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. These organisms can form biofilms within the endotracheal tube. Individuals on ventilators are unable to cough, and over time, bacteria are able to move from the tube directly into the lungs. Risk factors for developing VAP include older age, prolonged intubation, chronic lung disease (e.g. COPD), depressed mental status, and aspiration.  

Clinically, VAP can manifest with fever, purulent secretions, increased respiratory rate, and decreased oxygen saturation. Chest imaging may demonstrate the presence of new pulmonary infiltrates, and laboratory testing may demonstrate leukocytosis.  

Recommended practices for preventing VAP include avoiding intubation when possible, minimizing sedation, minimizing pooling of secretions above the endotracheal tube cuff, and elevating the head of the bed.  



Option Analysis

❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative coccobacilli that can cause community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient’s current pneumonia developed several days following endotracheal intubation, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP is often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus. 
❌ Legionellia pneumophila:
Incorrect:Legionellia pneumophila can be found in water systems (e.g. water-based cooling systems) and may cause pneumonia. However, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a more common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia and can account for around 25% of cases in some studies.
❌ Mycoplasma pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient developed pneumonia after being intubated for several days, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Mycoplasma pneumoniae is not a well-documented cause of VAP.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive coccus and one of the most common causes of community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient’s current pneumonia developed following endotracheal intubation, which is concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP is commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus.
