✅ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male comes to his primary care physician with worsening lower extremity weakness and fatigue. Over the past year, he has had increased difficulty climbing stairs and pain in his hips while doing so. Moreover, the patient has worsening fatigue, stating “I can only take a few steps before feeling short of breath.” He had an upper respiratory infection two weeks ago. Past medical history is notable for poliomyelitis as a child, hypertension, and asthma. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for asymmetric bilateral lower extremity weakness and atrophy, left greater than right, as well as hypoactive patellar reflexes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of poliomyelitis presents with worsening asymmetric weakness, fatigue, and signs of lower motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., muscle atrophy, hyporeflexia). These findings are consistent with post-polio syndrome.   

Post-polio syndrome refers to new or progressively worsening muscle weakness in survivors of polio and typically manifests decades after the initial infection. The etiology of this syndrome remains unknown. Potential explanations include progressive degeneration of reinnervated motor units, persistence of poliovirus in neural tissue, or induction of autoimmune-mediated neural tissue destruction.  

Clinically, both polio and post-polio syndrome manifest with asymmetric weakness, hypotonia, flaccid paralysis, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, and muscle atrophy. Diagnosis of post-polio syndrome is based primarily on clinical findings, although recovery of the virus is attainable in some circumstances via lumbar puncture or stool samples. 

Option Analysis

✅ Post-polio syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis:
Incorrect: Weakness is a common feature of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, but this disease tends to present with both signs of upper motor neuron (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity) and lower motor neuron (e.g., atrophy, fasciculations, hyporeflexia) disease. This patient has no clinical findings of an upper motor neuron lesion. 
❌ Guillain-Barre syndrome:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome tends to present with symmetric, ascending, bilateral lower extremity weakness. In contrast, this patient has asymmetric weakness and a history of poliomyelitis, which is more concerning for post-polio syndrome. 
❌ Spinal muscular atrophy type 1 :
Incorrect: Werdnig-Hoffman disease, or infantile spinal muscular atrophy type 1, is an inherited lower motor neuron disease that results in degeneration of anterior horn cells. It usually presents between the ages of 6-12 months of life. 
❌  Polymyalgia rheumatica  :
Incorrect: Polymyalgia rheumatica refers to a rheumatologic condition characterized by pain and stiffness in the proximal musculature. It is not associated with muscle atrophy or reduced tendon reflexes.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of left ear pain. The patient's mother states, “He has been tugging on his left ear for the past three days; he just cannot seem to get any relief.”  The patient has been taking tylenol at home for symptomatic relief. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy pediatric patient presents for evaluation of left ear pain, ear tugging, and fever. Otoscopic examination demonstrates a fluid-filled middle ear and bulging tympanic membrane. Given these findings, the patient likely has otitis media, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Otitis media is an acute bacterial infection of the middle ear and is common in children. Clinical features include ear pain, ear tugging, hearing loss, ear drainage, and low-grade fevers. Otoscopic evaluation of the inner ear is necessary for the diagnosis of acute otitis media, which will most commonly demonstrate a bulging and erythematous tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane may also have a white or pale yellow color, reflecting the pus accumulating behind the membrane. In rarer cases, patients may have a perforated tympanic membrane with purulent otorrhea.

If left untreated, acute otitis media may progress to acute mastoiditis, infection of the mastoid bone, which can worsen even further to cause central nervous system infections, such as septic thrombosis, subdural empyema, brain abscess, and epidural abscess. Cases of recurrent otitis media may result in conductive hearing loss, due to either ossicular erosion or tympanic membrane perforation.

Option Analysis

✅ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect:Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of acute otitis externa and malignant otitis externa. However, this patient has a bulging and fluid-filled tympanic membrane, which is more consistent with the presentation of otitis media.
❌ Moraxella Catarrhalis:
Incorrect: Moraxella Catarrhalis is implicated in the pathogenesis of acute otitis media. However, Streptococcus pneumoniae is a more common cause.  
❌ Candida parapsilosis  :
Incorrect: Candida parapsilosis is a rare cause of malignant otitis externa, which can present with necrosis and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal. In contrast, this patient has a bulging and fluid-filled tympanic membrane, which is more suggestive of otitis media.
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus, like Candida parapsilosis, is associated with malignant otitis externa. However, it is not associated with otitis media.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parent for the evaluation of a diffuse rash. The parent reports that the boy had flushed cheeks for the past 2 days. Today in the morning, while dressing him up, she noticed a lace-like rash on his stomach, back and extremities. The patient had a low-grade fever, cough, and sore throat for the past 6 days. He goes to a daycare daily, and a number of children there have reported similar symptoms. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), which is caused by parvovirus B19 infection.   

Parvovirus B19 is part of the parvoviridae family and is a single-stranded DNA virus. It is primarily transmitted by respiratory droplets but transmission can also occur via an infected blood transfusion or from mother to baby through the placenta. It replicates primarily in erythroid progenitors.  

Erythema infectiosum most commonly affects children of early school age and occasionally adults. Infection begins with a minor febrile prodrome ~4–14 days after exposure, and the typical “slapped cheek” rash (relative circumoral pallor) develops several days later. After 2–3 days, the erythematous macular rash may spread to the extremities in a lacy reticular pattern.



Reproduced from Wikipedia

Joint involvement (due to immune complex deposition) is a prominent feature in adult cases. Joints in the hands and the knees are most frequently affected. The symptoms mimic rheumatoid arthritis, and the arthropathy may persist for weeks, months, or years.

Option Analysis

❌ Coxsackievirus:
Incorrect:  Coxsackievirus can cause hand-foot-mouth disease. The majority of patients develop small vesicles on the tongue or oral mucosa, which rapidly rupture to form shallow erosions. The cutaneous manifestations include bilateral macular, maculopapular, or vesicular rash on palms and soles.
❌ Cytomegalovirus:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus typically presents with an infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome and is characterized by fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy.
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Cutaneous manifestations of streptococcus pyogenes infection (e.g. scarlet fever) include a sand-paper like rash along with pharyngitis. In children <3 years of age, it usually presents with nasal congestion, discharge, low-grade fever (e.g. <38.3°C [101°F]), and tender anterior cervical adenopathy.
✅ Parvovirus B19:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Human herpesvirus-6:
Incorrect: Roseola infantum is caused by Human Herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) and classically presents with a fever for 3-5 days followed by a maculopapular rash.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of sinus pressure. The patient has had a stuffy nose with purulent nasal discharge for the past two weeks. In addition, he has been experiencing headaches and ear fullness. His symptoms began improving around 11-12 days after onset but then took a turn for the worse. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin daily. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/71 mmHg. Physical exam demonstrates tenderness to palpation over the bilateral maxillary sinuses. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of rhinosinusitis including nasal discharge, ear fullness, headache, and sinus tenderness. Given the patient’s prolonged course of illness, biphasic pattern, and presence of purulent discharge, his presentation is most consistent with bacterial rhinosinusitis. The condition is often caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Rhinosinusitis is characterized by inflammation and obstruction of sinus drainage through the nasal cavities. Viral pathogens, such as rhinovirus, influenza virus, and parainfluenza viruses, are the most common cause. Bacterial causes of rhinosinusitis include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophiluus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

As these pathogens infect the nasal mucosa, inflammation follows, causing hypersecretion and increased vascular permeability. These changes result in extravasation of fluids into the nasal cavity and sinuses. Furthermore, many of these pathogens exert direct toxic effect on nasal cilia, impairing mucociliary clearance. Ultimately, this combination of mucosal edema, thickened secretions, and impaired mucociliary clearance results in sinus obstruction.

Rhinosinusitis can manifest with nasal discharge, sinus fullness or pressure, headache, fever, ear pressure, and loss of smell. In viral rhinosinusitis, symptoms typically resolve in 7-10 days. In contrast, bacterial rhinosinusitis often persists beyond ten days, and patients can experience a biphasic illness pattern, which is characterized by initial symptomatic improvement followed by subsequent exacerbation. If untreated, bacterial rhinosinusitis can lead to infection of the deeper facial structures, potentially causing orbital cellulitis, meningitis, or cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Findings associated with Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis include fever, tonsillar swelling with exudates, and tender lymphadenopathy. If left untreated, patients may develop complications such as rheumatic fever and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. However, S. pyogenes is not a common cause of rhinosinusitis.
❌ Moraxella catarrhalis :
Incorrect: Moraxella catarrhalis is a well established etiology of bacterial sinusitis. However, it is overall a less common cause than Streptococcus pneumoniae.
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: This patient presents with purulent nasal discharge, headaches, ear fullness, and sinus tenderness. These symptoms are concerning for bacterial rhinosinusitis. Staphylococcus aureus is not a well established cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis. Instead, the pathogen is more commonly implicated in skin and soft tissue infections, septic arthritis, and osteomyelitis.
❌ Enterococcus faecalis:
Incorrect: Enterococcus faecalis is part of the normal colonic flora. It can give rise to urinary tract infections, biliary tract infections, and subacute endocarditis. However, it is not a well-documented cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with increased work of breathing. His parents, who are at the bedside, recall that the patient developed a “stuffy nose” two days ago. This morning, he was noted to have a hoarse voice, drooling, and increased work of breathing. The patient was born full-term at home and has rarely seen a physician. Past medical history is otherwise noncontributory. Temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is noted to be leaning forward with the neck hyperextended and chin thrust forward. The patient is drooling and has stridorous breathing. Radiographic imaging reveals the following finding:



Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following best describes the medication that would have been most effective in preventing this patient’s current symptoms?

choices.text: Type b capsular polysaccharide conjugated to diphtheria toxoid
Monoclonal antibody that binds RSV envelope fusion protein
Purified polysaccharides from Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci

questions.solution:
This patient presents with dysphagia, drooling, respiratory distress, and neck imaging demonstrating a swollen epiglottis. He likely has epiglottitis. This condition has become increasingly rare due to widespread administration of the Hib subunit vaccine, which consists of the type b capsular polysaccharide conjugated to diphtheria toxoid. However, unvaccinated children are still at risk for developing the condition.

The most common infectious organism associated with pediatric epiglottitis is Haemophilus influenzae (specifically type B). In contrast, the underlying etiology of adult epiglottitis is more varied. Infection by H. influenzae results in cellulitis of the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and adjacent tissue, which rapidly progresses to edema and narrowing of the airway.

The condition can manifest with fever, stridor, dysphagia, respiratory distress, and significant anxiety. Classically, patients will also lean their trunk forward and hyperextend the neck with chin protrusion to maximize airway opening. The posture is termed the “sniffing position” or “tripod position.” Lateral neck radiographs will often demonstrate the thumbprint sign due to an edematous glottis.

If untreated, epiglottitis can rapidly progress to loss of the airway and hypoxemic arrest. Patients should be judiciously evaluated for impending airway collapse, and endotracheal intubation may be necessary. Furthermore, if untreated, epiglottitis can progress to epiglottic abscess and bacteremia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Type b capsular polysaccharide conjugated to diphtheria toxoid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of peptidoglycan cross-linking:
Incorrect: This patient has dysphagia, drooling, respiratory distress, and a swollen epiglottis on neck imaging. He likely has epiglottitis. Cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone and cefotaxime, can be used to treat epiglottitis. However, these medications are not used for prophylaxis.
❌ Monoclonal antibody that binds RSV envelope fusion protein:
Incorrect: Palvizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds RSV envelope fusion protein (RSV F), thereby preventing the virus from fusing with host cells. The medication can be administered to premature and high risk infants for RSV prophylaxis. However, Palivizumab would be ineffective in preventing the Haemophilus influenzae infection that likely precipitated this patient’s epiglottitis.
❌ Inactivated orthomyxovirus:
Incorrect: The yearly influenza vaccine involves administration of a live-attenuated version of the influenza virus, which is a type of orthomyxovirus. The vaccine allows the recipient to develop antibodies against viral neuraminidase and hemagglutinin receptors, thereby helping confer immunity. However, the influenza virus does not lead to epiglottitis.
❌ Purified polysaccharides from Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci:
Incorrect: The pneumococcal vaccine protects against infection by the Gram-positive, lancet-shaped bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae. Although Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause epiglottitis, Haemophilus influenzae is overall a more common cause in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the clinic with inguinal ulcers that he noticed two days ago. He is sexually active and began a relationship with a new partner one month ago. They use condoms inconsistently. He immigrated from Papua New Guinea two months ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Shallow, nontender ulcers are noted along the shaft and base of the penis with associated erythema. Painful, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. An additional flesh-colored papule is noted at the base of the penis. Which of the following is most likely the causative organism responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of a non-tender papule, multiple painless ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. These findings suggest lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which is caused by serotypes L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis.

LGV begins as a primary infection in the genitals and spreads via a direct extension to draining lymph nodes in the pelvis (superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes). The primary infection is usually indolent and is often missed as it is not associated with accompanying symptoms (though in some cases, proctitis may be the initial presenting symptom). This lymphatic infection ultimately results in a lymphoproliferative inflammatory reaction and painful lymphadenopathy. However, in individuals with female genitalia, lymphadenopathy is unlikely as the vagina and the cervix drain to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes (not the inguinal lymph nodes).

If these lesions are left untreated, the infection can progress to the formation of painful inguinal buboes with subsequent lymphatic fibrosis and stricture formation. Diagnosis is accomplished via nucleic acid amplification testing of sample fluid.

Genital ulcers in sexually active individuals raise concern for infection from several organisms, which requires prompt identification and treatment. Recalling the nature of the ulcer (painful vs. painless, multiple vs. single) and features of lymphadenopathy can assist in diagnosis, as outlined in the table below.
 


Option Analysis

✅ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Treponema pallidum:
Incorrect: Syphilis is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum. Clinical manifestations include a single, nontender genital ulcer. Painful, purulent lymphadenopathy or buboes would be atypical.  
❌ Herpes simplex virus-2:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex infection typically causes multiple, painful genital ulcers. This patient’s ulcers are nontender.  
❌ Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes urethritis in individuals with male genitalia, presenting with purulent urethral discharge and pruritus. This patient’s nontender ulcers and painful lymphadenopathy suggests an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Haemophilus ducreyi:
Incorrect: Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which presents with multiple, tender purulent genital ulcers. This patient’s ulcers are nontender.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right knee pain for the past two days. Medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and knee osteoarthritis status post-bilateral total knee arthroplasty. Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), blood pressure is 142/89 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min and SpO2 is 99% of room air. On physical examination, the right knee appears swollen and is tender to palpation. An arthrocentesis is performed and cultures reveal a Gram-positive coccus which is catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. Which of the following organisms was most likely identified?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of bilateral total knee arthroplasty and presents with a swollen and tender right knee joint. These findings are concerning for a prosthetic joint infection.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a Gram-positive, catalase-positive and coagulase-negative organism that is commonly implicated in device-associated infections. The organism is also novobiocin sensitive, meaning that the bacteria will die off when exposed to this antibiotic. Staphylococcus epidermidis is able to secrete extracellular polysaccharide, which facilitates biofilm formation and enables the organism to adhere to the surface of devices and prostheses.

Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcus epidermidis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: The organism isolated from the joint aspirate is a Gram-positive coccus. In contrast, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative rod.  
❌ Candida albicans:
Incorrect: Candida albicans is the most common fungal cause of prosthetic joint infection. In contrast, this patient’s joint aspirate is growing bacteria.  
❌ Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus  :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is Gram-positive and coagulase-positive. It is also a common cause of prosthetic joint infections. However, the bacteria in this patient’s joint is coagulase-negative.
❌ Streptococcus viridans  :
Incorrect: Streptococcus viridans is a Gram-positive organism that is associated with dental caries and endocarditis. The organism, however, does not produce catalase and is not a common cause of prosthetic joint infections.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician due to a facial rash. The rash started one week ago as a small vesicle and has enlarged. The rash is itchy and painful. Physical examination shows erythematous plaque with a honey-colored crust on the left maxilla. Culture is taken from the lesion and positive for group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes). The child is at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?

choices.text: No increased risk of long-term complications

questions.solution:
This child has impetigo, a superficial skin infection characterized by an erythematous plaque with a honey-colored crust. Streptococcus pyogenes, also known as group A strep (GAS), is one of the causative agents of non-bullous impetigo.

GAS is a Gram-positive bacterium that can cause two types of infections: skin infections (e.g., impetigo, erysipelas, cellulitis) and pharyngitis. Infections with GAS can lead to severe sequelae, which are mainly immunological. The most feared sequelae are acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) and acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Patients with GAS skin infections are at increased risk of PSGN but not ARF. On the other hand, patients with GAS pharyngitis are at increased risk of both PSGN and ARF.

Option Analysis

✅ Glomerulonephritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mitral valve stenosis:
Incorrect: Mitral valve stenosis is a long-term complication of acute rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease. Acute rheumatic fever is a feared complication of pharyngitis caused by S. pyogenes but does not occur from the strains of S. pyogenes causing skin infections (e.g., impetigo).  
❌ Acute rheumatic fever:
Incorrect: Acute rheumatic fever is a feared complication of pharyngitis caused by S. pyogenes. However, acute rheumatic fever does not occur from the strains of S. pyogenes causing skin infections.  
❌ Recurrence of the infection:
Incorrect: There is no increased risk of recurrence of impetigo compared to the average population.  
❌ No increased risk of long-term complications:
Incorrect: Glomerulonephritis is a known possible complication of impetigo caused by S. pyogenes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to a sore throat and fever. The patient's symptoms started three days ago. Examination of the patient’s throat shows wide exudates on the tonsils, pharyngeal erythema, and cervical adenopathy.  A pharyngeal swab is performed and sent to the laboratory for Gram stain and culture, and bloodwork is drawn. The patient is started immediately on antibiotics.  Anti-streptolysin O antibody titers return several days later and are elevated. Which of the following characteristics of the most likely pathogen causing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: It causes alpha hemolysis on blood agar

questions.solution:
This patient likely has pharyngitis due to Streptococcus pyogenes (group A strep) because of the classic symptoms (fever, tonsillar exudate, cervical lymphadenopathy, lack of cough) and elevated anti-streptolysin O antibody titers. These antibody titers usually become positive/elevated several days to a week after the initial infection.

GAS is a Gram-positive catalase-negative coccus that clusters in chains and pairs. On blood agar, GAS causes beta-hemolysis, which is mainly mediated by the exotoxins of the bacteria (i.e., streptolysin O). GAS is encapsulated, which helps in preventing phagocytosis.

GAS that helps distinguish it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci (e.g. Streptococcus agalactiae) is pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR)-positive. GAS produces an enzyme called L-pyrrolidinyl arylamidase that converts pyrrolidonyl beta-naphthylamide to beta-naphthylamide. If pyrrolidonyl beta-naphthylamide were added to a culture of GAS, it would convert to beta-naphthylamide, which reacts with N-methylamino-cinnamaldehyde to produce a red color. The red color confirms that the bacteria is PYR-positive (i.e. produces this enzyme).  


Option Analysis

✅ It is pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR)-positive  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is catalase-positive  :
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes, like all other streptococci, is catalase negative.  
❌ It is a non-encapsulated bacterium:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes is an encapsulated bacterium.  
❌ It causes alpha hemolysis on blood agar:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes causes beta hemolysis on blood agar.  
❌ It produces a CAMP factor  :
Incorrect: Group B strep (Streptococcus agalactiae) produces CAMP, not group A strep (Streptococcus pyogenes).

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past five days. During this time the patient has had around six watery bowel movements per day. Medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient was recently treated for a dental abscess with amoxicillin and then clindamycin. The patient drinks only bottled water and has not recently traveled. Temperature is 38.2 °C (100.8 °F), blood pressure is 135/86 mmHg, pulse is 103/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and SpO2 is 100% in room air. On physical examination, there are dry mucous membranes and diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation. Which of the following best characterizes the effects of the bacterial toxin most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of glycine and GABA release
Inhibition of fat absorption from gastrointestinal tract

questions.solution:
This patient has abdominal pain and multiple watery stools per day after a recent antibiotic regimen. These symptoms are likely due to infection by the bacterium Clostridioides difficile(formerly Clostridium difficile), which releases toxins that disrupt actin polymerization.

The bacterium produces two toxins, toxin A and toxin B. The toxins enter cells lining the intestinal walls and cause actin depolymerization, thereby increasing epithelial cell permeability and causing apoptosis. The clinical effects of the two toxins include watery diarrhea and possibly pseudomembranous colitis, which is severe inflammation of the inner lining of the large intestines. Patients with C. difficile colitis must be treated with antibiotics. Care must be taken to wash hands with soap and water, as hand sanitizing solution does not often kill the C. difficile spores.  


Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of elongation factor 2  :
Incorrect: The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae inhibits elongation factor 2 (EF-2), leading to the formation of pseudomembranes in the pharynx. It does not cause copious diarrhea.  
❌ Inhibition of glycine and GABA release:
Incorrect: The bacterium Clostridium tetani releases an exotoxin that inhibits glycine and GABA release at the neuromuscular junction, thus causing tetanus. Tetanus is characterized by spastic paralysis, as opposed to watery diarrhea.  
❌ Inhibition of fat absorption from gastrointestinal tract  :
Incorrect: This patient developed new diarrhea after starting an antibiotic regimen, which is concerning for infection by the bacterium C. difficile. Decreased fat absorption is more commonly from chronic processes such as chronic pancreatitis.  
✅ Stimulation of actin depolymerization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Overactivation of adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: Vibrio cholera can cause watery diarrhea via a toxin that leads to overactivation of adenylate cyclase. The bacterium predominantly affects individuals in developing countries who drink contaminated water. This patient only drinks bottled water and symptoms started after antibiotic use.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with HIV comes to the clinic due to the recent appearance of skin nodules and progressive fatigue and anorexia for the past 2 months. She recently moved to Ohio and started working in a pet store. She is currently not taking antiretroviral therapy, and her recent CD4 count one month ago was 80 cells/mm3. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows multiple small red-purple papules, some of which are pedunculated and some bleed. Histopathology of one of the lesions shows vascular proliferation with some clusters of neutrophils and lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with fever, fatigue, anorexia and characteristic skin lesions, most likely has bacillary angiomatosis.  

Bacillary angiomatosis is caused by Bartonella species, a fastidious, slow-growing, gram-negative bacillus. The natural reservoir is domestic cats and is transmitted to humans via scratch, bite, or exposure to cat feces/fleas. Cat-scratch disease (CSD) usually affects immunocompetent children and presents as regional limited lymphadenopathy/lymphadenitis. Immunodeficient individuals, however, are at risk for developing disseminated bacillary angiomatosis which usually occurs when CD4 count is less than 100 cells/mm3.    

Patients with bacillary angiomatosis often present with constitutional symptoms, including fever, chills, malaise, headache, anorexia, weight loss and unique vascular lesions. The skin is the most affected organ, but the lesions can occur throughout the body (e.g., bone, lymph nodes, GI). The lesions may start as red to purple papules which gradually expand into pedunculated lesions or nodules that become friable and bleed. Biopsy shows vascular proliferation with clusters of neutrophils and lymphocytes infiltrating. Diagnosis is challenging and usually requires a combination of tests including culture, PCR, biopsy, and staining with Warthin-Starry silver staining. Treatment consists of prolonged courses of either erythromycin or doxycycline.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blastomycosis dermatitis:
Incorrect: Blastomycosis dermatitis is a systemic pyogranulomatous infection caused by inhalation of the spores of the dimorphic fungus, which is prevalent in North America. Pulmonary involvement is the most common manifestation, and patients may present with acute or chronic pneumonia. Skin involvement is also common, and present as gray to violet, verrucous skin lesions with an irregular border that may mimic squamous cell carcinoma. Biopsy from the margins typically shows broad-based budding organisms on microscopy. This patient’s characteristic nodules, biopsy results and the absence of pulmonary involvement favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Human herpesvirus 8 :
Incorrect: Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is an angioproliferative disorder caused by infection with human herpesvirus 8 (HSV-8), often seen in immunocompromised patients. KS can involve virtually any site in the body, however, cutaneous disease is most common. The lesions of KS can be pink, red, purple, or brown, and they tend to be elliptical, not painful or pruritic, and without necrosis. There are generally no associated constitutional symptoms. Additionally, histopathology analysis in KS will likely show whorls of spindle-shaped cells with lymphocytic infiltration, not neutrophilic infiltration, as well as proliferation of small vessels.  
✅ Bartonella henselae :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Yersinia pestis:
Incorrect: Yersinia pestis is a zoonotic infection that causes plague. It is transmitted by bites from rodent fleas, scratches or bites from infected domestic cats, and inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected animals. The most common manifestation is acute febrile lymphadenitis (bubonic plague). It is characterized by the acute onset of fever, chills, weakness, and headache, followed by intense pain and swollen lymphadenopathy. Skin lesions may appear and include eschars, pustules, or lesions resembling ecthyma gangrenosum. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Rickettsia rickettsii  :
Incorrect: Rickettsia rickettsii is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a tick-borne disease (Dermacentor dog tick). Patients often present with non-specific symptoms such as fever, headache, malaise, myalgias, and arthralgias followed by blanching erythematous rash with macules that later become petechial. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is currently postoperative day 5 after having an open cholecystectomy. She reports worsening suprapubic pain and malaise.  Her vital signs are 37 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 137/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination shows suprapubic tenderness on palpation as well as cloudy urine in her Foley catheter. Which of the following pathogens is most likely causative of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a nosocomial urinary tract infection following Foley catheter placement for her cholecystectomy. Of the pathogens listed, the Enterococcus species has the highest association with catheter-associated urinary tract infections; it is also commonly multidrug resistant.  

Many bacterial species are known to cause both hospital and community acquired urinary tract infections. Overall, Escherichia coli is the most common cause in both of these settings. Other pathogens associated with nosocomial urinary tract infections include enterococcus, serratia marcescens, and pseudomonas aeruginosa. In sexually active women, Staphylococcus Saprophyticus is the second leading cause of urinary tract infections. Proteus mirabilis is commonly associated with chronic urinary tract infections and the formation of struvite stones or staghorn calculi.   

Option Analysis

✅ Enterococcus species:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Klebsiella pneumoniae   :
Incorrect: Klebsiella pneumonia is the third leading cause of urinary tract infections overall. While it is classified as a known cause of nosocomial urinary tract infections, it is overall less common than Enterococcus species.   
❌ Proteus mirabilis:
Incorrect: Proteus mirabilis is associated with chronic pyelonephritis. It is not associated with nosocomial urinary tract infections.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause of urinary tract infections overall, and it is unlikely in this patient presenting with a nosocomial urinary tract infection.   
❌ Staphylococcus saprophyticus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common urinary tract infection in individuals engaging in frequent sexual intercourse. It is unlikely in this patient presenting with a nosocomial urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a 6-week history of malaise, chills, and fevers. He additionally has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over this same time period. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, as well as a known mitral valve prolapse. The patient reports he has otherwise been in his usual state of health and endorses compliance with his home medication regimen. He has a past surgical history of total hip replacement at 61, as well as a molar tooth extraction two months ago. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a 3/6 holosystolic murmur present at the apex that radiates to the left axilla. Blood is drawn and sent for culture. Three days later, 3 of 4 blood cultures obtained on admission grow Gram-positive, alpha-hemolytic bacteria. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen implicated in this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
Subacute bacterial endocarditis is commonly caused by bacteria from the group of viridans streptococci, which includes the organisms S. mutans and S. sanguineous. Viridans streptococci are found in abundance as normal oral flora, and if they gain access to the bloodstream via dental procedures or persistent gum bleeding from gingivitis, they can cause subacute bacterial endocarditis in patients with preexisting cardiac lesions.  

As the name implies, subacute bacterial endocarditis progresses slowly, with symptoms often taking weeks to months to manifest. Subacute bacterial endocarditis tends to affect native, diseased heart valves. Previously, rheumatic heart disease was the most common disorder in developed countries as the leading cardiac lesion in patients with infective endocarditis; however, over the last few decades, mitral valve prolapse has replaced this as the most common underlying cardiac lesion. The patient in this vignette has known mitral valve prolapse.  

Patients with subacute bacterial endocarditis present with a chronic history of nonspecific symptoms. Fever is the most common symptom in infective endocarditis (IE), and it is often associated with chills, anorexia, and weight loss. Relatively uncommon clinical manifestations, yet pathognomonic of IE, include Janeway lesions (nontender erythematous macules on the palms and soles), Osler nodes (tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes), and Roth spots (exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina).  

Option Analysis

❌ Staphylococcus aureus  :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is the most commonly implicated bacteria causing endocarditis in patients with IV drug use, and it most commonly affects the tricuspid valve. Involvement of the tricuspid valve typically presents with tricuspid regurgitation, which results in a new-onset holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. It typically causes a more acute and rapidly progressive infection, and therefore this patient’s more subacute disease process is less suggestive of S. aureus as the cause. Moreover, S. aureus is beta-hemolytic on blood agar, not alpha-hemolytic.   
❌ Streptococcus bovis:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a common cause of endocarditis in patients with underlying colorectal cancer. However, S. bovis is a Gram-positive, gamma-hemolytic bacteria on blood agar.   
✅ Streptococcus mutans:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Coxiella burnetii:
Incorrect: Coxiella burnetii can cause endocarditis in the setting of patients with a history of contact with livestock. This patient lacks the occupational risk factors that would increase his exposure to this pathogen; additionally, C. burnetti is a Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterial pathogen, making it extremely difficult to culture on agar.  
❌ Bartonella henselae:
Incorrect: Bartonella henselae causes a disease known as cat scratch fever and can present as endocarditis in the setting of a history of a cat bite/scratch with painful lymphadenopathy. This patient lacks the risk factors that would increase his exposure to this pathogen; additionally, C. burnetti is a Gram-negative organism.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after developing confusion and lethargy. The patient’s friend reports that she complained of right-sided weakness several days ago. The patient has a history of HIV and is inconsistent with her antiretroviral medication regimen. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg. The patient is arousable to voice. On physical examination, there is evidence of right-sided weakness and sensory loss. CD4 count is undetectable. MRI of the brain with contrast reveals a solitary, periventricular ring-enhancing lesion. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of HIV presents with focal neurologic deficits, somnolence, and brain imaging that reveals a solitary ring-enhancing lesion – consistent with primary central nervous system lymphoma (PCNSL). PCNSL is an AIDS-defining illness and represents advanced disease. The majority of PCNSL cases in HIV patients are Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)-related. The most likely etiology involves ineffective immunoregulation of EBV, inducing oncogenic protein expression, with subsequent loss of apoptosis and increased proliferation of lymphocytes.

The clinical presentation of PCNSL is typically acute to subacute, including symptoms such as headache, confusion, lethargy, memory loss, hemiparesis, and/or seizures progressing over several days to weeks. Diagnosis begins with head imaging (e.g. MRI) that typically demonstrates a solitary, ring-enhancing lesion. Lumbar puncture is recommended for all patients with suspected HIV-related PCNSL (unless contraindicated), as EBV DNA found in the cerebrospinal fluid has a near 100% specificity for PCNSL.


Image credit ">Wikimedia commons  

Option Analysis

✅ Virally-mediated neoplasm   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Reactivation of a parasitic infection   :
Incorrect: Cerebral toxoplasmosis occurs in AIDS patients secondary to reactivation of a prior infection with Toxoplasma gondii. Multiple ring-enhancing lesions are observed with brain imaging, in contrast to a solitary lesion.   
❌ Focal bacterial infection   :
Incorrect: Cerebral abscess formation typically occurs secondary to contiguous spread from a primary site of infection (e.g. dental infection). Patients characteristically have high fevers, headaches, and focal neurological deficits. Imaging typically demonstrates a focal intraparenchymal lesion with a central hypodense (necrotic) area.   
❌ Virally-mediated demyelination   :
Incorrect: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a demyelinating condition caused by reactivation of the JC virus in patients with advanced AIDS. Patients often present with confusion, lethargy and seizure. Brain imaging typically reveals numerous nonenhancing lesions, in contrast to a solitary lesion.   
❌ Virally-mediated encephalopathy   :
Incorrect: HIV-associated encephalopathy (AIDS dementia complex) is characterized by cortical and subcortical atrophy with resultant ventricular enlargement. Patients typically present with chronic cognitive deficits, depressive symptoms, and features of movement disorders.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to an outpatient clinic for evaluation of pain and increased frequency of urination for the past four days. The patient endorses penile discharge and is concerned he “may have a urinary tract infection.” The patient is currently sexually active with three partners. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. External genital examination reveals mucopurulent, cloudy discharge at the urethral meatus. Digital rectal exam (DRE) is within normal limits. Findings from a urinalysis are demonstrated below. Gram staining of the discharge is negative for the presence of bacteria. Urine culture is negative for growth at 24 hours. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on further evaluation?
 
Laboratory value  
Result
Urinalysis  

Color
Cloudy
Specific gravity  
1.013  
Glucose
Negative
Blood
Negative  
Leukocyte esterase  
Large leukocyte esterase  
Nitrites
Negative  
Leukocytes  
50-100/hpf  
Erythrocytes  
1-2/hpf  
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent  
Casts  
None

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification of a gram-negative bacterium
KOH wet mount with motile trichomonads

questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic features of chlamydial urethritis including dysuria, penile mucopurulent discharge, sterile pyuria, and a negative gram stain and culture. Confirmatory diagnosis is made via nucleic acid amplification testing.

Chlamydia trachomatis is a gram-negative, predominantly intracellular bacterium that is transmitted sexually. Infection with chlamydia trachomatis should be suspected in patients with multiple sexual partners who present with symptoms of either urethritis (in patients with male genitalia)or cervicitis (in patients with female genitalia). The serotypes that are responsible for urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) include serotypes D-K. Of note, Neisseria gonorrhoeae coinfects a significant proportion of patients with chlamydial infections.

Most biologically male patients with chlamydial infections are asymptomatic; however, common clinical manifestations of male chlamydial urethritis include dysuria, increased urinary frequency, penile discharge, and pruritus. Urethral discharge may be mucoid or watery. In contrast, infection in biological females presents with symptoms of cervicitis including vaginal discharge, pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, or mucopurulent discharge on speculum examination.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae may also cause symptoms of urethritis and cervicitis and present in a similar manner to chlamydial urethritis/cervicitis. However, gonorrhoeal cervicitis/urethritis typically involves more copious urethral/vaginal discharge, and diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes with gram stain and microscopy. By comparison, chlamydial infections cannot be detected by traditional stains and culture due to the absence of murein in its cell wall. Therefore, the diagnostic test of choice for chlamydial infection is a nucleic acid amplification test. Vaginal and cervical swabs are obtained in patients with female genitalia, and urine samples are analyzed in patients with male genitalia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nucleic acid amplification of a gram-negative bacterium  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ KOH wet mount with motile trichomonads  :
Incorrect: Trichomonas is an uncommon cause of urethritis. Motile trichomonads on a wet mount analysis may indicate trichomonal urethritis. Microscopy of urethral samples is insensitive in patients with male genitalia, although they may be positive for cervicitis in patients with female genitalia.  
❌ Ring-enhancing prostatic lesions on CT:
Incorrect: A CT scan is not indicated in the evaluation of uncomplicated urethritis. CT scans may be used for the evaluation of prostatic abscesses, which may mimic the symptoms found in this patient; however, this patient has a negative DRE, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Positive hepatitis B surface antigen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B antigen is diagnostic of hepatitis B infection. Most patients are asymptomatic or present with a febrile illness and icterus. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with chlamydial urethritis.  
❌ Positive VDRL serology:
Incorrect: VDRL is a preliminary investigation for the diagnosis of syphilis. Primary syphilis presents with an isolated, nontender chancre on the external genitalia. Dysuria and urethral discharge are uncommon in primary syphilis.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents to the clinic due to a skin lesion. The lesion started as a small vesicle that continues to enlarge. It is not painful or itchy. The patient was stationed in the military in Iraq for the last 5 years and just returned to the United States 6 months ago. Examination of the lesion reveals a black necrotic lesion surrounded by edema as shown in the picture below. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the edema surrounding this skin lesion?  


Source: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: An exotoxin produced by the bacteria that acts like adenylate cyclase
An exotoxin produced by the bacteria that acts as a protease
Increased vascular permeability due to inflammatory cytokines released by macrophages
Increased vascular permeability due to inflammatory cytokines released by T-cells
Increased vascular permeability due to the degranulation of mast cells in the local tissue

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis, a Gram-positive spore-forming bacterium. The spores of Bacillus anthracis are found in soil and mostly cause diseases in horses, cattle, and sheep. People who handle these animals can get an infection through skin contact (cutaneous anthrax), or by inhalation or ingestion (pulmonary or gastrointestinal anthrax, respectively) of contaminated products. Anthrax can also be used as a biological weapon.

Cutaneous anthrax is characterized by an edematous and painless black eschar. The lesion usually starts as a papule that converts into a large vesicle, then ruptures. The black color of the lesion is due to necrosis of the skin tissue. Upon skin contact, B. anthracis spores enter the skin. The spores are then taken up by macrophages where they convert to active bacteria and start producing toxins.

Anthrax toxin is an exotoxin complex, which is composed of a protective antigen, edema factor, and lethal factor. Protective antigen allows toxins to enter into immune cells. Edema factor acts like adenylate cyclase, increasing the production of cyclic adenosine monophosphate. This causes phagocytic dysfunction and is also responsible for the edema that surrounds the black eschar in cutaneous anthrax.
 

Lethal factor is a zinc-dependent protease that cleaves mitogen-dependent protein kinases which are used by the immune system and other cells in the body to produce NADPH. Without NADPH the cells cannot produce ATP, and eventually undergo apoptosis.  


Option Analysis

✅ An exotoxin produced by the bacteria that acts like adenylate cyclase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ An exotoxin produced by the bacteria that acts as a protease:
Incorrect: The lethal factor, which is one part of the anthrax toxin, acts as a protease. However, it is not responsible for the edema that surrounds the black eschar.  
❌ Increased vascular permeability due to inflammatory cytokines released by macrophages:
Incorrect: The edema that surrounds the black eschar in patients with cutaneous anthrax is most likely due to the edema factor of the anthrax toxins.  
❌ Increased vascular permeability due to inflammatory cytokines released by T-cells:
Incorrect: The edema that surrounds the black eschar in patients with cutaneous anthrax is most likely due to the edema factor of the anthrax toxins.  
❌ Increased vascular permeability due to the degranulation of mast cells in the local tissue:
Incorrect: The edema that surrounds the black eschar in patients with cutaneous anthrax is most likely due to the edema factor of the anthrax toxins.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man comes to the office because of itching over his shins for the past few months. The itching is unrelenting and is now interfering with his sleep. He has used several over-the-counter ointments, which have not helped. Past medical history is noncontributory. He is sexually active with a female partner and uses condoms consistently. He has a previous history of IV drug use in his early 20s. Physical examination shows multiple, well-healed track marks on his arms. Examination findings of the shins are shown below.



Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons

Complete blood count is within normal limits. Further testing reveals elevated serum aminotransferase levels. This patient’s condition is associated with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
This young man presents with pruritic, purple, polygonal plaques and papules on the lower extremities without improvement from over-the-counter ointment. He is most likely suffering from lichen planus (LP), an immune-mediated disorder resulting from CD8-positive T-cells activating against basal keratinocytes. LP is found to be associated with hepatitis C virus infection and various drugs including diuretics (e.g. thiazides) and antihypertensives (e.g. ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers). This patient’s history of IV drug use and laboratory testing revealing elevated serum aminotransferase levels (AST, ALT) suggest an underlying hepatitis C infection. The various clinical presentations of LP are as follows:

Cutaneous LP particularly affects the skin of the ankles and wrists and appears as a papulosquamous eruption defined by 6 Ps.



Oral LP (Fig A): Mucosal involvement manifests as lace-like Wickham striae and hypergranulosis affecting the buccal mucosa.


Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons
Fig A

  • Genital LP usually presents as violaceous papules affecting the glans penis in men and the vulva in women. 
  • Nail LP (Fig B) primarily affects the nail matrix and can range from nail dystrophy or complete nail loss.

 Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons
 Fig B

  •  Lichen planopilaris affects the hair follicles of the scalp and results in alopecia if left untreated. 
Diagnosis is made on clinical appearance and is confirmed on biopsy findings of a “saw-tooth” shaped dermo-epidermal junction (presence of lymphocytes) and a thickened stratum granulosum or hypergranulosis.



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Human papillomavirus (HPV):
Incorrect: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is most commonly associated with warts, which are small cauliflower-like outgrowths that can appear on any part of the body. HPV can be transmitted via direct skin- to-skin contact or by unprotected sexual activity. This patient’s low-risk sexual behavior and pruritic, purple plaques on the lower extremities are atypical.
✅ Hepatitis C virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV):
Incorrect: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is found to be associated with severe seborrheic dermatitis, disseminated molluscum contagiosum, recurrent herpes zoster, and sudden-onset psoriasis; however, none of these conditions present with the pruritic, purple, polygonal plaques seen in this patient.
❌ Trichophyton rubrum:
Incorrect: Tinea corporis is caused by Trichophyton rubrum and usually presents as a pruritic, scaly, erythematous patch with central clearing and raised annular borders. Purple, polygonal plaques, as seen in this patient, are inconsistent with the diagnosis.
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect:Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis can secondarily lead to scarlet fever, which presents with a sand-paper-like, blanching, diffuse, erythematous rash, in addition to circumoral pallor and strawberry tongue. The rash typically affects the groin and armpits initially. Pruritic, purple plaques on the lower extremities suggest an alternative association.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an assessment of a tongue lesion. She states it is occasionally painful and has impacted her ability to eat. Her history is significant for active IV drug use and homelessness. She was recently hospitalized and treated for Pneumocystis pneumonia six months ago. She takes no medications and has not visited a primary care physician in over ten years. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a thin woman with temporal wasting and minimal muscle mass. Oral examination reveals a white lesion on the lateral margin of the tongue with “feathery” projections. The lesion is not easily scraped away with a tongue depressor. There are track marks and scars present in the bilateral antecubital fossa. The rest of the physical examination is noncontributory. The pathogen implicated in this patient’s tongue lesion is also associated with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL) is an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)-mediated mucocutaneous condition involving the squamous epithelium of the tongue. Hairy leukoplakia is associated with HIV infection or immunosuppression – as suggested in this vignette by the patient’s history of IV drug use and recent hospitalization with PCP pneumonia. The pathophysiology of OHL depends on several factors, including EBV virulence/strain and host immune system factors.    

The lateral border of the tongue is more susceptible to mechanical trauma, predisposing epidermal cells at this location to infection with EBV. Hence, this condition is commonly discovered as a unilateral non-painful white lesion on the lateral margin of the tongue. The lesion may vary in appearance as either a smooth and flat or irregular, "hairy" or "feathery" lesion with prominent folds or projections. In contrast to oral thrush, OHL lesions are adherent to the surface and cannot be removed by scraping. The surrounding tissue does not typically demonstrate any signs of erythematous change. EBV is implicated in several conditions beyond OHL, such as infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.  

Option Analysis

✅ Burkitt lymphoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Kaposi sarcoma:
Incorrect: Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8). Kaposi sarcoma presents with multiple cutaneous lesions (vascular tumors) and is almost exclusively seen in AIDS patients. A different pathogen precipitates this patient’s condition (hairy leukoplakia).
❌ Shingles:
Incorrect: Shingles is caused by reactivation of a prior infection with varicella-zoster virus (VZV) (i.e. chickenpox). A different pathogen causes this patient’s condition (hairy leukoplakia).
❌ Cervical cancer:
Incorrect: Cervical cancer is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV preferentially infects squamous cells and can result in oropharyngeal cancers. However, this patient’s hairy leukoplakia is caused by a different virus. 
❌ Vulvovaginitis:
Incorrect: Vulvovaginitis occurs secondary to colonization with various pathogens, with one of the most common pathogens being Candida albicans. Oropharyngeal candidiasis, also known as oral thrush, is caused by C. albicans. A physical examination will reveal white plaques on the oral mucosa, similar to this patient. However, oral thrush is scrapable with a tongue depressor, unlike leukoplakia and erythroplakia (premalignant lesions).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to a primary care physician’s clinic with fever, generalized muscle aches, and painful perineal ulcers. The patient had similar symptoms four months ago and did not seek treatment. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with acute cervicitis and treated with a course of ceftriaxone and doxycycline. She is sexually active and began a non-monogamous relationship with a new partner six months ago. They use condoms inconsistently. The patient has never traveled outside the country. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple tender ulcers on the labia majora. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. Bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on further laboratory evaluation?

choices.text: Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies
RNA virus with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple, painful genital ulcers and a history of inconsistent condom use; this presentation has typical features of genital herpes infection. Microscopic evaluation via a Tzank smear will likely reveal multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies.

Two serotypes of the herpes simplex virus are responsible for inducing herpes genitalis: HSV-1 and HSV-2 (with HSV-2 being implicated in genital infections in most cases). Transmission of genital herpes infection occurs through unprotected sexual intercourse (i.e., oral, vaginal, or anal sex). Clinical manifestations of primary genital HSV include multiple, grouped, painful genital ulcers with an erythematous base, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms of fever, headache, malaise, and myalgias. Individuals with male genitalia may also present with symptoms of proctitis, particularly in individuals who engage in unprotected anal sex. Symptoms of acute proctitis include rectal pain, bleeding, and purulent rectal discharge with diffuse tenderness on digital rectal examination.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical; however, viral culture and PCR-based testing are often performed. Histologically, Tzanck smear will demonstrate multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusion bodies known as Cowdry bodies.

Option Analysis

✅ Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ RNA virus with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies:
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is an RNA poxvirus that causes multiple, nontender, small, flesh-colored papules with central umbilication and eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with genital herpes infection.
❌ Reactive VDRL test:
Incorrect: A diagnosis of syphilis is supported by a positive VDRL test. Clinical features of syphilis include a single, nontender, indurated genital ulcer and painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. This patient has evidence of multiple painful genital ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy, which is more consistent with genital herpes infection.  
❌ Gram-negative rods on microscopy:
Incorrect: Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Although the classic presentation of chancroid includes purulent genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenitis, this patient’s pattern of recurrence (i.e. similar symptoms four months ago) and the physical description of the lesions instead point toward a diagnosis of genital herpes infection.  
❌ Deeply staining gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts:
Incorrect: Certain serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3) can cause lymphogranuloma venereum. Clinical manifestations include painless, small, shallow genital ulcers and painful coalesced inguinal lymph nodes. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with genital herpes infection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman presents to the obstetrics clinic to discuss pregnancy. Based on the first-trimester ultrasound, the patient is in the 20th week of gestation. As part of pregnancy complication counseling, the patient and physician discuss Listeria monocytogenes infection and how the risk of infection can be decreased. Which of the following measures can be taken to decrease the risk of infection with Listeria monocytogenes?

choices.text: Avoidance of handling cat litter boxes
Avoid contacts with infants with a rash
No measures can be taken to avoid infection with Listeria

questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacterium. It is a food-borne pathogen that can be transmitted by unpasteurized dairy products or cold deli meat. The bacteria have the ability to survive and replicate in cold environments.

L. monocytogenes infection in healthy adults usually causes self-limited gastroenteritis. However, it can lead to severe infections in pregnant women, both in the mother and fetus. In pregnant women, L. monocytogenes can cause fever, gastrointestinal manifestations (e.g., vomiting, diarrhea), or a disseminated infection. If the bacteria crosses the placenta to the fetus, they can lead to catastrophic events, including stillbirth or miscarriage, or neonatal listeriosis.

Neonatal listeriosis can present with fever, respiratory distress, and granulomatosis infantiseptica which presents as a nodular rash and other symptoms. It can also cause meningitis, sepsis, and death in neonates.

Because of these severe complications, pregnant women should avoid cold deli meats and unpasteurized dairy products.  


Option Analysis

✅ Avoidance of cold deli meat:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Avoidance of handling cat litter boxes:
Incorrect: Toxoplasmosis can lead to devastating infections for fetuses. Avoidance of cat feces should be done to prevent infection with Toxoplasma gondii.  
❌ Avoid contacts with infants with a rash:
Incorrect: Rubella, which causes a rash (among other symptoms) in children, can be transmitted from children to adults. As it can lead to disease in newborns, pregnant women should avoid contact with children who have a rash or suspected rubella.  
❌ No measures can be taken to avoid infection with Listeria:
Incorrect: Listeria monocytogenes is generally a food-borne bacterium and can be transmitted in cold deli meat or unpasteurized dairy products. Avoidance of these foods can decrease the risk of infection.  
❌ Vaccination:
Incorrect: No vaccine is available for Listeria monocytogenes.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the molecular mechanism through which HPV infection leads to cervical cancer. He has developed an in vitro model that involves transfecting cervical epithelial cells grown in culture flasks with a lentivirus carrying the HPV E6 and E7 genes. The expression of protein E6 and E7 in infected cells is subsequently confirmed using fluorescence microscopy. Which of the following best describes the role these proteins play in the pathogenesis of cervical cancer?

choices.text: Inhibition of cell cycle regulatory proteins

questions.solution:
Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia is linked to HPV infection. HPV viruses are DNA viruses that invade stratified squamous epithelial cells. In the cervix, the virus inserts itself into the immature squamous cells of the transformation zone and then integrates its DNA into the host DNA. An important fact to know is what sets low-risk HPV strains (HPV 6 and 11) and high-risk HPV strains (HPV 16, 18, 31, 33) apart.  

The key difference is that the high-risk strains make large quantities of two proteins, E6 and E7, using the host DNA. The E6 protein inhibits p53 whereas the E7 protein inhibits pRB, the retinoblastoma tumor suppressor gene product. The inhibition of p53 and pRB allows infected cells to pass through cell-cycle checkpoints regardless of how much DNA mutation or damage has taken place. The end result is uncontrolled replication of cervical epithelial cells which are resistant to apoptosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of cell cycle regulatory proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Overactivation of tyrosine kinase :
Incorrect: Overactive tyrosine kinases are the underlying cause of many neoplasma, including  myeloproliferative disorders and chronic myeloid leukemia. However, the proteins E6 and E7 inhibit p53 and Rb, respectively. Both p53 and Rb are cell cycle checkpoint regulators.  
❌ Stabilization of mitochondrial membrane:
Incorrect: A gain-of-function mutation in the Bcl-2 gene will help stabilize the mitochondrial membrane and prevent apoptosis. This is the underlying cause of follicular and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas. However, the E6 and E7 proteins produced by HPV infection do not affect the Bcl-2 gene.  
❌ Overproduction of transcription factors:
Incorrect: The overproduction of transcription factors can lead to malignancies such as Burkitt lymphoma. However, neither E6 or E7 contributes to the development of cervical cancer via this mechanism.  
❌ Inhibition of DNA repair proteins:
Incorrect: Mutations in genes such as BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 can lead to the production of defective DNA repair proteins. E6 inhibits p53 and E7 inhibits Rb. Neither of the inhibited proteins play a direct role in DNA repair.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic due to the recent onset of throat pain, fever, and substernal burning pain. Medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia and end-stage renal disease, for which he received an allograft renal transplantation from a deceased donor 6 months ago. Medications include azathioprine and TMP-SMX. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Examination of the oropharynx is normal without exudate or erythema. The abdomen is soft with mild epigastric tenderness. Leukocyte count is 5000/mm3. An endoscopy is obtained and reveals multiple shallow linear ulcers in the distal esophagus. Which of the following best characterizes the organism responsible for this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
The constellation of an immunocompromised state, fever, odynophagia, dysphagia and linear ulcers found on endoscopy is most consistent with cytomegalovirus (CMV) esophagitis. CMV belongs to the herpes virus family, all of which are enveloped double-stranded DNA viruses.   

CMV is a common pathogen that mainly affects immunocompromised patients, including solid organ transplant recipients, HIV patients, hematopoietic cell transplant recipients, and patients treated with immunomodulating therapy. Transmission can occur through close contact carriers, sexual exposure, or blood and tissue exposures. CMV is capable of diverse clinical manifestations including hepatitis, febrile syndromes, pneumonitis, retinitis, encephalitis, esophagitis, and colitis. CMV esophagitis is characterized by linear shallow ulcers on endoscopy. Microscopic examination shows intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions (“owl eye”). Available treatments include ganciclovir, valganciclovir, and foscarnet.  

Other common causes of esophagitis in an immunocompromised patient are depicted in the table below:  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Non-enveloped double-stranded DNA virus:
Incorrect: Examples of non-enveloped double-stranded DNA viruses include adenovirus and papillomavirus; however, neither of these is associated with esophagitis.   
❌ Non-enveloped single stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: An example of a non-enveloped single-stranded RNA virus include the Picornaviruses family (i.e., poliovirus, echovirus, rhinovirus, coxsackievirus, and hepatitis A); however, none of these causes esophagitis.   
✅ Enveloped double-stranded DNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Enveloped single-stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: An example of an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus includes influenza virus. Although some of the patient’s symptoms can be explained by influenza infection, it is not a cause of esophagitis.   
❌ Dimorphic fungi :
Incorrect: An example of dimorphic fungi includes Candida albicans, which can cause esophagitis in immunocompromised individuals. However, candida esophagitis is typically not painful and white plaques are typically seen, not linear ulcers.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with a 2-month history of worsening   weakness, fatigue, and cough. The patient reports the cough is non-productive and notes some shortness of breath on exertion. Medical history is notable for rheumatic heart disease when she was 7 years old. A screening colonoscopy performed at age 50 showed no polyps or abnormalities. She currently works as a cattle rancher at a nearby farm. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F) , pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 122/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination is notable for holosystolic murmur appreciated at the cardiac apex as well as bibasilar rales. Nail examination is notable for small ecchymotic lesions of the upper nail beds bilaterally. Follow-up blood cultures are negative. Which of the following is the most likely organism implicated in this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
Endocarditis due to Coxiella burnetii is a rare occurrence but should be considered in patients presenting with symptoms of endocarditis, atypical pneumonia, and a history of exposure to cattle, sheep, or the amniotic fluid of farm animals. C. burnetii is thus classified as a zoonotic infection because it spreads from mammals to humans.  

C. burnetii is a Gram-negative rod that causes a disease called Q fever, which is an atypical pneumonia; if left untreated it can progress to endocarditis, especially in patients with underlying heart valve disease, such as this patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease. It has the ability to form endospores, which is a dormant form in which the bacteria is transmitted in aerosolized form.

The presentation of endocarditis due to C. burnetii is similar to other pathogens that cause subacute presentations and includes fatigue, weakness, chills, or splinter hemorrhages, such as in this patient. Blood cultures for this pathogen are often negative, making it a common cause of culture-negative endocarditis along with the HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella), Bartonella, and Candida.     

Option Analysis

❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of endocarditis due to IV drug use and tends to cause acute endocarditis affecting the tricuspid valve more often than the mitral valve. This patient's murmur is heard at the cardiac apex, which is more reflective of mitral regurgitation. Additionally, blood cultures would typically grow Gram-positive bacteria in clusters, as opposed to this patient’s negative culture results.  
❌ Streptococcus bovis:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a common cause of endocarditis in patients with underlying colon cancer. This patient had no lesions on the last colonoscopy 5 years ago, and the culture-negative results would be atypical, as S. bovis is a Gram-positive bacteria that normally grows on culture.   
❌ Streptococcus mutans:
Incorrect: Streptococcus mutans is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. This patient’s culture-negative results would be atypical, as S. mutans is a Gram-positive bacteria that normally grows on culture.  
✅ Coxiella burnetii:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Streptococcus sanguineous:
Incorrect: Streptococcus sanguineous is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. This patient’s culture-negative results would be atypical, as S. sanguineous is a Gram-positive bacteria that normally grows on culture.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and cough of three days duration. The patient uses intravenous heroin regularly and reports he last used heroin earlier today. He is currently living in a homeless shelter. Temperature of 38.7 °C (101.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 100/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears disheveled. Erythematous lesions are noted on the chest and arms bilaterally. Rales are appreciated in the lungs bilaterally, and a holosystolic murmur is appreciated at the left lower sternal border. Laboratory values are demonstrated below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
Complete Blood Count, Serum 
 Hemoglobin  12.5 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40.5% 
 Leukocyte count  18,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  250,000/mm3 
Inflammatory Markers, Serum 
ESR                 44 mm/hr 
 CRP  18 mg/L 
Electrolytes, Serum 
                  Sodium                131 mEq/L 
               Potassium                 3.6 mEq/L 
                 Chloride                 94 mEq/L  
              Bicarbonate                 20 mEq/L 
                 Calcium                8.4 mg/dL 
Blood is drawn and sent for culture, and the patient is started on empiric antibiotics. Three days later, 3 of 4 blood cultures obtained on admission grow Gram-positive, coagulase-positive bacteria. Which of the following is the most common initial site of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Infective endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus (Gram-positive, coagulase-positive bacteria) is the most common cause of endocarditis in resource-rich settings. Risk factors for acquisition include intravascular catheter placement, history of prosthetic heart valves, and IV drug use, as in this patient.  

The most common site of origin of infective endocarditis due to S. aureus is the tricuspid valve. This is because the bacteria typically gain access primarily through the venous system and initially come in contact with the tricuspid valve as they circulate through the cardiovascular system. This seeding can present as a new-onset murmur in patients, typically heard as a holosystolic murmur appreciated at the left lower sternal border. After attachment to the tricuspid valve, bacterial emboli can mobilize, causing septic emboli to the lungs that result in symptoms of cough, pleuritic chest pain, fever, and hemoptysis.

Option Analysis

❌ Pulmonary veins :
Incorrect: While the pulmonary veins may be implicated in further transmission of vegetations from endocarditis, they are not the most common site of origin for Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis.  
✅ Tricuspid valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Aortic valve:
Incorrect: The aortic valve may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus, especially in the setting of bicuspid aortic valve or after a valve repair; however, it is not the most common initial site of infection.  
❌ Mitral valve:
Incorrect: The mitral valve is overall the most common site of infection in subacute endocarditis and may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus; however, it is not the most common initial site due to this bacteria.  
❌ Pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: The pulmonic valve may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus; however, it is not the most common initial site of infection.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic with fatigue and malaise. He reports he has been experiencing symptoms for over the past six months and wants to make sure he “hasn’t contracted a sexually transmitted infection.” He currently uses intravenous drugs and has had multiple sexual partners over the past year. He has no other significant past medical history. A screening HIV test is negative, and the remainder of the laboratory results are detailed below:
