Which of the following best describes the replicative mechanism of the pathogen with which this patient is infected?

choices.text: Reverse transcription of an RNA template into partially double-stranded DNA progeny
Reverse transcription of an RNA template into double-stranded DNA progeny
Use of an RNA dependent RNA polymerase to synthesize single-stranded RNA progeny
Use of a DNA dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize double-stranded DNA progeny
Use of a DNA dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize single-stranded DNA progeny.

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use and multiple sexual partners over the past year presents with six months of malaise and fatigue. The laboratory findings are consistent with chronic hepatitis B infection, and he is currently highly infectious given the positive HBeAg titer. Of the replicative mechanisms listed, reverse transcription of an RNA template into partially double-stranded DNA progeny describes the replicative mechanism of hepatitis B.  

Hepatitis B is a partially double-stranded DNA virus of the hepadnavirus family. It is transmitted via multiple routes including parenteral transmission, sexual transmission, as well as vertical transmission from mother to fetus. Following inoculation, hepatitis B infects hepatocytes via a bile salt transporter and utilizes cellular DNA polymerase to complete replication of the partially double-stranded (ds) segment of the virus. After this step, the virus uses host RNA polymerase to transcribe a single-stranded RNA template from the dsDNA genome for translation of the viral capsid, DNA polymerase/reverse transcriptase, and associated proteins. Finally, the virus utilizes this DNA polymerase/reverse transcriptase to generate partially dsDNA progeny.  

After infection, hepatitis B carries an incubation period of approximately 180 days, after which patients may experience a prodrome of symptoms such as malaise, arthralgias, fatigue, rash, or lymphadenopathy. Patients may then experience symptoms of acute hepatitis (jaundice, right upper quadrant pain) or have complete resolution and viral clearance. Other patients go on to develop chronic hepatitis or fulminant hepatitis, which is characterized by severe liver necrosis and atrophy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reverse transcription of an RNA template into partially double-stranded DNA progeny:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reverse transcription of an RNA template into double-stranded DNA progeny:
Incorrect: HIV utilizes a reverse transcriptase to synthesize dsDNA progeny. This patient’s viral hepatitis  panel shows an active infection with hepatitis B, which replicates via a different mechanism.
❌ Use of an RNA dependent RNA polymerase to synthesize single-stranded RNA progeny:
Incorrect: Picornaviridae and influenza viruses utilize this replicative mechanism to generate single-stranded RNA progeny. This patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows an active infection with hepatitis B, which replicates via a different mechanism.
❌ Use of a DNA dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize double-stranded DNA progeny:
Incorrect: Herpes viruses utilize this mechanism to generate double-stranded DNA progeny. This patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows an active infection with hepatitis B, which replicates via a different mechanism.
❌ Use of a DNA dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize single-stranded DNA progeny.:
Incorrect: Parvovirus is the smallest DNA virus and utilizes this mechanism to generate single-stranded DNA progeny. This patient’s viral hepatitis panel shows an active infection with hepatitis B, which replicates via a different mechanism.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He was found unconscious in an alley by a bystander who called paramedics to the scene. Upon arrival in the emergency department, the patient is mumbling but is unable to report his medical history. Chart review demonstrates a history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatitis B infection. Temperature is 36 °C (96.8°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 100/53 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates jaundice, track marks on the upper extremities, as well as diffuse ecchymosis. The patient is appropriately resuscitated, and the following laboratory results are seen:

This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with infection with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of hepatitis B and intravenous drug use presents with altered mental status and features concerning for fulminant hepatitis. Characteristic features include evidence of severe liver injury evidenced by jaundice, altered mental status, significant elevation of AST and ALT (>15 times the upper limit of normal) with signs of shock and coagulopathy (elevated PT and aPTT). Given this patient's history of chronic hepatitis B, this clinical presentation is suspicious for superinfection with hepatitis D, an RNA delta virus.  

Hepatitis D is an RNA delta virus that is transmitted sexually and parenterally; however, most cases occur via contamination with infected blood products or contaminated syringes. The virus is completely dependent on the hepatitis B surface protein HBsAg for viral entry, and thus patients must either have a prior history of hepatitis B infection or undergo coinfection simultaneously with hepatitis B.  

Coinfection, where hepatitis B and hepatitis D are acquired at the same time, represents the most common mechanism of hepatitis D infection. Coinfection presents similarly to acute hepatitis B with malaise, arthralgias, fatigue, a rash, or lymphadenopathy occurring weeks to months after infection. Superinfection, such as in this patient, occurs when patients who are already chronic carriers of hepatitis B become infected with hepatitis D. This form of acquisition presents with a shorter incubation period, more severe symptoms of hepatitis, and significantly increases the risk of progression to fulminant hepatitis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.  

Diagnosis of hepatitis D infection is achieved by obtaining viral titers against the pathogen, and liver biopsy will demonstrate similar features to hepatitis B, with a ground glass appearance.   

Option Analysis

✅ RNA delta virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ RNA picornavirus:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A is spread via the fecal oral route and is an extremely uncommon cause of fulminant hepatitis. Most cases are mild and self resolve without hospitalization.
❌ RNA hepevirus:
Incorrect: Hepatitis E carries a risk of fulminant hepatitis in pregnant mothers in endemic areas. This patient with a history of hepatitis B and intravenous drug use more likely has a different cause for fulminant hepatitis.
❌ RNA flavivirus:
Incorrect: Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis C is a rare event, as most cases progress to stable chronic infection.
❌ RNA orthomyxovirus:
Incorrect: Influenza tends to present with abrupt onset of high fevers and rigors and does not typically cause severe symptoms in patients without significant comorbidities or an immunocompromised state.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and cough that have been going on for the past four days. The cough is productive and yields purulent, foul-smelling sputum. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 121/65 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry shows 91% on room air. Crackles are heard bilaterally. Chest radiograph reveals infiltrations in the basilar region of both lungs. Sputum Gram-stain is notable for neutrophils and Gram-negative organisms. Subsequent sputum culture yields growth of Klebsiella and Bacteroides species. Which of the following is most likely to be found upon further interviewing this patient?

choices.text: Exposure to contaminated water-based cooling systems

questions.solution:
This patient has fevers, consolidations primarily affecting the basilar lungs, and sputum culture yielding growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria. These findings suggest aspiration pneumonia.

Aspiration pneumonia occurs when patients accidentally aspirate food, drinks, or gastric contents. The condition typically occurs in patients with impaired gag and cough reflexes or altered consciousness. Therefore, aspiration pneumonia is more common in patients with a history of drug or alcohol intoxication, seizure disorders, or stroke leading to swallowing issues.  

The right lung is preferentially involved due to the larger caliber and vertical orientation of the right mainstem bronchus. Furthermore, aspiration pneumonia is gravity-dependent, meaning the location where pneumonia develops depends on the patient’s position. In patients who aspirate while lying on their back, pneumonia will likely develop in the posterior segment of the upper lobe and superior segment of the lower lobe. In patients who aspirate while upright, the basilar segments may be affected.

Since aspiration pneumonia is caused by a mixture of aspirated gastric contents and oral secretions, sputum Gram-stain will typically reveal mixed infections with aerobic and anaerobic organisms. Clinically, patients may have crackles on auscultation, high fevers, shortness of breath, and a productive cough with foul-smelling sputum. 



Option Analysis

❌ Close quarters living arrangement:
Incorrect: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) in children and young adults. The organism is transmitted from person to person primarily via respiratory droplets. Therefore, outbreaks most frequently occur among persons living in close quarters (e.g., dormitories, military facilities). However, this patient’s sputum culture yields growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, which is more concerning for aspiration pneumonia.
❌ Exposure to contaminated water-based cooling systems:
Incorrect: Legionella pneumophila (legionellosis) can be found in contaminated water sources and is a cause of atypical pneumonia, which would similarly present with fevers and cough. However, patients with legionellosis also often have extrapulmonary symptoms, such as diarrhea, nausea/vomiting, and confusion. Additionally, this patient’s sputum cultures yield growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, which is more concerning for aspiration pneumonia.
❌ History of incarceration:
Incorrect: A history of incarceration is a risk factor for tuberculosis infection. In contrast, this patient has bilateral basilar infiltrates and cultures that yield growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, which is more concerning for aspiration pneumonia.
❌ Recent history of spelunking:
Incorrect: Spelunking can place an individual at risk for histoplasmosis, which is caused by the pathogen Histoplasma capsulatum. In contrast, this patient’s culture yields growth of Gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, which is more concerning for aspiration pneumonia.
✅ History of alcohol intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of burning micturition, increased frequency of urination, and malodorous vaginal discharge. She is sexually active with three sexual partners. Her male partner does not use condoms when engaging in vaginal intercourse. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The patient’s abdomen is soft and nontender. Speculum examination reveals purulent, malodorous discharge and a friable, erythematous cervix with punctate hemorrhages. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. The pH of the vaginal discharge is 5.5. An external genital examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on further laboratory evaluation?

choices.text: Motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy
Detection of multinucleated cells on Tzanck smear
Gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of dysuria and malodorous, purulent discharge, and the physical exam reveals an erythematous cervix and punctate hemorrhages (“strawberry cervix”). This presentation is consistent with trichomoniasis, which is caused by infection with the organism Trichomonas vaginalis.

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted genitourinary infection that often presents with dysuria, purulent, malodorous vaginal discharge, and dyspareunia. The presence of motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy confirms the diagnosis, and NAAT (nucleic acid amplification testing) is also specific and sensitive for the detection of this condition. Additional clues for the diagnosis include an elevated vaginal pH (greater than 4.5) and an increase in polymorphonuclear leukocytes on microscopy.

After diagnosis, treatment should be offered to both symptomatic and asymptomatic patients as well as  their sexual contacts. The treatment of choice includes a course of oral metronidazole.

Option Analysis

✅ Motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Detection of multinucleated cells on Tzanck smear  :
Incorrect: Multinucleated cells on Tzanck smear indicate the presence of herpes simplex virus. Herpes simplex genital infection presents with multiple, painful genital ulcers. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with trichomoniasis.  
❌ Gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands:
Incorrect: Haemophilus ducreyi appears as gram-negative rods in parallel strands (or a “school of fish” appearance) on gram staining. The clinical infection manifests with multiple, painful, genital ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with trichomoniasis.  
❌ Spirochetes on darkfield microscopy:
Incorrect: Primary syphilis manifests with a single, nontender genital papule or ulcer. Cervicitis and purulent, malodorous discharge would be atypical; this patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with trichomoniasis.  
❌ Positive whiff amine test  :
Incorrect: Bacterial vaginosis infection often yields a positive whiff test. While patients with bacterial vaginosis may have an elevated vaginal pH (normal 3.8-4.5) as in this case, the discharge associated with bacterial vaginosis is typically characterized as homogenous and gray-white with a fishy odor. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with trichomoniasis.

questions.text: A microbiologist is studying the case report of a young woman who developed sudden-onset emesis and cramping abdominal pain 30 minutes after eating. The patient did not have diarrhea. Which of the following foods is most likely implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Bacillus cereus is a Gram-positive, rod-shaped, spore-forming bacterium. It is aerobic, beta-hemolytic, and catalase-positive.

Reheated or fried rice is an important cause of emetic-type food poisoning associated with B. cereus. The organism is frequently present in uncooked rice, and heat-resistant spores may survive cooking. B. cereus can cause two distinct types of toxin-mediated food poisoning, characterized by either diarrhea or vomiting, depending on which toxin is produced. The diarrheal toxin causes destruction to the intestinal epithelium, triggering the secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea. The emetic toxin is ingested directly from contaminated food, which explains why symptoms usually occur very shortly after ingestion of the causative food.

Option Analysis

❌ Canned foods:
Incorrect: Canned foods that are contaminated with C. botulinum can be associated with foodborne illness manifesting as a descending, symmetric paralysis. The onset of any associated GI symptoms is not this rapid.  
❌ Raw oysters:
Incorrect: Consumption of raw oysters can cause infection with Vibrio parahaemolyticus, which is characterized by voluminous watery diarrhea.  
❌ Undercooked chicken:
Incorrect: Consumption of incompletely-cooked chicken or raw eggs can cause Salmonella gastroenteritis, which usually causes watery diarrhea but can be bloody.  
✅ Reheated rice:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Undercooked beef:
Incorrect: Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) infection typically occurs after eating undercooked beef and is characterized by inflammatory, bloody diarrhea.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, cough, and night sweats over the past 2-3 months. Past medical history is notable for HIV infection, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. She is currently undomiciled, drinks 3-4 alcoholic drinks per day, smokes one pack of cigarettes per day, and uses intravenous heroin daily. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99.0°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 156/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates a thin, cachectic middle aged female with track marks noted on the upper extremities bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals rales in the upper lobe of the left lung, without gallops, rubs, or murmurs. Chest x-ray is demonstrated below.  

 

Image reproduced from Radiopaedia  
Which of the following is the most important contributing factor for the development of this radiographic finding?

choices.text: Higher oxygen tension in upper lung lobes

questions.solution:
This patient has clinical features (e.g., chronic cough, night sweats) and a social history (e.g., undomiciled status, polysubstance use) suspicious for Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. The chest x-ray demonstrates an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the left lung, which is consistent with reactivation or secondary tuberculosis.   

Unlike primary pulmonary tuberculosis, reactivation or secondary tuberculosis tends to affect the upper lobes of the lung. This phenomenon is due to the fact that mycobacteria are obligate aerobes, and the upper lobes have a higher oxygen tension and poor lymphatic drainage, which allows the bacteria to replicate more effectively.  

Reactivation tuberculosis refers to recrudescent infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis after a period of dormancy. Typically, primary disease occurs when aerosolized tuberculi take residence in lung tissue, typically the mid/lower lobes of the right lung due to a higher density of lymph nodes and anatomic preference. Mycobacteria then form a primary focus of granulomatous infection, referred to as a Ghon focus, which, along with hilar lymphadenopathy, is referred to as a Ghon complex. If the Ghon focus or complex fails to be cleared by the immune system, mycobacteria can travel to the upper lobes of the lung and form new foci, resulting in fibrocaseous cavitary lesions and secondary tuberculosis. If left untreated, further localized destruction, bacteremia, and disseminated disease may ensue.    

Option Analysis

✅ Higher oxygen tension in upper lung lobes:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Impaired phagolysosome formation by macrophages:
Incorrect: Mycobacterium tuberculosis uses sulfatide to prevent phagolysosome formation while inside of macrophages. However, this is not the most important factor contributing to the formation of reactivation tuberculosis in the upper lobes of the lung.   
❌ Inhibition of opsonization:
Incorrect: The primary virulence factor of Streptococcus pneumoniae is a polysaccharide capsule that prevents opsonization and phagocytosis. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with reactivation tuberculosis, making this answer choice unlikely. 
❌ Embolization of bacterial vegetations:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial endocarditis in patients with IV drug use. However, septic emboli tend to present with multifocal bilateral pulmonary opacities. Moreover, the absence of a new murmur on physical exam makes this answer choice unlikely as well. 
❌ Increased lymphatic drainage:
Incorrect: Reactivation tuberculosis has a propensity to affect the upper lobes of the lung due to poor lymphatic drainage, which protects the pathogen from immune cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to confusion and altered mental status. His friend, who brought him in, states the patient has been complaining of fevers accompanied by malaise for the past 2 weeks. The patient is currently living in a homeless shelter, but oftentimes he is seen sleeping on the streets by his friends. Medical history is unknown, but a month ago the patient was hospitalized for Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly P. carinii) pneumonia. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic and mildly confused. Neck is supple, and there are no focal signs. The patient’s arms show multiple needle marks. The pathogen most likely responsible for this patient’s condition is most likely to show which of the following on further testing?

choices.text: Nonseptate hyphae branching at wide angles
Septate hyphae branching at acute angles
Forms germ tubes at hot temperatures

questions.solution:
This patient is immunocompromised (recent Pneumocystis jirovecii infection, with evidence of risk factors such as needle marks and homelessness), likely due to undiagnosed HIV infection. The constellation of indolent course, headaches and immunosuppression, from the options above, favors the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis (neck stiffness is absent in 2/3 of patients). The subacute and chronic nature of this condition is caused by capsular proteins produced by Cryptococcus which obstruct cerebrospinal fluid outflow, resulting in symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, confusion, cranial nerve VI palsy).  

Cryptococcus neoformans is a budding, heavily encapsulated yeast (not dimorphic) that can be found in soil and pigeon droppings. It is acquired through inhalation of spores with hematogenous dissemination to the brain meninges. Confirmation of diagnosis requires identification of the encapsulated yeast in cerebrospinal fluid (e.g. India ink stain) or detection of the polysaccharide antigen.  
  

Option Analysis

❌ Nonseptate hyphae branching at wide angles:
Incorrect: These features depict Mucor and Rhizopus spp. that can cause mucormycosis in diabetic ketoacidosis and/or neutropenic patients (e.g. leukemia). Mucormycosis typically presents as headache, facial pain, and a black necrotic eschar on the affected area because the fungi proliferate in blood vessel walls. 
✅ Budding, encapsulated yeast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Septate hyphae branching at acute angles :
Incorrect: These features depict Aspergillus fumigatus, which is a type of fungus that can be found throughout the environment. Healthy individuals are usually asymptomatic, but immunocompromised patients are at risk for developing invasive disease. It classically presents with fever, chest pain, shortness of breath, cough, and/or hemoptysis. 
❌ Forms germ tubes at hot temperatures:
Incorrect: These features depict Candida albicans, which is a dimorphic fungus that forms pseudohyphae and budding yeasts at 20°C and germ tubes at 37°C. Immunocompromised hosts are at risk for invasive disease. Invasive candidiasis can present anywhere from minimal fever to acute sepsis syndrome (similar to bacterial infection). However, it is not typically a cause of meningitis. 
❌ Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci:
Incorrect: Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci describes Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults of all ages. However, pneumococcal meningitis typically causes severe, life-threatening manifestations within hours to days of inoculation, not weeks as in this patient.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friend due to severe headaches, fever, and vomiting. Medical history is unknown, but the friend states they live in a homeless shelter together. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented and seems in distress due to pain. Meningeal signs are positive, but no focal signs are observed. Head imaging reveals mild hydrocephalus with marked basilar enhancement. The results of the CSF analysis are shown below:  

 
 Cerebrospinal fluid 
 Opening pressure  350 mm H2O 
 Color  Yellow 
 Protein   350 mg/dL 
 Glucose  20 mg/dL 
 RBCs  4 cells//mm3 
 WBC count   400/µL 
 Neutrophils   20%  
 Lymphocytes  80% 

Which of the following methods can assist in identification of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The constellation of fever, headaches, confusion, and positive meningeal signs raises concern for meningitis. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose, xanthochromia (yellow color), and elevated protein, which favors the diagnosis of fungal/tuberculosis meningitis. The imaging results further support the diagnosis by demonstrating hydrocephalus with marked basilar enhancement, a finding which is classically seen in tuberculosis and fungal meningitis.  

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a gram-positive acid-fast rod that is able to disseminate and scatter tuberculous foci (tubercles) in the brain, meninges, or adjacent bone following primary infection or late reactivation. Although infections with tuberculosis are not common in developed countries, certain populations (e.g., homeless, immunocompromised) are at risk of acquiring the infection. Tuberculous meningitis typically follows 3 stages as follows:    

  •  Prodromal phase: insidious onset of malaise, headache, low-grade fever, and personality change. 
  •  Meningitic phase: meningismus, protracted headache, vomiting, lethargy, confusion, and varying degrees of cranial nerve and long-tract neurological signs. 
  •  Paralytic phase: stupor and coma, seizures, and often hemiparesis. Death ensues within 5-8 weeks of the onset of illness if left untreated.  
Diagnosis is made by CSF analysis showing elevated protein and lowered glucose with a mononuclear pleocytosis. The diagnosis is confirmed with demonstration of acid-fast bacilli (AFB) in the CSF with the Ziehl-Neelsen stain, as well as nucleic acid testing if feasible. CT or MRI evidence of basilar meningeal enhancement with hydrocephalus is strongly suggestive of tuberculous meningitis. Treatment includes prolonged antituberculous therapy.    



Option Analysis

❌ Venereal disease research laboratory test:
Incorrect: Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL) of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) can assist in the diagnosis of syphilis meningitis which can present with similar symptoms as seen here. CSF analysis in syphilis meningitis typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein and occasionally a depressed glucose concentration. However, imaging may show enhancement of the meninges, spinal fluid, cranial nerves, or spinal roots. This patient’s findings favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Giemsa stain:
Incorrect: Giemsa stain is used for recognition of Rickettsia, Chlamydia, Trypanosomes,  Plasmodium, and Borrelia (typically intracellular organisms). Lyme meningitis presents with classic symptoms of meningitis; however, CSF analysis typically shows elevated cell count with lymphocytic predominance, elevated protein, and normal glucose.   
❌ Thayer-Martin agar:
Incorrect: Thayer-Martin agar is a selective medium used for growth of Neisseria species. Bacterial meningitis CSF analysis typically reveals elevated WBC count with neutrophilic predominance, low glucose, and high protein, rather than lymphocytic predominance as seen here.
✅ Ziehl-Neelsen stain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ India ink stain:
Incorrect: India ink stain is used for the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans infections which usually presents with insidious onset of fever and headaches. CSF analysis shows low glucose, mild protein elevation, low WBCs (<200 cells/µL) with mononuclear predominance. This patient’s laboratory and imaging results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic due to concerns for contracting a sexually transmitted infection. He reports that several months ago, he had unprotected sexual intercourse, and several weeks thereafter, he experienced malaise, fatigue, and jaundice. He reports since then, his symptoms have abated, but he is concerned because he started a new relationship and does not want to “potentially infect” his new partner. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:

Which of the following best describes the current clinical stage of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with serologic markers consistent with a recovered infection from hepatitis B, as indicated by the presence of antibodies to the surface antigen, core antigen, and e antigen. Given his recovered status, he is no longer considered infectious from hepatitis B.  

Multiple serologic markers are utilized in determining the stage of infection from hepatitis B. The first markers to rise in acute hepatitis B infection are HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM antibodies, oftentimes with positive HBeAg titers. Next is the window period, which is the time between first infection and when the test can reliably detect that infection occurs. During this period, the patient may be infected; however, viral titers are so low that the patient may have negative serological testing for HBsAg, HBcAg, or HBeAg. During this period, the only markers that are positive are either anti-HBc IgM or anti-HBe.  

Chronic infection is defined by the presence of HBsAg, anti-HBc IgG, +/- the presence of HBeAg. When HBeAg is present, this indicates a high degree of HBV replication, infectivity, and transmissibility. Recovery is then defined by antibodies to HBs, anti-HBc IgG, and anti-HBe. Immunized patients (e.g. vaccinated) can be differentiated as they possess only anti HBsAg antibodies.

Option Analysis

✅ Recovered:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic HBV with high infectivity:
Incorrect: Chronic HBV with high infectivity would be indicated by a positive HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgG.
❌ Chronic HBV with low infectivity:
Incorrect: Chronic HBV with low infectivity would be indicated by a positive HBsAg, anti-HBe, and anti-HBc IgG.  
❌ Acute HBV:
Incorrect: Acute HBV would be indicated by a positive HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgM. Additionally, the patient would likely be symptomatic, as opposed to his already resolved symptoms.
❌ Window period:
Incorrect: The window period of hepatitis B infection is indicated by a positive anti-HBc IgM and anti-HBe titers.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of a nonproductive cough and fever for the past 3 weeks. She also has been experiencing arthralgias in her wrists, knees, and elbows. The patient is a farmer and regularly comes in contact with various animals, including cows and pigs. Past medical history is notable for hypertension that is well-controlled with losartan. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit substances. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 138/85 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry shows 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals expiratory wheezes bilaterally. Chest radiograph reveals right lower and middle lobe consolidation. Sputum and blood cultures are obtained and show no growth after incubation for several days. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fevers, nonproductive cough, and arthralgias in the setting of a history notable for extensive exposure to livestock. She likely has Q fever, which is a zoonotic disease caused by the Gram-negative bacteria Coxiella burnetii.   

Many species of domesticated mammals (e.g., cattle, sheep) are reservoirs of C. burnetii. Infected animals can shed bacteria into the environment. Furthermore, female animals can release millions of Coxiella spores during parturition. Humans are usually infected by contaminated aerosols from domestic animals, particularly after contact with female animals in labor and their birth products. Therefore, farmers and slaughterhouse workers are at risk for being infected by this organism.  

Most exposed individuals remain asymptomatic. However, some patients may develop acute disease, which can manifest with fever, pneumonia, hepatitis, or even chronic disease (e.g. endocarditis). C. burnetii pneumonia commonly presents with a non-productive cough and fever. In addition to respiratory symptoms, patients often have extrapulmonary manifestations including severe headaches, myalgias, and arthralgias. Since C. burnetti is a strictly intracellular organism, it is often difficult to grow on culture.  

Option Analysis

✅ Coxiella burnetii :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Klebsiella pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Klebsiella pneumoniae is a relatively common cause of aspiration pneumonia, which can occur in patients with a history of altered mental status, substance intoxication, or impaired cough and gag reflexes. This type of infection can be associated with a productive cough (sometimes with “currant jelly sputum”), lung necrosis, and abscess formation. In contrast, this patient does not have the aforementioned risk factors. Furthermore, this patient’s occupation puts her at increased risk for exposure to a different pathogen.
❌ Legionella pneumophila:
Incorrect: Legionella pneumophila (legionellosis) can be found in water systems and is a cause of atypical pneumonia, which can present with fevers and dry cough. Patients with legionellosis can also have prominent extrapulmonary symptoms, such as diarrhea, nausea/vomiting, confusion. However, this patient’s history of exposure to farm animals is more suggestive of another cause of pneumonia.  
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: Bacteria like Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus can form biofilms on the endotracheal tube of patients who are mechanically ventilated, or they can chronically colonize the lungs of patients with cystic fibrosis. P. aeruginosa is a rare cause of pneumonia in otherwise healthy patients.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae :
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia, and should be suspected in otherwise healthy individuals presenting with fevers and productive cough. However, community-acquired pneumonia usually has acute onset, over the course of a few days. Additionally, this patient’s occupation puts her at risk for exposure to a different pathogen.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man goes to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, cough, and shortness of breath for the past several days. The patient has also experienced several episodes of diarrhea daily. He recently went on a business trip and stayed in a large hotel. The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus that are well-managed with lisinopril and metformin, respectively. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/88 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds over the left lung. Chest radiograph reveals multifocal opacities in the right lung. Laboratory results are as follows:  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   128 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.9 mg/dL 
 Aspartate aminotransferase   74 U/L 
 Alanine aminotransferase  88 U/L 

Which of the following media is required for culturing the pathogen most likely causing this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with nonproductive cough, fevers, hyponatremia, elevated liver enzymes, and diarrhea. In conjunction with his recent stay at a large hotel, the patient likely has pneumonia secondary to Legionella pneumophila, which is termed Legionnaire disease. Legionnaire disease can be acquired sporadically or during outbreaks, which are often associated with contamination of water supplies in large facilities such as hotels, apartment buildings, or cruise ships.  

Although Legionnaire disease is similar to other forms of pneumonia, and no signs or symptoms clearly distinguish Legionnaire disease from other forms of pneumonia, suggestive clinical features include:  

  •  Hyponatremia 
  •  Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 
  • Elevated liver enzymes   
Diagnosis of L. pneumophila infection can be made via a Legionella urine antigen test. Another clue is that on sputum Gram stain, there will be a high number of neutrophils but no bacteria since the organism has a cell wall that inhibits staining. Additionally, L. pneumophila requires a buffered charcoal yeast extract medium supplemented with L-cysteine and iron to grow.  



Option Analysis

✅ Charcoal yeast extract agar:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Sabouraud agar:
Incorrect: Sabouraud agar is useful in culturing fungal pathogens. This patient’s respiratory illness, in combination with diarrhea and hyponatremia, is likely the result of a different pathogen. 
❌ Thayer-Martin agar:
Incorrect:Legionella pneumophila requires charcoal yeast extract agar, not Thayer-Martin agar, which is used for Neisseria gonorrhoeae growth.
❌ Löwenstein–Jensen medium:
Incorrect: Löwenstein–Jensen medium is helpful in culturing Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Although tuberculosis can cause respiratory complications, it typically presents with an insidious course, with night sweats and weight loss. This patient’s current clinical picture (e.g., pneumonia, diarrhea, hyponatremia) is likely the cause of a different pathogen.
❌ Cholesterol-rch agar:
Incorrect: Cholesterol-rich agar (Eaton agar) is helpful in culturing Mycoplasma pneumoniae, the most common cause of walking pneumonia. M. pneumoniae typically presents with an indolent course, manifests with a non-productive cough, and can cause various extrapulmonary symptoms (e.g., headaches, arthralgia, confusion). This patient’s current clinical picture (e.g., pneumonia, diarrhea, hyponatremia) is likely the cause of a different pathogen.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of severe pain affecting several joints. The symptoms began 3 months ago. He has also had loose, greasy stools several times daily as well as a 12-lb weight loss. Past medical history is noncontributory. He is not sexually active and does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/62 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a soft, high-pitched, early diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best at the left 3rd intercostal space. The left and right knee are warm and tender to palpation, and passive range of motion is limited bilaterally. Abdominal examination reveals intense epigastric pain on palpation. Generalized lymphadenopathy is present. Biopsy of the small intestine reveals periodic acid-Schiff-positive (PAS)-positive macrophages within the lamina propria. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Dysregulated immune response to intestinal microbiome

questions.solution:
This older male patient is presenting with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, arthritis, valvular insufficiency, and biopsy results showing PAS-positive macrophages in the intestinal wall. He most likely has Whipple disease.   

This condition is caused by the Gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei, which invades and colonizes many areas of the body, resulting in the wide spectrum of clinical findings. Intestinal manifestation include malabsorption and diarrhea, whereas extraintestinal symptoms include arthritis, generalized lymphadenopathy, cardiac symptoms (e.g. aortic insufficiency), and neurological conditions (e.g., ataxia, oculomotor dysfunction).  

The diagnosis of Whipple disease can be made via a small intestine biopsy showing macrophages that stain positive with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS). Treatment consists of IV ceftriaxone, as well as a year of maintenance therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole given the disease’s high relapse rate.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Infection by Gram-positive rod:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypersensitivity to gliadin:
Incorrect: Celiac disease is caused by an intestinal hypersensitivity reaction to gliadin, which is a component of gluten, and subsequent T-cell activation. While celiac disease may also present with bloating and diarrhea, this patient’s arthritis, cardiac murmur, and generalized lymphadenopathy are not adequately explained by this diagnosis alone.
❌ Increased circulating T3 and T4:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism can result in weight loss and diarrhea. However, hyperthyroidism would not account for the patient’s diastolic decrescendo murmur, which is concerning for aortic regurgitation. Furthermore, this patient’s arthritis and generalized lymphadenopathy cannot be explained by hyperthyroidism.
❌ Infection by Acid-fast staining parasite :
Incorrect: Acid-fast staining parasites that can cause diarrhea include Cryptosporidium species and Cyclospora cayetanensis. Infection with these parasites can cause watery diarrhea, but they would be unlikely to cause the arthritis, valvular insufficiency, or generalized lymphadenopathy seen in this patient. 
❌ Dysregulated immune response to intestinal microbiome:
Incorrect: Dysregulation of the immune system in response to the intestinal microbiome can lead to inflammatory bowel diseases, such as Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Although these conditions can also present with diarrhea, their endoscopic findings would differ from this patient’s. Crohn disease would show sporadic granulomatous inflammation, whereas ulcerative colitis would show continuous lesions at the rectum. Neither condition would show the presence of PAS-positive macrophages.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of a persistent cough. The patient’s mother recalls, “He’s been coughing non-stop for weeks, but we got really worried tonight after he turned blue during an episode and threw up after another.” The patient was born full-term at home with assistance from a midwife. He has been evaluated by a physician only once shortly after he was born. Temperature is 38.7°C (102°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 110/53 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% while on room air. On physical examination, the patient has a long series of coughs, during which he has very few respirations. Shortly afterwards, the patient has one episode of non-bloody emesis. Which of the following investigations will most likely help confirm the patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Nasopharyngeal swab for influenza A and B

questions.solution:
This patient presents with paroxysms of severe coughing, apnea in between coughs, and posttussive vomiting. Moreover, he likely did not receive all his childhood vaccines. In combination, the patient’s history is concerning for pertussis.

The condition is caused by Bordetella pertussis, a Gram-negative coccobacillus that has largely been eradicated due to vaccination efforts. However, in recent years, new cases have been reported due to an increasing number of unvaccinated children.

Infection with this organism leads to a characteristic series of phases and associated clinical findings. The first phase is known as the catarrhal stage. It presents with symptoms similar to those of a viral upper respiratory infection, such as mild cough and coryza, and lasts one to two weeks. The next phase is the paroxysmal stage, which is characterized by frequent coughing spells that are followed by forceful inspiration, resulting in a high-pitched “whoop.” Patients can also develop cyanosis and apnea during coughing episodes and emesis afterwards. This paroxysmal stage lasts approximately two to eight weeks. Finally, during the convalescent stage, the cough subsides over several weeks to months.

Pertussis is a clinical diagnosis made based on the patient's symptoms. However, laboratory testing such as bacterial culture, serology, and PCR (performed on samples obtained via nasopharyngeal aspiration or swab) can be used to confirm the diagnosis. 

Option Analysis

✅ PCR-assisted identification of Bordetella DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nasopharyngeal swab for influenza A and B:
Incorrect: Infection by influenza A and B can cause symptoms including fevers, cough, myalgias, and malaise. This patient, however, has episodes of severe coughing associated with apnea and subsequent vomiting, which is more concerning for pertussis. The influenza virus does not cause pertussis.
❌ Oropharyngeal streptococcal antigen testing:
Incorrect: The rapid strep test involves swabbing the throat and checking the sample for the presence of Streptococcus pyogenes antigens. However, Streptococcus pyogenes infection would not lead to pertussis.
❌ Sputum culture on chocolate agar :
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae can cause epiglottitis, meningitis, and otitis media. It is known to grow well on chocolate agar due to the presence of factors V and X. Unvaccinated children are at risk for being infected by this pathogen. However, Haemophilus influenzae would not cause the symptoms of pertussis seen in this patient.
❌ Chest radiography:
Incorrect: This patient has episodes of coughing, apnea, and post-tussive emesis. These symptoms are concerning for pertussis. Chest radiography may demonstrate subtle abnormalities such as peribronchial cuffing, perihilar infiltrates, and atelectasis. However, these findings are non-specific and have limited utility in helping diagnose the patient’s underlying condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of multiple, painless, wart-like genital lesions that have been present for one week. The patient is sexually active and has had two sexual partners in the last month. He uses condoms inconsistently during sexual intercourse. The patient went on a week-long hike in New Hampshire two weeks ago. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a diffuse macular rash over the patient’s trunk and extremities with involvement of the palms and soles of the feet. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple flat topped and non-tender wart-like lesions over the penile shaft. Which of the following tests is most likely to reveal this patient’s underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Indirect immunofluorescence antibody assay for immunoglobulin G (IgG) Rickettsii antigen

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of unsafe sexual practices (inconsistent condom use, multiple sexual partners) presents with painless genital warts, a fever, diffuse lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse macular rash involving the palms and soles of the feet. This presentation is characteristic for secondary syphilis and condylomata lata.

Serologic tests for the diagnosis of syphilis include both non-treponemal and treponemal tests.  Nontreponemal tests include detecting antibodies to reagin antigen, a cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen (RPR testing), and VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Lab) testing. However, it should be noted that these tests are used for screening purposes given their high sensitivity and lower specificity. The level of antibodies present at the time of administration of these tests can predict the activity of a spirochete infection. However, given their low specificity, false-positive VDRL tests are commonly encountered due to infection with infectious mononucleosis or in patients with lupus, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, rheumatic fever, leprosy, pregnancy, and those using medications such as phenothiazines (chlorpromazine and procainamide).

Specific treponemal tests include the FTA-ABS (fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test),  microhemagglutination test for T. pallidum antibodies, and T. pallidum enzyme immunoassay (TP-EIA). In contrast to non-treponemal tests, these assays are highly specific, as they detect specific antibodies to treponemal antigens. Confirmatory tests include direct visualization of the spirochete under dark field microscopy, direct fluorescent antibody testing, and PCR testing for T. pallidum DNA.

Option Analysis

✅ Fluorescent treponemal antibody adsorption tests:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wet mount microscopy:
Incorrect: Wet mount microscopy is useful for evaluating for the presence of bacterial vaginosis, trichomonas, or candidal infections. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with secondary syphilis.  
❌ Tzanck smear:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus causes a genital infection characterized by multiple tender ulcers over the external genitalia. A Tzanck smear may be used to aid in the diagnosis. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with secondary syphilis.  
❌ Indirect immunofluorescence antibody assay for immunoglobulin G (IgG) Rickettsii antigen:
Incorrect: Rocky mountain spotted fever is transmitted by a tick bite and can manifest with nonspecific symptoms like fever, generalized malaise, and a blanching, erythematous rash that begins on the ankles and wrists and spreads to the trunk. Wart-like genital lesions would be atypical. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with secondary syphilis.  
❌ Parvovirus B-19 DNA testing:
Incorrect: Erythema infectiosum predominantly affects children and is characterized by an erythematous rash that begins in the malar region and spreads to the trunk and extremities. Genital involvement is uncommon. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with secondary syphilis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to a burning sensation with urination. The symptoms started 3 days ago and now cause the patient to wake up multiple times at night to urinate. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is sexually active with their spouse. Physical examination is unremarkable and vital signs are within normal limits. Urinalysis is positive for leukocytes and leukocyte esterase. Urine culture reveals growth of Gram-positive cocci. Which of the following is a feature of the causative organism most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI), likely due to Staphylococcus saprophyticus. Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a Gram-positive coccus (circle-shaped) that grows in clusters, and is a common cause of UTI in women. S. aureus does not generally cause UTI, and S. epidermidis in urine culture, is rare and usually indicates contamination with skin flora.

Like all other staphylococcal species, Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a catalase-positive pathogen, which means that it is able to convert hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. S. saprophyticus is also urease-positive (like S. epidermidis) which helps in the pathogenesis of UTI by converting urea to ammonia. This elevates the pH of the urine and makes it more suitable for bacterial growth. Unlike S. aureus, S. saprophyticus is a coagulase-negative pathogen.

One of the distinguishing features of S. saprophyticus from other staphylococcal species is its resistance to novobiocin. Both S. aureus and S. epidermidis are sensitive to novobiocin. Therefore, novobiocin sensitivity can be used to distinguish between S. saprophyticus and other staphylococcal species.  


Option Analysis

✅ Novobiocin resistant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Coagulase positive:
Incorrect: The most likely cause of this patient’s urinary tract infection is Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is coagulase negative.  
❌ Catalase negative:
Incorrect: All staphylococcal species are catalase positive, including Staphylococcus saprophyticus.  
❌ Intracellular microorganism:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is not an intracellular pathogen.  
❌ Novobiocin sensitive:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is novobiocin resistant while Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are novobiocin sensitive.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by a friend for evaluation of muscle pain. The patient is currently undomiciled and has limited access to medical care. A few days ago, the patient developed painful muscle spasms as well as difficulty opening her mouth. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100.0 °F), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, and pulse is 100/min. On physical examination, the patient is unable to open her jaw and facial expression appears fixed. There is also backward arching of the neck and head. Multiple deep puncture wounds and superficial lacerations are present on the bilateral feet. Which of the following proteins is targeted by the toxin responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with painful muscle spasms, lockjaw, as well as backward arching of the head,  and neck (opisthotonos) after stepping on a rusty nail. These symptoms are concerning for tetanus, which is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani (C. tetani).

C. tetani is an anaerobic Gram-positive bacterium that is ubiquitously present in the soil. Injuries such as deep puncture wounds or crush injuries can enable bacterial spores to enter the body. Afterwards, the bacteria are able to proliferate under anaerobic conditions and produce neurotoxins that reach the central nervous system via retrograde axonal transport. The neurotoxins cleave SNARE proteins and block vesicles containing the inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) from being released into the neuromuscular junction. The end result is muscle overactivation and development of muscle spasms.

Symptoms of C. tetani infection (tetanus) include lockjaw, risus sardonicus (persistent smile-like expression due to facial muscle contractions), and opisthotonos (hyperextension of the neck and/or back). In more advanced stages, patients can develop autonomic dysfunction and eventually respiratory arrest (due to diaphragm failure).  

Option Analysis

✅ SNARE:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elongation factor 2  :
Incorrect: The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae inhibits elongation factor 2 (EF-2), leading to the formation of pseudomembranes in the oropharynx. In contrast, this patient has painful muscle spasms, lockjaw, as well as backward arching of the head and neck.  
❌ Adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: Vibrio cholera releases a toxin that activates adenylate cyclase, thereby increasing cAMP levels. Infection by this pathogen would present with watery diarrhea, not spastic paralysis.  
❌ Superoxide dismutase:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are concerning for tetanus, which is caused by Clostridium tetani. This bacterium produces a toxin that disrupts the function of SNARE proteins, not superoxide dismutase.  
❌ Neuron specific enolase:
Incorrect: Detection of neuron-specific enolase (NSE) can be used to identify cells of neuroendocrine origin. However, NSE does not play a role in the pathogenesis of tetanus.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with lightheadedness. Since last night, she has felt fatigued and has noticed that every time she stands, she feels like she is about to pass out. She reports feeling short of breath after climbing a set of stairs for the past week. One month ago, she returned from summer camp in New Jersey, after which she began to develop fatigue and headaches. She takes acetaminophen for the headaches. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 40/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. She appears exhausted. Physical exam shows regular bradycardia without murmurs. No skin lesions are seen. An ECG is obtained and shows the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following species most likely transmitted this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ECG shows a third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block, also called complete heart block. In third-degree AV block, none of the electrical impulses are conducted through the AV node. Cutoff from one another, the atria and ventricles (which both have their own pacemakers) begin to contract independently of one another, known as AV dissociation. This desynchronization of the heart chambers can reduce cardiac output dramatically, leading to syncope or even sudden cardiac death. On ECG, the P-waves and QRS complexes have no relation to each other, each occurring at their own rates. Initial management of all patients with third-degree AV block involves the placement of transcutaneous pacer pads or transvenous pacing with chronotropes (atropine) to ensure adequate cardiac output. If no reversible cause is found, patients will require permanent pacemaker implantation.  



This patient’s history of outdoor activities in the northeastern United States (eg, New Jersey, Connecticut) is concerning for Lyme disease. Transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi (the spirochete responsible for Lyme disease) occurs through tick bites from Ixodes scapularis. Early localized Lyme disease may cause fatigue, anorexia, and headache days to weeks after infection. Although inoculation is usually associated with erythema migrans, the majority of patients do not notice this rash. Lyme carditis represents early disseminated disease, which occurs a few months after infection. Lyme disease, although it can cause lesser-degree AV blocks, is most strongly associated with third-degree AV block. With appropriate antibiotic therapy (intravenous ceftriaxone in this patient), third-degree AV block from Lyme carditis typically resolves within one week.  

Other causes of third-degree AV block overlap with the causes of other AV blocks, including myocardial ischemia, cardiomyopathy (e.g., amyloidosis, sarcoidosis), hyperkalemia, and adverse effects of AV-nodal blocking medications (e.g., beta blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, digoxin).  

Option Analysis

❌ Dermacentor variabilis:
Incorrect: Dermacentor variabilis, the American dog tick, is the principal vector of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) in the eastern and south central United States. RMSF is characterized by fever, headache, and a blanching erythematous rash. It is not associated with heart block.  
❌ Rhipicephalus sanguineus:
Incorrect: Rhipicephalus sanguineus, the common brown dog tick, is a vector for Rocky Mountain spotted fever in the southwestern United States. RMSF is characterized by fever, headache, and a blanching erythematous rash. It is not associated with heart block.  
✅ Ixodes scapularis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amblyomma americanum:
Incorrect: Amblyomma americanum, the lone star tick, is a vector for human ehrlichiosis. Ehrlichiosis is characterized by fevers, myalgias, arthralgias, and a maculopapular or petechial rash. It is not associated with heart block.  
❌ Dermacentor andersoni  :
Incorrect: Dermacentor andersoni, the Rocky Mountain wood tick, is a vector for Colorado tick fever virus. Infection is characterized by fever, chills, myalgias, leukopenia, and encephalitis. It is not associated with heart block.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with flank pain, malaise, and weight loss over the past several weeks. She states, “I just have no appetite for anything these days.” She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and several episodes of nephrolithiasis. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 94/min and blood pressure is 154/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows a palpable left sided flank mass. She subsequently undergoes a biopsy of the mass with the following histologic finding demonstrated below:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following pathogens is most commonly implicated in this disease process?
questions.solution:
Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XP) is a rare form of chronic pyelonephritis, most commonly implicated with long standing or recurrent urinary tract infections with Proteus mirabilis. Macroscopic tissue demonstrates orange nodules that can mimic renal cell carcinoma tumor nodules. Staghorn calculi are often present as well. This appearance is due to widespread kidney damage and necrosis due to granulomatous tissue containing foamy macrophages in response to the bacteria. This biopsy demonstrates immunohistochemical staining of macrophages and giant cells in a case of XP. The disease occurs in middle-aged women and is most commonly unilateral. Treatment is nephrectomy after a course of antimicrobials to control the local infection.   

Option Analysis

✅ Proteus mirabilis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Staphylococcus epidermidis :
Incorrect: S. epidermidis a common cause of urinary tract infections in patients with indwelling catheters. It is not, however, associated with xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis, which is the likely diagnosis in this patient.  
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa  :
Incorrect: While Pseudomonas aeruginosa is associated with chronic urinary tract infections, it is not the most common bacteria implicated in xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis. It is more commonly found in patients with diabetes.   
❌ Staphylococcus aureus :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause of urinary tract infections overall, and it is not associated with xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis.  
❌ Staphylococcus saprophyticus   :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common urinary tract infection in individuals engaging in frequent sexual intercourse. It is not, however, associated with xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a several week history of malaise, subjective fevers, and fatigue. He has a history of renal cell carcinoma diagnosed 5 months ago. The patient reports he had a recent stent placed in the left ureter approximately two months ago due to worsening metastatic disease burden. The hospital course was complicated by damage to the ureter, which was repaired surgically. Temperature is 37.7 °C (100.6 °F) , pulse is 102/min, respirations are 22/min and blood pressure is 130/62 mmHg. On physical examination the patient is noted to have conjunctival pallor. A new holosystolic murmur is appreciated at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
Infective endocarditis (IE) due to Enterococcus faecalis most commonly results after invasive urologic or abdominal procedures that allow seeding of the organism into the bloodstream. Enterococci are normal colonizers of the gastrointestinal and urologic tracts and can attach to heart valves causing symptoms of endocarditis. This patient likely acquired E. faecalis from the recent urologic surgery.  
Endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis can cause all of the same symptoms as other pathogens; fever is the most common symptom in IE, and it is often associated with chills, anorexia, and weight loss. Relatively uncommon clinical manifestations, yet pathognomonic of IE, include Janeway lesions (nontender erythematous macules on the palms and soles), Osler nodes (tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes) and Roth spots (exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina).  

Enterococcus faecalis generally has a slow, subacute presentation, and anemia of chronic disease (as evidenced by this patient’s conjunctival pallor) tends to be more prevalent among patients with endocarditis due to this organism.  

Option Analysis

❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of endocarditis due to IV drug use and tends to cause acute endocarditis. It tends to affect the tricuspid valve more often than the mitral valve. This patient's murmur is heard at the cardiac apex, which is more reflective of mitral regurgitation.  
❌ Streptococcus bovis:
Incorrect:Streptococcus bovis is a common cause of endocarditis in patients with underlying colon cancer or inflammatory bowel disease. It is an unlikely cause of this patient’s infective endocarditis.   
❌ Streptococcus mutans :
Incorrect: Streptococcus mutans is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures, due to their predominance as oral flora. This patient had no recent dental procedures.  
❌ Streptococcus sanguineous :
Incorrect: Streptococcus sanguineous is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. This patient had no recent dental procedures.  
✅ Enterococcus faecalis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician's clinic for evaluation of one week of burning urination, increased urinary frequency, and spotting after sexual intercourse. She was diagnosed with herpes simplex genital infection two months ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. On physical exam, the abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals three healed, nontender genital ulcers. Speculum examination reveals mucopurulent discharge and a friable erythematous cervix. Cervical motion tenderness is absent. Which of the following findings is most likely on laboratory evaluation?

choices.text: Gram-negative rods in a “school of fish” chain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with vaginal discharge, spotting, dysuria, and a friable, erythematous cervix on clinical examination–suggestive of acute cervicitis. The most common causes of acute cervicitis include Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis.

In patients with female genitalia, infection with Neisseria gonorrhea presents with purulent or mucopurulent cervical discharge and/or vaginal bleeding. Physical examination findings include a friable, erythematous cervix with copious purulent discharge. Diagnostic studies include a gram stain and culture of vaginal fluid or an endocervical sample with microscopy and culture. A gram stain will demonstrate gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

NAAT (nucleic acid amplification test) is indicated in the diagnostic evaluation of acute cervicitis to evaluate for the presence of both Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis, which cannot be detected with traditional gram stain and culture. The presentation of cervicitis due to Neisseria gonorrhea is similar to that caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, although gonorrhea involvement is more likely to cause purulent or mucopurulent discharge. Because coinfection with the two pathogens is common, symptomatic patients are empirically treated for both with intramuscular ceftriaxone and a macrolide or tetracycline (doxycycline).

Meanwhile, in patients with male genitalia, infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae results in urethritis and copious urethral discharge. Patients may have additional symptoms of dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and pruritus. Diagnostic workup similarly involves gram stain, culture and NAAT evaluation of a urethral sample.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Positive hepatitis B surface antigen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B antigen is diagnostic of hepatitis B infection. Most patients are asymptomatic or present with a febrile illness and icterus. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with acute cervicitis.  
❌ Multinucleated cells on Tzanck smear  :
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus can be diagnosed by performing a Tzanck smear, which will demonstrate the presence of multinucleated cells. Most patients present with painful genital ulcers, dysuria, and tender lymphadenopathy. This patient does not have evidence of an active HSV-2 infection.  
❌ Spirochetes on dark field microscopy:
Incorrect: Darkfield microscopy is used to diagnose syphilis. Primary syphilis typically presents with a single nontender genital chancre. This patient’s presentation with vaginal discharge, spotting, and dysuria is more consistent with acute cervicitis secondary to Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis.  
❌ Gram-negative rods in a “school of fish” chain:
Incorrect: Haemophilus ducreyi presents with painful genital ulcers and suppurative lymphadenopathy. Gram stain reveals gram-negative rods with a “school of fish” appearance. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with acute cervicitis secondary to Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy presents to the emergency department with weakness and difficulty feeding. Parents state the patient has been getting progressively weaker over the past two days. The parents state, “He is not crying as loudly as he used to, and he has not had a bowel movement recently either.” Prior to this, the patient has been developing normally and had no issues during gestation or birth. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows global hypotonia and drooling from the mouth.  Which of the following best describes the most likely source of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Clostridium botulinum is a Gram-positive spore-forming bacterium that causes a rare but potentially devastating peripheral neurological disease known as botulism. The bacteria are primarily found in soil and have been well known to contaminate canned food products. This disease results from a heat-labile exotoxin produced by the bacteria, known as botulinum-neurotoxin.

This infant presents with clinical signs of botulism including a weak cry, drooling, constipation, and diffuse hypotonia. In infants, the most common means of acquiring this condition is ingestion of products contaminated with bacterial spores (e.g., honey). Infants lack a robust immune system and have poorly developed gut flora; this allows for the proliferation of toxin-producing C. botulinum colonies in the digestive tract. In contrast, adults largely acquire the infection by means of ingestion of the pre-formed toxin only, due to their more developed immune system and gastrointestinal tract.

Once ingested, this toxin prevents intracellular vesicles containing acetylcholine from fusing with the cellular membrane, thus preventing acetylcholine release into the neuromuscular junction. Ultimately, this results in the clinical features of flaccid paralysis.

Option Analysis

✅ Honey contaminated with bacterial spores:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Canned peaches contaminated with exotoxin:
Incorrect: The adult form of botulism occurs secondary to ingestion of contaminated canned goods with preformed exotoxin.  
❌ Contaminated drinking water:
Incorrect: Clostridium botulinum is not routinely transmitted via contaminated drinking water. It is more commonly transmitted via contaminated canned foods.  
❌ Puppy feces:
Incorrect:  Puppy feces serves as a common vector for Yersinia enterocolitica, which more commonly presents with acute bloody diarrhea or pseudoappendicitis.  
❌ Undercooked poultry:
Incorrect:  Several pathogens are transmitted via undercooked poultry including Campylobacter jejuni. This pathogen more commonly presents with findings of inflammatory diarrhea (e.g. mucoid stool or hematochezia).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic due to a painless jaw mass that started a few weeks ago. The mass has slowly increased in size and has recently begun producing a yellow discharge. The patient underwent molar extraction a few weeks prior to noticing the mass. Past medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.0 ºC (100.4 ºF), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows a painless mandibular mass with sinus tract formation and yellow purulent discharge. Gram stain and culture of the discharge shows Gram-positive bacteria with yellow sulfur granules. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has actinomycosis, which is caused by Actinomyces israelii. A. israelii is a Gram-positive, filamentous bacterium that is part of the normal flora of the oral cavity, gastrointestinal tract, and genitourinary tract. When identified microscopically, it is often found in “sulfur granules,” which are just yellow-colored clumps of the filaments of Actinomyces (and do not necessarily contain sulfur).

A. israelli does not usually cause infections unless there is a breach to the mucosal barriers, allowing bacteria to invade deeper into tissues and cause infection. The inflammatory response is granulomatous and suppurative, and can eventually lead to abscess and/or sinus tract formation. Purulence is often characteristically yellow. Risk factors for actinomycosis include decreased immunity, such as in patients with HIV, leukemia, or poorly controlled diabetes mellitus.

The most common form of actinomycosis is maxillofacial actinomycosis, which usually results after dental caries or dental extraction. The patient usually presents with a painless mass in the jaw or face due to an abscess, with sinus tract formation and yellow discharge. If persistent, the infection may spread to the bones of the jaw and cause osteomyelitis. Diagnosis can be made with Gram-stain, as culture may take weeks. Treatment involves a prolonged course of antibiotics.  


Option Analysis

✅ Actinomyces israelii:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nocardia:
Incorrect: Nocardia does not usually cause maxillofacial infections and does not form yellow sulfur granules.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus can cause abscess formation in multiple tissues, but it does not cause the characteristic yellow sulfur granules.  
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin infections of the face, but it is unlikely to cause a maxillary/dental abscess and does not cause the characteristic yellow sulfur granules.  
❌ Serratia marcescens:
Incorrect: Serratia marcescens is a Gram-negative bacterium that is associated with red pigment production, not with maxillary abscesses or sulfur granule formation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to a clinic for evaluation of ulcerative genital lesions for two weeks. The lesions have progressively increased in size with increasing purulent discharge. He is sexually active and began a monogamous relationship with a new male partner six months ago. He has had three sexual partners in his lifetime. Past medical history is significant for Crohn disease. He immigrated from India three months ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. On physical exam, the abdomen is soft and nontender. Inguinal lymph nodes appear normal. Genital examination reveals multiple non-tender ulcers along the shaft and base of the penis with associated purulent discharge. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on further laboratory evaluation?

choices.text: Gram-negative bacteria with intracytoplasmic cysts and deeply staining bodies
Multinucleated cells with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies
Gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands

questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of multiple purulent, non-tender genital ulcers without associated lymphadenopathy. In addition, this patient’s history of recent immigration from India raises suspicion of granuloma inguinale or Donovanosis–a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacteria Klebsiella donovanosis.

Clinically, this infection begins with the development of painless papules that progress to extensive, beefy red, nontender ulcers with associated purulent discharge. The majority of patients with this condition do not have regional lymphadenopathy. Anatomic areas commonly affected in individuals with female genitalia include the labia majora and minora and the fourchette. In individuals with male genitalia, the penile shaft is most commonly affected.

Diagnostic evaluation involves bipolar staining of ulcerative fluid which reveals gram-negative bacteria with intracytoplasmic cysts and deeply staining bodies resembling “safety pins.” Donovanosis is rarely encountered in the United States, but it is a cause of genital infections in tropical countries including India, Papua New Guinea, the Caribbean, South America, and Australia.

Genital ulcers in sexually active individuals raise concern for infection from several organisms, which requires prompt identification and treatment. Recalling the nature of the ulcer (painful vs. painless, multiple vs. single) and features of lymphadenopathy can assist in diagnosis, as outlined in the table below.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Gram-negative bacteria with intracytoplasmic cysts and deeply staining bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes urethritis in individuals with male genitalia. Symptoms include purulent urethral discharge and dysuria. Genital ulcers are not found in this condition.  
❌ Multinucleated cells with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex genitalis infection does cause multiple genital ulcers; however, they tend to be painful and associated with tender lymphadenopathy as opposed to the nontender ulcers observed in this patient.  
❌ Spirochetes under dark field microscopy:
Incorrect: Primary syphilis typically presents with a single, nontender genital chancre or ulcer. This patient instead has multiple nontender purulent ulcers.  
❌ Gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands:
Incorrect: Microscopic analysis of Haemophilus ducreyi infection will reveal a  “school of fish” appearance. Clinically, patients present with multiple, tender purulent genital ulcers.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to fever accompanied by severe headache and myalgias for the past 2 days. Since then, he has felt nauseous and has vomited multiple times. He was born at term through normal vaginal delivery and reached all milestones. Immunizations are up to date, and his parents deny sick contacts but are not sure if any of the other kids in the daycare have been sick. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the child is lethargic, and the knees flex upon neck flexion. Lumbar puncture is obtained, and the results are shown below:  
 
 Cerebrospinal fluid 
 Opening pressure  250 mm H2O 
 Protein   100 mg/dL 
 Glucose  60 mg/dL 
 RBCs  none 
 WBC count   400/µL 
 Neutrophils   40%  
 Lymphocytes  60% 

Cultures and gram stain results are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with headache, confusion, fever, and positive Brudzinski sign, raising concern for meningitis.
