Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes can cause pharyngitis, which can manifest with fever, tonsillar swelling with exudates, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. In contrast, this patient has posterior auricular and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, which is more concerning for infectious mononucleosis.
❌ Human herpes virus 3:
Incorrect: Human herpes virus 3 (HHV-3), also known as the varicella-zoster virus, is the pathogen that causes shingles as well as chicken pox. In contrast, this patient presents with malaise, tonsillar swelling, posterior lymphadenopathy, which is more suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. HHV-3 does not cause infectious mononucleosis.
❌ Human herpes virus 6:
Incorrect: Human herpes virus 6 (HHV-6) can give rise to roseola infantum. The condition can manifest with high fevers followed by development of a macular rash. In contrast, HHV-6 is an uncommon cause of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old young man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of lesions on the abdomen. The lesions were fluid-filled sacs that eventually burst, leaving behind yellow, crusted areas of inflammation. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 112/73 mmHg, and pulse is 68/min. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathogenic factors is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient had flaccid bullae on the trunk that ruptured and left behind yellow, crusted lesions. These findings are consistent with bullous impetigo, which is most commonly caused by strains of Staphylococcus aureus that secrete exfoliative toxin A.

Impetigo is a contagious superficial bacterial infection manifesting on the face, trunk, and extremities with lesions that progress from papules to vesicles/bullae and later crusting. Impetigo is divided into bullous and non-bullous forms.

Non-bullous impetigo is the more common form and is caused by either Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Clinically, it is characterized by papules that progress to vesicles surrounded by erythema, which subsequently break down to form thick, adherent crusts with a characteristic golden appearance. It most commonly involves the face and extremities.

In contrast, bullous impetigo is less common and is almost always due to infection with Staphylococcus aureus strains carrying exfoliative toxin A. This toxin targets desmoglein, resulting in loss of adhesion along the superficial epidermis. Clinically, exfoliative toxin A leads to formation of large bullae that eventually burst and leave behind a golden crusting lesion. Bullous impetigo is nearly always found on the trunk.



Option Analysis

✅ Exfoliative toxin A :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Erythrogenic toxin:
Incorrect: Scarlet fever arises due to infection by Streptococcus pyogenes. The condition is characterized by a constellation of symptoms including fever, pharyngitis, strawberry tongue, and a diffuse erythematous rash. The pathogenic etiology of the scarlatiniform rash is streptococcal erythrogenic toxin.
❌ IgA protease:
Incorrect: IgA protease is a virulence factor that allows pathogens to adhere to mucous membranes. IgA protease is produced by several organisms including Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, as well as Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is not, however, implicated in the pathogenesis of this patient’s bullous impetigo.
❌ Streptolysin O:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O is a virulence factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes that induces beta hemolysis and cell membrane degradation. However, streptolysin O does not play a direct role in the pathogenesis of this patient’s bullous impetigo.
❌ Toxin B:
Incorrect: Toxin B is associated with Clostridium difficile infection and results in destabilization of the actin cytoskeleton. Clostridium difficile infection would manifest with watery diarrhea but not the cutaneous findings present in this patient.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of double vision and difficulty swallowing. The patient’s family member reports the patient was “ill with a stomach bug” two days ago, after eating home-canned peaches. The patient has no other medical history and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows dysarthria and lateral rectus palsy. The organism implicated in this patient’s presentation produces a toxin that works via which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Inhibition of acetylcholine release from intracellular vesicles
Inhibition of glycine and GABA release

questions.solution:
Clostridium botulinum is a Gram-positive spore-forming bacterium that causes a rare but potentially devastating neurological disease known as botulism. The bacterium is primarily found in soil and has been well known to contaminate canned food products. This disease results from a heat-labile exotoxin produced by the bacteria, known as botulinum-neurotoxin.

This exotoxin works via cleavage of snare proteins, which normally bring loaded vesicles with acetylcholine to the nerve terminal at the neuromuscular junction. With snare proteins cleaved, acetylcholine is inhibited from release into the neuromuscular junction, resulting in absent muscle contraction.

Clinically, this manifests with flaccid paralysis – first involving the small peripheral nerves of the body (e.g. cranial nerves), resulting in dysarthria, diplopia, or dysphagia. Over time, the toxin begins to affect larger nerves, resulting in a descending paralysis involving the limbs, and even the diaphragm, potentially resulting in respiratory paralysis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of acetylcholine release from intracellular vesicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of elongation factor 2:
Incorrect: The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae inhibits elongation factor 2 (EF-2), leading to the formation of pseudomembranes in the oropharynx.  
❌ Overactivation of adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: The exotoxin associated with Vibrio cholerae works via the overactivation of adenylate cyclase, increasing cAMP, and increased secretion of chloride into the lumen of the intestine. V. cholerae presents with copious watery diarrhea but not neurologic changes.  
❌ Inhibition of glycine and GABA release:
Incorrect: The bacterium Clostridium tetani releases an exotoxin that inhibits glycine and GABA release at the neuromuscular junction, thus causing tetanus. Tetanus is characterized by spastic paralysis as opposed to flaccid paralysis and cranial nerve palsy.  
❌ Stimulation of actin depolymerization:
Incorrect: Clostridium difficile releases toxins A and B, which cause actin depolymerization in intestinal epithelial cells. Clostridium difficile infection presents with copious watery diarrhea and abdominal pain.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to severe shortness of breath and a cough with blood in the sputum. The patient started feeling tired and having myalgias a few days ago. The shortness of breath began yesterday and has worsened ever since. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol, and is employed on a horse farm. Chest X-ray demonstrates pulmonary infiltrates and a widened mediastinum. Sputum culture reveals a Gram-positive bacterium with a polypeptide capsule. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has pulmonary anthrax (also known as woolsorter disease). This is caused by Bacillus anthracis, a Gram-positive spore-forming bacterium. Pulmonary anthrax is a severe form of anthrax caused by inhalation of B. anthracis spores. Exposure is often from infected farm animals. Once in the lungs, the spores are taken up by macrophages and transported to the mediastinal lymph nodes, where they germinate, multiply and begin toxin production.

Pulmonary anthrax is the most severe form of anthrax. It is characterized by severe necrosis of the mediastinal lymph nodes and damage to the alveoli. On imaging, pulmonary infiltrates and mediastinal widening are often seen. Patients develop shortness of breath, hemoptysis and high fever, and can eventually develop bacteremia and death. Due to the severity of pulmonary anthrax, it is a possible agent for bioterrorism.  


Option Analysis

✅ Bacillus anthracis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: S. pneumoniae has a polysaccharide capsule, not a polypeptide capsule.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: S. aureus can cause cavitating pneumonia, especially after influenza infection. However, it is not an encapsulated bacterium.  
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: P. aeruginosa is a Gram-negative bacterium. This patient’s sputum culture is growing a Gram-positive organism.  
❌ Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
Incorrect: M. tuberculosis can lead to severe pulmonary disease. However, it is not an encapsulated bacterium.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic due to watery diarrhea for the last 3 days. The patient returned from Central America last week. The diarrhea is associated with diffuse abdominal pain. Stool studies show Gram-negative bacilli which produce a toxin that resists heating at 60 ºC (140 ºF). Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this toxin?

choices.text: Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by over-activating adenylate cyclase
Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by mimicking adenylate cyclase
Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by activating Gs protein
Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by inhibiting Gi protein
Increases cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by over-activating guanylate cyclase

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has “traveler’s diarrhea,” which is very frequently caused by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC).

ETEC causes watery diarrhea and abdominal pain that can sometimes be associated with fever. This process is toxin-mediated. Once the bacteria are ingested, they attach to the gut epithelium and secrete toxins that work in the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to diarrhea. The two toxins produced by ETEC are the heat-labile toxin (LT) and the heat-stable toxin (ST).

ST is resistant to heat. It works by over-activating guanylate cyclase in the gut epithelial cells, causing increased production of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). cGMP inhibits the reabsorption of NaCl, drawing water into the lumen of the gut and causing diarrhea.

LT is destroyed easily by heating. It works by over-activating adenylate cyclase in the gut epithelium, increasing production of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). cAMP in the gut stimulates the secretion of Cl- ions into the gut lumen, drawing water into the lumen of the gut and causing diarrhea.  


Option Analysis

❌ Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by over-activating adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of the heat-labile toxin of ETEC.  
❌ Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by mimicking adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of the edema factor of the anthrax toxin. Anthrax toxin does not significantly cause diarrhea and it is heat-labile.  
❌ Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by activating Gs protein:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of cholera toxin, which is a heat-labile toxin.  
❌ Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by inhibiting Gi protein:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of the diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin is a heat-labile toxin and does not cause diarrhea.  
✅ Increases cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by over-activating guanylate cyclase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider’s office for a wellness exam. She has no chronic medical conditions. The patient reports smoking half-a-pack of cigarettes daily, and she has been sexually active with multiple male partners in the last year. A speculum exam is performed, and a sample from the cervix transformation zone is collected. Subsequent visualization of the sample under microscopy is notable for the following findings:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s finding?
questions.solution:
This patient’s Pap smear is notable for koilocytes, which are immature squamous cells with dense irregularly staining cytoplasm and perinuclear clearing, resembling a halo. These phenomena are due to viral replication within the cell. Koilocytes specifically indicate that the cells are infected by HPV. A pathologist can look at the koilocytes and determine the degree of dysplasia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Trichomonas vaginalis:
Incorrect: A wet mount performed on a patient with Trichomoniasis will reveal protozoa with flagella. In contrast, no flagella are seen in the sample collected from this patient.  
✅ Human papillomavirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gardenerella vaginalis:
Incorrect: Patients with a Gardenerella infection will have clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells that are covered with bacteria. In addition, patients will have gray vaginal discharge that bears a fishy smell. Both this patient’s history and microscopic findings are inconsistent with the presentation of a Gardnerella infection.  
❌ Candida albicans:
Incorrect: Patients with vaginal candidiasis will have white and sticky vaginal discharge. Wet mounts will reveal the presence of pseudohyphae. The patient in this vignette has none of the aforementioned findings.  
❌ Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
Incorrect: Patients with gonorrhea infection will have purulent vaginal discharge, and the sampled epithelial cells will not exhibit perinuclear haloing or irregularly staining cytoplasm, which are caused by viral replication within the cell.

questions.text: A 27-year-old-woman presents to the clinic with abdominal pain and pain with urination. She reports having frequent sexual intercourse with her male partner. She is otherwise healthy and takes an oral contraceptive pill for birth control. Her vital signs are 37 °C (98.6.°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 15/min and blood pressure is 130/74 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness on palpation. Which of the following virulence factors is most likely causative for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Fimbriae from a Gram-negative indole-positive rod
Adenylate cyclase toxin from a Gram-negative aerobic coccobacillus
Exotoxin A from an aerobic Gram-negative rod
IgA protease from a Gram-negative coccobacillary rod
Adhesin from Gram-positive cocci in clusters

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy female patient is presenting with suprapubic pain, dysuria, and a history of frequent sexual intercourse, which is consistent with a diagnosis of cystitis. Of the virulence factors listed, fimbriae from E. coli is the most likely etiology, since this organism is by far the most common cause of cystitis. Fimbriae allow E. coli to adhere to the urinary epithelium and ascend the urinary tract.  

Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, which typically presents with suprapubic pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency in the absence of systemic symptoms like fever or chills (which would instead suggest  pyelonephritis). Other commonly implicated organisms for cystitis include Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Klebsiella, and Proteus mirabilis.  

Diagnosis of cystitis is made clinically in conjunction with urinalysis findings, which will typically reveal positive leukocyte esterase, positive nitrites, as well as bacteria and >10 WBC/high power field. Urine culture can then be utilized to identify the causative organism. Sterile pyuria (positive leukocyte esterase without nitrites or identified bacteria) is more indicative of urethritis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fimbriae from a Gram-negative indole-positive rod:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Adenylate cyclase toxin from a Gram-negative aerobic coccobacillus:
Incorrect: The adenylate cyclase toxin is unique to Bordetella pertussis, which causes whooping cough. The toxin blunts phagocytosis as well as the production of radical oxygen species by neutrophils and monocytes.  
❌ Exotoxin A from an aerobic Gram-negative rod:
Incorrect: Exotoxin A is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and inhibits elongation factor 2 by ADP-ribosylation of EF2 using NAD+, which ceases the elongation of polypeptides. P. aeruginosa can cause urinary tract infections (UTIs), but it is not the most common organism, and therefore it is unlikely the cause of this otherwise healthy patient’s UTI.  
❌ IgA protease from a Gram-negative coccobacillary rod:
Incorrect: IgA protease is a virulence factor produced by Haemophilus influenzae, enabling the bacteria to adhere to mucous membranes. H. influenzae is not a common cause of urinary tract infections.  
❌ Adhesin from Gram-positive cocci in clusters:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is part of the normal flora of the female genital tract and perineum. It is the second most common cause of urinary tract infections in young women.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman comes to her physician for assessment of painless “swellings” over her body for the past several months. Additionally, she endorses abdominal pain, constipation, fatigue, and cognitive slowing for several weeks. She recently immigrated from Japan last year, and this is her first visit with a physician in the United States. She has a remote history of intravenous drug use but does not currently use. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals generalized lymphadenopathy. Splenomegaly is present. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis reveals generalized diffuse lymph node enlargement and lytic bone lesions. Laboratory findings demonstrated below:  


HIV testing is negative. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and hyperlobulated nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Integration of viral RNA into T-cells
Integration of viral DNA into hepatocytes
Integration of viral DNA into B-cells
Integration of viral DNA into endothelial cells
Integration of viral DNA into cervical squamous progenitor cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents with generalized lymphadenopathy, hypercalcemia, a history of intravenous drug use, and peripheral blood smear showing lymphocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei. She likely has adult T-cell leukemia (ATL). ATL is a variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is associated with infection with human lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1).

HTLV-1 is an RNA virus endemic to Japan, the Caribbean, and Africa. Similar to the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), HTLV-1 has trophic factors for CD4+ T cells–making this subset of T-cells  the major target for neoplastic transformation. Many aspects of HTLV-1’s neoplastic activity are attributable to Tax, the protein product of the tax gene. Mutations in Tax contribute to increased genomic instability, as well as increased survival and growth of infected cells.

Clinical features of ATL include generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. A unique feature of this form of lymphoma is lytic bone lesions, resulting in severe hypercalcemia and ensuing symptoms. Diagnosis consists of a peripheral blood smear that reveals lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and hyperlobulated nuclei that resemble clover leaves. Immunophenotyping of these cells demonstrates evidence of T-cell markers (CD3, CD4, CD7, CD25).  



Option Analysis

✅ Integration of viral RNA into T-cells   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Integration of viral DNA into hepatocytes   :
Incorrect: Integration of viral DNA into hepatocytes can be seen with hepatitis B or hepatitis C viral infection and can result in hepatocellular carcinoma. This patient’s constellation of symptoms and findings suggests an alternative diagnosis.   
❌ Integration of viral DNA into B-cells   :
Incorrect: Integration of viral DNA into B-cells occurs with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)-related neoplasms such as Burkitt lymphoma (BL). BL typically presents with a rapidly enlarging jaw or abdominal mass. This patient’s constellation of symptoms and findings suggests an alternative diagnosis.   
❌ Integration of viral DNA into endothelial cells   :
Incorrect: Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus-8 infection of endothelial cells, presents as multiple cutaneous tumors and commonly occurs in patients with underlying AIDS. This patient’s constellation of symptoms and findings suggests an alternative diagnosis.   
❌ Integration of viral DNA into cervical squamous progenitor cells   :
Incorrect: Cervical cancer caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) may also result in generalized lymphadenopathy, but this finding is more often observed in patients with late, disseminated disease. The most common presenting symptom is usually abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge, which this patient lacks. This patient’s constellation of symptoms and findings suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic due to recent-onset nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. It occurred 45 minutes after eating leftover rice and vegetables from a nearby restaurant buffet. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Bacillus cereus is a Gram-positive, rod-shaped, spore-forming bacterium. It is aerobic, beta-hemolytic, and catalase-positive.

Reheated or fried rice is an important cause of emetic-type food poisoning associated with B. cereus. The organism is frequently present in uncooked rice, and heat-resistant spores may survive cooking. B. cereus can cause two distinct types of toxin-mediated food poisoning, characterized by either diarrhea or vomiting, depending on which toxin is produced. The diarrheal toxin causes destruction to the intestinal epithelium, triggering the secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea. The emetic toxin is ingested directly from contaminated food, which explains why symptoms usually occur very shortly after ingestion of the causative food.  

Option Analysis

❌ Giardia lamblia:
Incorrect: Giardia lamblia is usually transmitted by drinking contaminated water. It typically causes foul-smelling, watery diarrhea.  
❌ Clostridium perfringens:
Incorrect: C. perfringens can also cause food poisoning. In contrast to S. aureus and B. cereus, it is late-onset. Its spores germinate in the GI tract and then begin to produce toxins, which explains the pathogens' delayed onset.  
❌ Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli  :
Incorrect: EHEC is characterized by a diarrheal illness that is classically bloody due to its inflammation-inducing properties.  
✅ Bacillus cereus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Shigella:
Incorrect: Shigellosis is characterized by a diarrheal illness that is classically bloody due to its inflammation-inducing properties.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to headache and fever for the last 2 days. There is also associated nausea and neck stiffness.  The patient was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease eight months ago and is taking an immunosuppressive agent. The patient also takes pantoprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease. Physical examination shows a positive Brudzinski and Kernig sign. Temperature is 39.0 ºC (102.2 ºF), blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, heart rate is 102/min and respiratory rate is 20/min. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows significant leukocytosis. Gram stain and culture of cerebrospinal fluid shows a Gram-positive bacterium with tumbling motility. Which of the following is true regarding the bacterium responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: It uses actin polymerization for intracellular movement.
It is an obligate intracellular bacterium.
It can only survive at room temperature.
It uses flagella for intracellular movement.

questions.solution:
This patient has meningitis, likely due to Listeria monocytogenes based on the Gram-stain and culture. Listeria monocytogenes can cause meningitis in neonates, pregnant women, elderly patients, and immunocompromised adults (e.g. patients taking immunosuppressive medications). Additionally, the use of a proton pump inhibitor increases the risk of L. monocytogenes infection.

L. monocytogenes is a Gram-positive, catalase- and oxidase-positive bacterium. It is a facultative anaerobe that causes beta-hemolysis when grown on blood agar. It is motile and uses two methods of movement:

  • At temperatures below 37 ºC (i.e. outside of cells): L. monocytogenes uses flagella for movements, appearing as tumbling motility. 
  • Inside cells: Because of the higher temperatures, it cannot form flagella. Intracellular movement is instead done using actin polymerization. This gives the rocket-tail appearance and allows the bacteria to move intracellularly and from one cell to another, thereby evading immune cells. 
 


Option Analysis

✅ It uses actin polymerization for intracellular movement.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It has a polysaccharide capsule.  :
Incorrect: Listeria monocytogenes is not an encapsulated bacterium.  
❌ It is an obligate intracellular bacterium.:
Incorrect: Listeria monocytogenes is a facultative intracellular bacterium. It can survive inside and outside of cells.  
❌ It can only survive at room temperature.:
Incorrect: One of the features of Listeria monocytogenes is its ability to survive and replicate in cold environments.  
❌ It uses flagella for intracellular movement.:
Incorrect: Listeria monocytogenes uses flagella to move in temperatures below 37 ºC. However, at warmer temperatures (e.g. inside human cells) it loses its ability to form flagella, and moves using actin polymerization.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with a fever, chills, and abdominal pain that began this morning. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with a herpes simplex genital infection and treated with valacyclovir. She is sexually active and has multiple sexual partners. She uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was four weeks ago. She has not received the human papillomavirus vaccination series. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. BMI is 32 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Speculum examination reveals mucopurulent discharge with a friable, erythematous cervix. Cervical motion tenderness and right adnexal tenderness are present on bimanual examination. An external genital examination is non-contributory. Which of the following clinical sequelae is this patient at risk for if she does not receive appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Tenderness in the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness; the most likely diagnosis is pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). PID, if left untreated, can be followed by long-term complications including Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome (perihepatitis), which presents with right upper quadrant tenderness on physical examination.

Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome is an inflammatory condition of the hepatic capsule and adjacent peritoneal and pleural surfaces secondary to acute pelvic inflammatory disease. Clinical findings include those typical of pelvic inflammatory disease (cervical motion tenderness, mucopurulent discharge, fever) along with right upper quadrant pain and right-sided pleuritic pain. Laboratory evaluation is typically normal without evidence of transaminitis. On laparoscopy, gross liver morphology demonstrates purulent exudates and adnesions on the anterior surface of the liver, referred to as “violin string” adhesions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Tenderness in the right upper quadrant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Postmenopausal bleeding:
Incorrect: The elevated estrogen levels associated with obesity is a significant risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial cancer. While this patient’s BMI meets criteria for obesity, this current presentation with pelvic inflammatory disease does not increase this patient’s risk for developing endometrial cancer.  
❌ Axillary lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Risk factors of breast cancer include increasing age, female sex, obesity, positive family history, early menarche, and late menopause. However, this patient is presenting with pelvic inflammatory disease, which is not a risk factor for breast carcinoma.  
❌ Stress urinary incontinence:
Incorrect: Risk factors for pelvic organ prolapse and associated stress urinary incontinence include increasing parity, age, obesity, and a history of gynecological procedures. However, this patient is presenting with pelvic inflammatory disease, which is not a risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse or stress urinary incontinence.  
❌ Fixed uterus:
Incorrect: Clinical examination in endometriosis typically includes a tender, fixed uterus and tender nodules along the uterosacral ligaments. Risk factors associated with the development of endometriosis include nulliparity, late menopause, and early menarche. However, this patient is presenting with pelvic inflammatory disease, which is not a risk factor for endometriosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to a primary care clinic with fever, generalized muscle aches, and inguinal ulcers. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with acute urethritis and treated with a course of oral antibiotics. He is sexually active and began a monogamous relationship with a new partner three months ago. They use condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple purulent, tender ulcers on the penile shaft. Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is noted along with overlying ulcerative lesions. Histological analysis of one of these ulcers reveals an organism organized in parallel strands. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple painful genital ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy. Microscopic analysis indicates the presence of organisms organized in parallel strands (or a “school of fish” appearance). This description and clinical features are characteristic of Haemophilus ducreyi, the causative agent of the sexually transmitted infection chancroid.

Haemophilus ducreyi is a gram-negative rod transmitted through sexual contact, and clinical manifestations of the infection include multiple painful genital ulcers with a gray exudate and tender regional inguinal lymphadenopathy. One way to remember these clinical findings is that patients “do cry” when infected with H. ducreyi. Most lesions involve the penile shaft, prepuce, and glans penis in individuals with male genitalia. In individuals with female genitalia, the areas involved include the labia majora and minora, vaginal introitus, and the perianal regions. Diagnostic evaluation via gram stain will reveal gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands.

Genital ulcers in sexually active individuals raise concern for infection from several organisms, which requires prompt identification and treatment. Recalling the nature of the ulcer (painful vs. painless, multiple vs. single) and features of lymphadenopathy can assist in diagnosis, as outlined in the table below.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Haemophilus ducreyi:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Herpes simplex virus-2:
Incorrect: The clinical presentation of genital herpes includes multiple, shallow, tender vesicular genital ulcers. Histology of vesicular fluid typically shows multinucleated cells with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.  
❌ Klebsiella granulomatis:
Incorrect: Donovanosis is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium. Clinically, infection with this organism results in the presence of painless, ulcerative genital lesions without associated lymphadenopathy. This patient has painful genital lesions with lymphadenopathy, which is more consistent with chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.  
❌ Treponema pallidum:
Incorrect: The classic clinical presentation of primary syphilis is a single, painless, indurated genital ulcer. This patient has multiple painful genital ulcers with lymphadenopathy, which is more consistent with chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.  
❌ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Incorrect: Serotypes L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis are responsible for developing lymphogranuloma venereum. This clinical entity presents with multiple, painless genital ulcers with painful lymphadenopathy. Histologically, this disease is characterized by the presence of epithelial cells with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. This patient has multiple painful genital ulcers with lymphadenopathy, which is more consistent with chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy who recently immigrated to the United States from Asia is admitted to the hospital with dyspnea. Vital signs are within normal limits other than an elevated respiratory rate. Physical examination shows a gray pseudomembrane in the oropharynx along with cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following describes the organism responsible for this patient's disease?

choices.text: Gram-positive bacterium-producing exotoxin that inactivates elongation factor 2
Gram-positive coccus with a hyaluronic acid capsule
Gram-negative bacterium-producing exotoxin that activates adenylate cyclase
Gram-positive bacterium-producing neurotoxin that cleaves SNARE
Gram-negative bacterium-producing exotoxin that inactivates 60S ribosome by removing adenine from rRNA

questions.solution:
Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a club-shaped Gram-positive bacterium that causes diphtheria due to the diphtheria toxin (DT).

DT is a cytotoxic protein. After infection by a beta-bacteriophage, C. diphtheriae strains become toxigenic and can produce DT. The beta-bacteriophage genome contains tox-genes, which code for diphtheria toxin production. DT has two main subunits, A and B, joined by a disulfide bond.

The B subunit helps bind to host cell membranes. After attaching to the host’s cells, the whole DT complex gets slowly engulfed by the cell membrane. The membrane then invaginates to form a sac on its inner side, eventually separating and forming a vesicle (endosome).

Within the host’s cell cytoplasm, the disulfide bond eventually breaks, separating the subunits. The A subunit then diffuses through the endosome membrane into the cytoplasm where it interferes with ribosomal protein synthesis.

This happens because the A subunit has an ADP-ribose group, which attaches to elongation factor 2 (EF2), an important ribosomal protein that joins amino acids together during protein synthesis. This process is called EF2 ADP-ribosylation, and it results in complete deactivation of EF2, stopping protein synthesis and leading to cell death.  


Option Analysis

✅ Gram-positive bacterium-producing exotoxin that inactivates elongation factor 2  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Gram-positive coccus with a hyaluronic acid capsule:
Incorrect: This is referring to Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Strep). It does not form a gray pseudomembrane.  
❌ Gram-negative bacterium-producing exotoxin that activates adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: This is referring to Vibrio cholerae, which usually presents as voluminous “rice water” diarrhea.  
❌ Gram-positive bacterium-producing neurotoxin that cleaves SNARE:
Incorrect: This is referring to Clostridium tetani or Clostridium botulinum, neither of which forms a gray pseudomembrane in the oropharynx.  
❌ Gram-negative bacterium-producing exotoxin that inactivates 60S ribosome by removing adenine from rRNA:
Incorrect: This is referring to Shigella. Its infection usually presents with severe diarrhea, and it does not affect the oropharynx.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to his corporate health office prior to starting a new job as a perfusion technologist. As part of the onboarding process, he receives screening for tuberculosis using a Mantoux skin test (also termed purified protein derivative test). The patient inquires about how the Mantoux skin test results will be interpreted. Which of the following is most suggestive of a positive test?

choices.text: Induration of 15 mm in an otherwise healthy patient
Induration of 5 mm in a patient with IV drug use
Induration of 5 mm in a patient who immigrated from Mexico ten years ago
Induration of 1 mm in an HIV positive patient
Induration of 10 mm in an otherwise healthy patient

questions.solution:
The Mantoux skin test, or purified protein derivative test, is a tuberculin skin test commonly used to assess for latent tuberculosis infection, particularly in healthcare workers and other high-risk individuals. The test is performed by injecting glycerol extract from Mycobacterium tuberculosis intradermally on the forearm and then monitoring for a cutaneous immune response 48-72 hours thereafter. If previously or actively infected, a delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction is initiated, resulting in the appearance of an erythematous wheal at the site of injection.  

The size of the wheal is then interpreted based on the patient’s demographic profile and risk factors for acquiring tuberculosis. In all patients, an induration ≥15 mm is highly suggestive of infection with tuberculosis. False positive results may arise due to infection by non-tuberculosis mycobacteria, previous BCG vaccination, or improper administration of the reagent. False negative results can occur due to a weakened immune system (resulting in inability to react to skin tests), age less than 6 months old, or recent live virus vaccination/illnesses.    

 The interferon-gamma release assay is an alternative to the Mantoux skin test. It functions as a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that quantitates the amount of IFN-γ produced in response to antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This blood test is also used to screen for latent tuberculosis and is becoming more popular in many healthcare settings due to its ease of use and no need for follow-up interpretation.  



Option Analysis

✅ Induration of 15 mm in an otherwise healthy patient:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Induration of 5 mm in a patient with IV drug use :
Incorrect: An induration ≥10 mm in diameter is needed to yield a positive PPD test result in individuals with a history of intravenous drug use, recent immigrants from endemic regions, children <4 years of age, and individuals working directly with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (e.g. laboratory personnel).
❌  Induration of 5 mm in a patient who immigrated from Mexico ten years ago:
Incorrect: An induration ≥10 mm in diameter is needed to yield a positive PPD test result in individuals who immigrated from endemic regions <5 years ago.   
❌ Induration of 1 mm in an HIV positive patient:
Incorrect: An induration ≥ 5 mm in diameter is needed to yield a positive PPD test result in individuals with a history of immunosuppression, organ transplant recipients, and individuals with known recent tuberculosis exposure. 
❌ Induration of 10 mm in an otherwise healthy patient:
Incorrect: An induration ≥15 mm is needed to yield a positive PPD test result in an otherwise healthy patient.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent due to 3 days of fatigue, malaise, decreased urine output, and gingival bleeding. The parent states that the patient had abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea one week earlier, which resolved without treatment. The patient has no prior medical diagnoses. Family history is also non-contributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 106/68. Physical exam shows petechiae on the arms and in the mouth. Laboratory testing and urinalysis are obtained and shown below.  
 
Laboratory value Result 
 Hematologic  
 Platelet count  45,000/mm3  
 Hemoglobin  9.4 g/dL 
 Reticulocyte count   4.1% 
 Haptoglobin  9 mg/dL 
Blood, plasma, serum  
 Total bilirubin  5 mg/dL 
 Direct bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  2.3 mg/dL 
 Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)  32 mg/dL 
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  370 U/L 
 Urine  
 Color  Pink 
 Casts   RBC casts 
Which of the following toxins is produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient has thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, and decreased urine output in the setting of a recent episode of gastroenteritis (abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea). He has typical hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).   

There are two types of HUS, typical and atypical. Typical HUS occurs in children following an episode of gastroenteritis caused by Shiga/Shiga-like toxin producing organisms, such as enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli O157:H7 (EHEC) or Shigella dysenteriae. The Shiga/Shiga-like toxin inactivates the 60S ribosomal subunit, which leads to inhibition of protein synthesis. In the intestines, it causes destruction of colonic epithelial cells and bloody diarrhea. Once the toxin enters the circulation, it damages endothelial cells, triggers a massive release of von Willebrand factor, and causes widespread clot formation.

Patients usually have a history of eating undercooked beef, drinking unpasteurized milk, or swimming in contaminated water. Typical HUS carries a relatively good prognosis and typically is not life-threatening.    

Atypical HUS is caused by a genetic mutation in factor H, a protein that normally controls the complement system. It can occur at any age, is not associated with Shiga-toxin producing organisms, and carries a worse prognosis. Without factor H, the complement system is overactivated and unregulated, leading to extensive endothelial cell damage.    


 Peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes:  


Reproduced from; Wikimedia commons

Treatment consists of supportive care and dialysis if acute kidney injury develops. Plasmapheresis, in which the patient’s plasma is replaced by new plasma, may be indicated in refractory cases of HUS.  

Option Analysis

❌ Alpha toxin:
Incorrect: Alpha toxin is produced by Clostridium perfringens. It is associated with myonecrosis (“gas gangrene”) and hemolysis. However, this pathogen would not cause thrombocytopenia. 
❌ Erythrogenic exotoxin A:
Incorrect: Erythrogenic exotoxin A is produced by Streptococcus pyogenes and is associated with toxic shock-like syndrome. Toxic shock-like syndrome can manifest with fever, rash, hypotension, and altered mental status. However, this pathogen would not account for the patient’s bloody diarrhea.
❌ Toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1):
Incorrect: Toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1) is produced by Staphylococcus aureus and is associated with toxic shock syndrome. However, this pathogen would not account for the patient’s bloody diarrhea.
✅ Shiga-like toxin:
Correct: See Main explanation
❌ Heat-stable toxin (ST):
Incorrect: Heat-stable toxin (ST) is one of two toxins produced by Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). It is associated with “traveler’s diarrhea.”

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats. He reports a progressive onset of symptoms over the past several weeks, and he has also noted the appearance of purplish, itchy, flat bumps on his forearms and legs. He also states his urine looks “darker” than usual. Past medical history is notable for diabetes mellitus and intravenous heroin use in his 20s. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 134/72 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a cachectic male in no acute distress, with submandibular and axillary lymphadenopathy, violaceous papules on the arms and legs, and 1+ pitting edema. Urinalysis is notable for 4+ protein without blood. He subsequently undergoes lymph node biopsy, which demonstrates the following histologic image:


Reproduced from:

Which of the following pathogens is most likely associated with patients clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with constitutional B symptoms including weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats. The examination demonstrates diffuse lymphadenopathy, features of nephrotic syndrome, and lichen planus (“violaceous papules”). The lymph node biopsy demonstrated large, atypical B-cells with a high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio consistent with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Give the clinical manifestations in this patient, he should undergo evaluation for concurrent hepatitis C infection.  

Hepatitis C infection often presents with multiple extrahepatic manifestations including hematologic, autoimmune, renal, and dermatologic diseases. Oftentimes, these disease states are the only clinical features of the infection. Associated hematologic diseases include essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, ITP, autoimmune hemolytic anemia and leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Autoimmune conditions include diabetes, hypothyroidism and dermatologic conditions including porphyria cutanea tarda and lichen planus. Renal manifestations are also commonplace, with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis being identified in most patients.



Option Analysis

✅ Hepatitis C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Human polyomavirus 2:
Incorrect: Human polyomavirus 2, also known as JC virus, is more commonly associated with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in patients with underlying HIV. This disease will present with neurologic symptoms and non-enhancing areas of demyelination on MRI.
❌ Human T-cell leukemia virus:
Incorrect: Human T-cell leukemia virus is associated with diffuse large T-cell lymphoma. While also common in patients with a history of intravenous drug use, this virus is more commonly found in patients from Japan, the Caribbean and west Africa. Patients will develop hypercalcemia and lytic bone lesions.
❌ Helicobacter pylori:
Incorrect: MALT lymphoma is more common in patients with underlying H. pylori infection. This disease will more commonly present with gastrointestinal symptoms including postprandial pain or vomiting. It is not associated with the development of lichen planus.
❌ Epstein-Barr virus:
Incorrect: The Epstein-Barr virus is more commonly associated with Burkitt lymphoma, which histologically demonstrates a “starry sky” appearance. Additionally, Burkitt lymphoma is more commonly seen in younger patients as a rapidly enlarging mandibular mass (endemic variant) or abdominal mass (non-endemic/sporadic variant).

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of severe right knee pain and swelling. The pain has been making it difficult for him to bear weight on his right leg. He also endorses new exertional dyspnea, stating he becomes short of breath after climbing a flight of stairs. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 95/minute, respirations are 22/minute, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin, lean emaciated man with track marks on his forearms. The right knee is red, swollen and tender. Cardiac auscultation reveals a holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border. Arthrocentesis is performed and demonstrates a leukocyte count of 160,000/mm3 with 92% neutrophils. Which of the following is most likely to be observed on gram stain of synovial fluid?
questions.solution:
The constellation of findings in this patient (acute onset right knee pain, swelling), together with synovial fluid analysis of >150,000 leukocytes/mm3 with 92% neutrophils, is highly suggestive of septic arthritis. In addition, the history of dyspnea, low-grade fever, track marks on forearms, and a new holosystolic murmur on exam raises concern for septic arthritis secondary to subacute infective endocarditis via hematogenous seeding from valvular vegetations.  

Septic arthritis that occurs secondary to IE (or even direct inoculation) is most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus given its propensity in adherence to synovial tissue. The organism appears as gram-positive cocci in clusters on microscopy. These patients usually present with painful, warm, tender and erythematous joint with restricted range of motion and an inability to bear weight on the affected extremity. The knee is the most commonly affected joint. Diagnosis is based on arthrocentesis to obtain synovial fluid for analysis and culture which reveals leukocyte count of 50,000-150,000/mm3 with >80% neutrophils.   

Option Analysis

❌ Gram negative bacilli :
Incorrect: Salmonella are gram negative bacilli that are the most commonly implicated organism in septic arthritis in patients with underlying sickle cell disease. 
✅ Gram-positive cocci in clusters:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Polymicrobial:
Incorrect: Small joint septic arthritis or those secondary to penetrating injury of a joint can be polymicrobial (Streptococci, Eikenella or anaerobic bacteria). Hematogenous seeding via valvular vegetations is mostly monomicrobial.
❌ Gram-positive anaerobic spore forming rods:
Incorrect: Clostridial species are gram-positive anaerobic spore forming rods. They can cause tetanus (C. tetani), botulism (C. botulinum), gas gangrene (C. perfringens) and diarrhea (C. difficile). Septic arthritis, however, is unlikely.
❌ Gram positive acid fast rods:
Incorrect: Mycobacteria are gram-positive acid fast rods. It can cause septic arthritis in patients with a history of travel to tuberculous endemic areas, but it is not a common cause in patients with infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A team of researchers is attempting to develop a new pharmacotherapy for the treatment of respiratory infections. Pathogen X, as identified by the researchers, is introduced to an in vitro model consisting of human nasopharyngeal epithelial cells grown within a culture container. Pathogen X is found to produce an enzyme that binds sialic acid residues on the surface of nasopharyngeal epithelial cells. This enzyme allows pathogen X to subsequently enter the epithelial cells. Clinically, pathogen X causes symptoms including shortness of breath, fevers, myalgias, and joint pain. Furthermore, infection by pathogen X can predispose patients to subsequent infection by Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following is the most likely identity of pathogen X?
questions.solution:
Pathogen X, as identified by the researchers, is most likely the influenza virus. Influenza is the most common viral cause of pneumonia and can clinically manifest with fever, shortness of breath, headaches, and other non-specific systemic symptoms (e.g., myalgias, joint pains). The pathogen possesses the enzyme hemagglutinin, which binds sialic acid residues on the surface nasopharyngeal cells, thereby allowing the virus to enter host cells. Additionally, the influenza virus causes necrosis of the respiratory epithelium, which inhibits mucociliary clearance and predisposes individuals to secondary bacterial infections.  

Secondary bacterial pneumonia is an important complication of influenzal pneumonia and contributes substantially to morbidity and mortality, especially among elderly individuals. The classic presentation is an initial improvement in symptoms of acute influenza followed by exacerbation of fever and respiratory symptoms. Common pathogens implicated in post-viral pneumonia include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus.  

In the United States, common causes of viral pneumonia are influenza (most common) and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Influenza virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mycoplasma pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Atypical or “walking pneumonia” can be caused by the bacteria Mycoplasma pneumoniae. However, Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks enzymes that bind sialic acid residues on host cells.
❌ Legionella pneumophila:
Incorrect: Legionella pneumophila can be found in water systems (e.g. water-based cooling systems) and can cause severe pneumonia in elderly patients. However, the pathogen does not synthesize hemagglutinin and hence would not be able to bind sialic acid residues on the surface of host cells.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia. However, the pathogen does not synthesize hemagglutinin and would not be able to bind sialic acid residues on the surface of host cells. Furthermore, pathogen X causes myalgias and joint pain, which are more consistent with the symptoms of atypical pneumonia caused by viruses, Chlamydiae, or Mycoplasma.
❌ Cytomegalovirus :
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus mainly causes respiratory infections in patients who are immunocompromised. Cytomegalovirus lacks enzymes capable of binding sialic acid residues on the surface of host cells.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician due to worsening weakness in his legs. According to his mother, the patient had a low-grade fever and several episodes of vomiting two weeks ago. They are from Pakistan and are currently visiting relatives in the United States. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 9/min, blood pressure is 100/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Neurologic examination is notable for bilateral lower extremity weakness, greater on the left than the right, as well as atrophy of the proximal lower extremity musculature. His speech is noted to be slightly dysarthric. Which of the following best describes the organism and mechanism of transmission responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Fecal-oral transmission of an RNA enterovirus
Respiratory secretions containing a double stranded DNA virus
Food-borne transmission of a Gram negative rod
Fecal-oral transmission of a roundworm helminth parasite

questions.solution:
Poliomyelitis is caused by fecal-oral transmission of an RNA enterovirus. It is incredibly rare due to widespread, worldwide vaccination, but it still occurs in unvaccinated children. Approximately 200 cases occur yearly, and 95% of infections occur in children under the age of five.  

Polio spreads by fecal oral transmission. After being ingested, the virus replicates in the oropharynx and intestinal mucosal cells. During this time, most patients are asymptomatic, although some may have non-specific symptoms including fever, vomiting, and headache. As viral load increases, the virus enters the blood-stream where it is thought to invade neurons and the central nervous system via retrograde axonal transport to the spinal cord. The virus then replicates in motor neurons of the anterior horn, resulting in neuronal death and muscle paralysis.    

The disease causes asymmetric paralysis, more commonly affecting the lower extremities, and signs of lower motor neuron disease (e.g., fasciculations, hypotonia, absent reflexes). Other rarer symptoms include impaired brain stem reflexes, difficulty breathing, and meningitis.  

Some patients may go on to develop post-polio syndrome, which refers to new or progressive muscle weakness and disability in survivors of poliomyelitis. These symptoms usually occur decades after the initial infection. However, the etiology of this syndrome remains unknown. Potential explanations include progressive degeneration of reinnervated motor units, persistence of poliovirus in neural tissue, or induction of autoimmune-mediated neural tissue destruction.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Fecal-oral transmission of an RNA enterovirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Respiratory secretions containing a double stranded DNA virus:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1) is implicated in encephalitis. Individuals with this disease process tend to have fever, fluctuating levels of consciousness, confusion, and personality changes. HSV-1 would not typically lead to muscle weakness, atrophy, or bradypnea.  
❌ Food-borne transmission of a Gram negative rod :
Incorrect: Campylobacter jejuni is the most common etiologic agent of Guillain-Barre syndrome, which tends to present with symmetrical ascending bilateral lower extremity weakness. In contrast, this patient has asymmetrical muscle weakness and atrophy. 
❌ Fecal-oral transmission of a roundworm helminth parasite :
Incorrect: Toxocara canis is a roundworm that causes visceral larva migrans. Its neurological sequelae include visual impairment, blindness, and seizures. However, the condition would not typically manifest with muscle weakness, muscle atrophy, or bradypnea.  
❌ Sexual transmission of a spirochete:
Incorrect: Syphilis is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum. As the infection progresses, it can lead to tertiary syphilis and tabes dorsalis. Symptoms of tabes dorsalis include broad based-ataxia and a positive Romberg sign due demyelination of the dorsal column of the spinal cord. However, these findings are not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of testicular pain and scrotal swelling. He had an episode of bilateral facial swelling along the jawline several days ago with associated fevers, headaches, and myalgias. The pain is worsened with movement. He has no dysuria. He is not sexually active. Records demonstrate his parents refused vaccinations throughout childhood. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilaterally enlarged and tender testicles. Stroking of the inner thigh bilaterally results in elevation of the testes. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Retrograde urethral ascent of E. Coli
Infection with a double stranded DNA virus

questions.solution:
This adolescent male presents with features of orchitis (acute testicular inflammation). Given his prior symptoms of parotitis, viral prodrome (e.g., malaise, fever), and lack of vaccination, he likely suffered from mumps. The pathogen implicated in this condition is an RNA virus in the family of Paramyxoviridae. Mumps is the most common cause of viral orchitis (occurs in 20-30% of men with mumps infection), and it usually spreads to the testicles via the bloodstream.

Orchitis can also occur in the setting of a prior epididymal infection via a retrograde urethral infection. In this setting, pyogenic bacterial orchitis occurs as a consequence of contiguous spread from an inflammatory process in the epididymis, resulting in epididymo-orchitis. The majority of these cases are caused by E. coli, and patients with high-spiking fevers and associated SIRS criteria. In either case, orchitis is characterized clinically by testicular swelling and tenderness, with normal cremasteric reflexes.    

Option Analysis

✅ Infection with an RNA paramyxovirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dissemination of gram-negative Neisseria spp.:
Incorrect: Epididymis due to blood-borne dissemination of N. gonorrhoeae is possible, but patients typically have high-spiking fevers with associated SIRS criteria. This patient’s stable vital signs and symptoms suggest a different etiology.
❌ Retrograde urethral ascent of E. Coli:
Incorrect: Retrograde ascent of urethral pathogens via the ejaculatory duct into the vas deferens is the typical route of epididymal infections. Pathogens, like E. Coli, can spread to the testicles and result in orchitis. This patient’s symptoms (e.g., lack of vaccination, parotitis, orchitis) suggests a different etiology. Additionally, this patient is not sexually active, which is the major cause of epididymitis/orchitis in adolescents and young adults.
❌ Infection with a double stranded DNA virus :
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) can result in painful genital ulcers, dysuria, fever, and tender local inguinal lymphadenopathy. Viral spread to the lumbosacral ganglion can result in acute urinary retention. In contrast, this patient’s other symptoms (e.g., lack of vaccination, parotitis, orchitis) suggest a different etiology.
❌ Autoimmune inflammation :
Incorrect: Autoimmune orchitis is characterized by testicular inflammation and the presence of specific antisperm antibodies. Although it could explain this patient’s symptoms, the constellation of other signs and symptoms (e.g., lack of vaccination, parotitis, orchitis) suggests a different etiology.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful red bump on the left  leg. The patient was initially bitten by a mosquito, but over the past several days, the area became red, hot, and tender to touch. He is otherwise healthy and does not smoke, use alcohol, or consume illicit substances. On physical examination, a 2 cm x 2 cm area of erythema, warmth, and fluctuance is observed on the anterior left leg as demonstrated below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has an area of fluctuance, warmth, and erythema on physical examination, which is most consistent with a simple skin abscess. The most common organism implicated in skin abscesses is Staphylococcus aureus.

Skin abscesses are a common clinical condition and are defined as a collection of pus from a walled-off infection within the dermis or subcutaneous space. In nearly all cases, the offending organism is either methicillin-sensitive or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Staphylococcus aureus is able to produce coagulase, which enables the pathogen to form fibrin clots around itself and lead to abscess formation.

Clinically, skin abscesses are characterized as painful, fluctuant, erythematous nodules, with or without surrounding cellulitis. Most skin abscesses resolve with simple incision and drainage and a course of antibiotic therapy.




Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcus aureus :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes, also termed group A streptococcus, can cause a variety of skin conditions including non-bullous impetigo, erysipelas, and scarlet fever. However, Streptococcus pyogenes would not typically cause purulent infections or abscess formation.
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is often implicated in skin and soft tissue infections. It is generally associated with infections in patients with a history of severe burn injuries, intravenous drug use, or diabetes mellitus. This patient has none of the aforementioned risk factors, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a rare cause of skin abscesses in the general population.
❌ Clostridium perfringens:
Incorrect:Clostridium perfringens is often implicated in myonecrosis and gas gangrene; it is not a common organism found in simple abscesses.
❌ Streptococcus viridans:
Incorrect: Streptococcus viridans is part of the normal skin flora and does not typically cause abscess formation. Streptococcus viridans, however, is implicated in dental caries, endocarditis, and infection of prosthetic joints.

questions.text: A study is performed to evaluate the pathogenesis of Gram-negative bacteria that can cause meningitis. Escherichia coli was found to cause meningitis in children. Which of the following virulence factors does this bacterium possess that helps in causing meningitis?
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli is a Gram-negative bacterium that is part of the normal flora of the intestines. It can however lead to a wide range of diseases in the human body, as it possesses many virulence factors that help in the pathogenesis of different diseases.

E. coli is one of the most common causes of meningitis caused by Gram-negative bacteria, especially in infants. The bacterial strains of E. coli that cause meningitis possess a unique K capsule, a virulence factor that prevents phagocytosis. This helps E. coli evade immune cells and reach the bloodstream. Additionally, K capsule mediates the movement of E. coli across the blood-brain barrier.

K capsule is also an important virulence factor for the strains of E. coli that causes pneumonia as it prevents the phagocytosis of the bacteria by alveolar macrophages, allowing the bacteria to survive in the lungs and replicate.  

Option Analysis

✅ K capsule:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fimbriae:
Incorrect: Fimbriae of E. coli help in adhesion to cell surfaces. Fimbriae play a role in pathogenesis of urinary tract infections, but do not facilitate meningitis caused by E. coli.  
❌ Heat-stable toxin:
Incorrect: Heat-stable toxin causes diarrhea, not meningitis.  
❌ Heat-labile toxin:
Incorrect: Heat-labile toxin causes diarrhea, not meningitis.  
❌ Lipopolysaccharide endotoxin:
Incorrect: LPS endotoxin is the mediator of septic shock in Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli. However, it is not an important virulence factor for meningitis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a rash on the right forearm. The patient was recently admitted to the hospital for pain-control in the setting of nephrolithiasis. He recalls, “After I left, I was feeling fine, then the next day my arm started hurting, and I noticed a red rash near the site where I had my IV.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 119/77 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a well demarcated erythematous, warm, and painful rash over the anterior aspect of the right forearm without fluctuance. Infection with which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s cutaneous findings?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient presents with a well-demarcated region of warmth, erythema, and swelling in the area of a recent intravenous line placement. Given the absence of fluctuance on physical examination, this patient’s clinical presentation is most consistent with a non-purulent cellulitis, which is most commonly caused by group A streptococcus (also termed Streptococcus pyogenes).

Cellulitis refers to an acute, painful infection of the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissues. It is divided into purulent and non-purulent forms. Purulent cellulitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and is characterized by an area of warmth and pain with the presence of fluctuant nodules. In contrast, non-purulent cellulitis is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes and is characterized by an area of warmth, erythema, and pain without fluctuant nodules.

Risk factors for developing cellulitis include skin barrier disruption (e.g., trauma, insect bite, IV placement), obesity, and venous stasis. Most patients are treated with a course of antibiotics that cover Gram positive organisms.




Option Analysis

✅ Group A streptococcus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Staphylococcus aureus :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a well established cause of purulent cellulitis. However, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with non-purulent cellulitis given the absence of fluctuant nodules.
❌ Pasteurella multocida:
Incorrect: Pasteurella multocida is a commonly implicated organism in skin and soft tissue injuries due to a dog or cat bite. In contrast, this patient has no history of recent animal bites.
❌ Trichophyton rubrum:
Incorrect:Trichophyton rubrum is a fungus that can cause tinea cruris, tinea pedis, and onychomycosis. However, these infections are superficial and would not manifest with systemic symptoms such as fever or tachycardia.
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is often implicated in skin and soft tissue infections. It is generally associated with infections in patients with a history of severe burn injuries, intravenous drug use, or diabetes mellitus. This patient has none of the aforementioned risk factors, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a rare cause of cellulitis in the general population.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a past medical history of HIV and hypertension presents to the emergency department with worsening anorexia, cough, and night sweats. The patient has lost 15 pounds over the past 2 weeks. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and is non-compliant with his HIV medications. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 156/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam reveals a thin, cachectic-appearing male with scattered, coarse breath sounds. Mantoux skin test is positive. Which of the following characteristics best describes the pathogen responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Gram positive weakly acid fast aerobe
Gram positive spore forming obligate anaerobic rods

questions.solution:
This patient with HIV (not on HAART therapy) presents with worsening anorexia, weight loss, and a positive purified protein derivative test (PPD or Mantoux skin test). This presentation is consistent with infection by the Gram positive acid fast aerobe, Mycobacterium tuberculosis.    

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a relatively resilient bacterial species. Multiple studies have demonstrated the bacteria’s ability to resist damage from basic disinfectants, and it has been documented to live on dry surfaces for days. It is primarily transmitted via inhalation of droplet nuclei produced when a patient coughs or during respiratory procedures. Primary characteristics of the organism include a waxy-cell wall made up of mycolic acid, which will stain red with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain.   



Option Analysis

✅ Gram positive acid fast aerobe:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Gram positive weakly acid fast aerobe:
Incorrect: Nocardia species most commonly causes disease in immunocompromised individuals and can present with symptoms mimicking those of pulmonary tuberculosis. However, unlike patients with tuberculosis, patients with Nocardia infection will have a negative Mantoux skin test. 
❌ Gram positive intracellular rod:
Incorrect: Listeria monocytogenes can cause a spectrum of conditions including gastroenteritis, meningitis, and septicemia. It does not typically cause pulmonary symptoms.
❌ Gram negative aerobic diplococci  :
Incorrect: Neisseria species can cause a spectrum of conditions including meningitis and pelvic inflammatory disease, but it would not typically cause pulmonary symptoms.
❌ Gram positive spore forming obligate anaerobic rods :
Incorrect: Clostridia species can cause a variety of conditions including tetanus, gastrointestinal infections, and gas gangrene. It is not a typical cause of pulmonary or chronic infections.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department accompanied by his partner due to sudden onset of confusion and altered mental status. The patient’s partner mentions that the patient was in his usual state until 2 days ago when he started complaining of headache and fever. Since then, he has vomited twice, and yesterday he became confused and disoriented. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented, and nuchal rigidity is noted. No focal signs are present, and Babinski sign is negative bilaterally. The results of the CSF analysis are shown below:

 
 Cerebrospinal fluid 
 Opening pressure  350 mm H2O 
 Protein   250 mg/dL 
 Glucose  30 mg/dL 
 RBCs  6 cells//mm3 
 WBC count   1200/µL 
 Neutrophils   90%  
 Lymphocytes  10% 

Which of the following is most likely to be found on gram stain of the cerebrospinal fluid of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, altered mental status, and nuchal rigidity, a classic presentation of meningitis. The CSF analysis reveals low glucose, high protein, high opening pressure, and elevated WBC count with neutrophil predominance, which supports the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. By far the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults at all ages is Streptococcus pneumonia. S. pneumonia is an encapsulated, gram-positive, α-hemolytic, lancet-shaped diplococci that can be seen on gram staining. Gram staining is an efficient and inexpensive method that can help to direct empiric treatment in patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before culture and sensitivity results become available. Empiric treatment for meningitis in individuals over the age of 50 includes vancomycin, ampicillin (Listeria coverage), and a 3rd-generation cephalosporin (e.g., cefotaxime, ceftriaxone).

   



Option Analysis

✅ Gram-positive; lancet-shaped diplococci :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gram-negative; bean-shaped diplococci :
Incorrect: These findings indicate Neisseria meningitidis infection, which is the 2nd most common cause of meningitis in individuals between the ages 6-60 years. Although it is a possible cause, outbreaks typically occur in crowded areas (e.g., military, dormitories). Also, patients often present with petechial hemorrhages, which are not seen in this patient. A helpful tip for the USMLE exams is if no specifying factors are given, think of the most common cause of infection first and foremost. 
❌ Gram-positive; motile rod:
Incorrect: These findings indicate Listeria monocytogenes infection, the 3rd most common cause of meningitis in neonates or elderly patients (>60 years), as well as immunocompromised individuals. Streptococcus pneumonia is a far more common cause of meningitis. 
❌ Gram-negative; coccobacillus rod:
Incorrect: These findings indicate Haemophilus influenza infection, the 3rd most common cause of meningitis in individuals between ages 6 months to 6 years. Since the introduction of the polysaccharide conjugated vaccine for type B, infection rates have declined significantly. Streptococcus pneumonia is a far more common cause of meningitis. 
❌ No findings:
Incorrect: The lack of findings on gram stains of the CSF fluids indicates aseptic meningitis, which refers to patients with clinical and laboratory evidence of meningitis with negative routine bacterial cultures. This patient’s CSF analysis indicates bacterial infection, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to acute onset of seizure 1 hour ago. His parents state that several days ago, he started complaining of headaches and fever. Last week, he experienced an episode of sinus congestion and purulent mucus production which was treated symptomatically with nasal saline irrigation. Past medical history is unremarkable other than a few episodes of otitis media. He was born via normal vaginal birth and delivery and has reached all milestones appropriately. The family owns a cat and a dog. The parents deny any trauma. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 104/68 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic but arousable. There is no nuchal rigidity or photophobia. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. Strength is 5/5 on the left side of the body and 3/5 on the right. The patient responds to questions, but his speech is incomprehensible. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a recent history of an upper respiratory infection (likely sinusitis) is now presenting with new-onset of seizure, headaches, fever, and unilateral weakness; he most likely has a brain abscess due to contiguous spread from the sinus infection. A definitive diagnosis requires further evaluation.  

Brain abscess is a focal collection of pus within the brain tissue that occurs as a complication of infection, trauma, or surgery. Bacteria gain access to the brain either by direct spread from a contiguous location or through hematogenous seeding. A direct spread of infection from a contiguous site usually causes a single abscess, while the spread through bacteremia usually causes multiple lesions. Primary infections that can directly spread to the brain include:  

  •  otitis media and mastoiditis, resulting in abscess formation in the temporal lobe and/or cerebellum 
  •  sinusitis in the frontal or ethmoid sinuses, resulting in abscess formation in the frontal lobes 
  •  dental infections, resulting in abscess formation in the frontal lobes 
The pathogens involved differ depending upon the primary infection location, patient age, and the immune status of the host. However, Viridans streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus are the most common pathogens.  

Patients may present with a classic triad of headache, fever, and focal neurologic deficits, although not all signs are always present. Other signs may include seizure and altered mental status. Meningeal signs can also be seen (e.g. neck stiffness). Imaging (e.g. MRI) may show a ring-enhancing lesion with vasogenic edema. The MRI below shows a ring-enhancing lesion, which indicates the brain abscess (red circle), as well as a therapeutic ventricular catheter (yellow arrow). Lumbar puncture is contraindicated when signs of elevated intracranial pressure are present, due to the risk of brain herniation. Stereotactic CT-guided aspiration is required to direct treatment. Treatment of a brain abscess usually requires a combination of antibiotics and surgical drainage.    


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Toxoplasmosis:
Incorrect: Toxoplasmosis is caused by the intracellular protozoan parasite, Toxoplasma gondii. Primary infection in immunocompetent individuals is usually asymptomatic. Rarely, immunocompetent individuals can present with systemic infection (e.g., fever, chills, and sweats) or as an ocular disease (e.g., posterior uveitis). Reactivation of latent infection is often seen in immunocompromised patients and presents with multiple central nervous system ring-enhancing lesions. This patient is immunocompetent, and the presence of focal neurologic deficits after a preceding upper respiratory infection favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Viral meningitis:
Incorrect: Viral meningitis (or aseptic meningitis) usually presents with fever, headache and signs of meningeal inflammation (e.g. nuchal rigidity) on physical examination. This patient is presenting with impaired brain function (e.g. aphasia) and focal neurologic deficits, which favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Bacterial meningitis:
Incorrect: Bacterial meningitis usually presents with fever, headache, and signs of meningeal inflammation (e.g. nuchal rigidity) on physical examination.
