This patient is presenting with impaired brain function (e.g. aphasia) and focal neurologic deficits after a preceding upper respiratory infection, favoring another diagnosis.   
✅ Brain abscess:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intracranial tumor:
Incorrect: Intracranial tumors can also present with signs of elevated intracranial pressure and focal neurologic deficits; however, fever is not typical. In addition, the recent history of a sinus infection, fever, and focal neurologic deficits favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner following an episode of generalized convulsions. His partner reports that for the past 3 days, the patient has had a high fever and severe headache accompanied by nausea and vomiting. She also mentions that he started complaining of smell and taste changes. A few days ago, they came back from a trip to California in which they hiked and swam in lakes. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is confused and unresponsive. Pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Brudzinski sign is positive. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows the following:  

 
 Cerebrospinal fluid 
 Opening pressure  300 mm H2O 
 Protein   130 mg/dL 
 Glucose  20 mg/dL 
 RBCs  Numerous 
 WBC count   1500/µL with polymorphonuclear predominance 
 Neutrophils   80%  

Gram stain of the CSF is negative. Head imaging results are nonspecific. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an abrupt onset of fever, seizure and altered mental status. The physical examination shows nuchal rigidity, while the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) results show low glucose with numerous neutrophils and RBCs. In light of the recent swimming activity, the rapidly progressive course of the disease, and the presence of RBCs in the CSF, the most likely diagnosis is amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) caused by Naegleria fowleri.   

Naegleria fowleri is a protozoan parasite that can be found in fresh and warm water sources (thermophilic amoebae) worldwide. The most common risk factor for infection is recreational water activities. Trophozoites from the water penetrate the olfactory mucosa, cross the cribriform plates, and eventually reach the olfactory bulb and brain. PAM is an acute hemorrhagic meningoencephalitis with an extremely high mortality rate. Patients often present with high fevers, severe headache, photophobia, nausea, vomiting, behavioral changes, seizures, and altered mental status. Smell and taste abnormalities may occur early and imply the migration of the parasite through the olfactory mucosa. Eventually, severe intracranial hypertension develops, leading to herniation and death within days. CSF analysis typically shows high WBC count with marked polymorphonuclear predominance, low glucose, elevated protein, numerous RBCs (due to hemorrhage) but negative routine bacterial cultures and gram stain. Diagnosis is based upon the clinical suspicion and is established by observation of motile trophozoites on CSF with wet mount or by polymerase chain reaction. Conventional treatment includes amphotericin B as well as other agents.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cryptococcus neoformans:
Incorrect: Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis typically presents with insidious onset of fever and headaches. CSF analysis shows low glucose, mild protein elevation, low WBCs (<50 cells/µL) with mononuclear predominance. It is unlikely to cause infection in an immunocompetent individual, such as this patient. This patient’s abrupt presentation and CSF analysis favor another diagnosis.  
✅ Amoeba :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: Patients with Herpes simplex virus meningitis often present with rapid onset of fever and at least one of the following: altered mentation, focal cranial nerve deficits, hemiparesis, dysphasia, aphasia, ataxia, focal seizures, headache, and/or focal neurologic signs. CSF analysis demonstrates normal glucose levels, elevated WBC with lymphocytic predominance, elevated protein, and often RBCs. This patient CSF analysis shows low glucose and neutrophilic predominance. 
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Bacterial meningitis usually present with fever, malaise, photophobia and meningeal signs. The cerebrospinal fluid of a patient with bacterial meningitis will exhibit a high neutrophil count, elevated protein concentrations, and reduced glucose concentrations; however, numerous RBCs in the CSF are not expected. Additionally, gram stain results would show gram positive cocci, unlike here. 
❌ Echovirus:
Incorrect: Viral/aseptic meningitis refers to cases that present with clinical signs and laboratory evidence of meningeal inflammation but have negative routine bacterial cultures. The most common cause of aseptic meningitis is the enteroviruses family, which includes poliovirus, coxsackievirus, and echovirus. CSF analysis typically shows normal/slightly low glucose, WBC count between 10-500 cells/µL and protein <150 mg/dL in most cases. This patient’s CSF analysis and acute presentation favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old female presents to the emergency department with worsening cough and hemoptysis. The patient has had a cough for months, but over the past week, it has become more severe and produces bright-red blood. She is originally from Bolivia, where she worked as a nurse, and she immigrated to Ohio several months ago. Past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not smoke or use illicit drugs.  Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 90/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 92% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates an ill-appearing, cachectic woman. Cardiopulmonary exam is notable for diffuse rales throughout the lung fields, and mental status exam demonstrates a confused woman who is unable to recall the year or month. Abdominal exam is remarkable for hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory and radiographic findings are demonstrated below.  
 
 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40% 
 Leukocyte count  2,500/mm3 
 Platelet count  90,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils, segmented  25% 
 Neutrophils, banded  1% 
 Eosinophils  0.5% 
 Basophils  0% 
 Lymphocytes  10% 
 Monocytes  2% 

 
 Urine  
 Erythrocytes  0/hpf 
 Leukocytes  100/hpf 
 Color   Yellow 
 Urine protein  1+ 
 Sediment   None 
 

Image reproduced from Radiopaedia    
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Disseminated infection with acid fast aerobe
Systemic infection with a Gram negative diplococci

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of working as a nurse in an tuberculosis endemic country, in conjunction with her chronic cough, hemoptysis, and signs of shock, raises concern for systemic miliary tuberculosis.   

Systemic miliary tuberculosis initially referred to only the radiographic findings associated with this progressive form of tuberculosis, noting the uniform reticulonodular millet seed appearance on chest x-ray and CT-scans. Now, this progressive form of tuberculosis refers to disseminated tuberculosis that can result as a sequela of primary or secondary reactive tuberculosis. Miliary tuberculosis tends to present with symptoms of systemic infection and multi-organ dysfunction. These findings include subacute cachexia, failure to thrive, fevers, hemoptysis, as well as acute multi-organ failure and shock.  

When tuberculosis gains access to the bloodstream, it can spread to the kidneys (resulting in sterile pyuria), lumbar vertebrae (resulting in Pott disease), central nervous system (resulting in meningitis), and liver (resulting in hepatosplenomegaly). When tuberculosis invades the bone, it can result in osteomyelitis as well as pancytopenia, due to destruction of precursor cells. Additionally, adrenal gland invasion can result in Addison disease. Of note, disseminated tuberculosis is actually the most common cause of Addison disease in developing countries. Lymphadenitis in the neck, referred to as scrofula, is another specific finding for disseminated tuberculosis.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Disseminated infection with acid fast aerobe :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Systemic infection with a Gram negative diplococci :
Incorrect: Neisseria meningitidis can cause a systemic infection, which manifests with symptoms of sepsis, meningitis, diffuse purpura, and Waterhouse-Freidrichson syndrome due to adrenal gland infiltration. This disease has become less common due to widespread vaccination efforts. Furthermore, it does not typically present with primary pulmonary symptoms. 
❌ Mycotic infection :
Incorrect: Histoplasmosis may be difficult to distinguish clinically from systemic miliary tuberculosis. While this patient has clinical stigmata for disseminated histoplasmosis, she does not have a history of exploring caves, spelunking, or contact with bird or bat droppings.
❌ Systemic sarcoidosis:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous infection that affects females more than males. Sarcoidosis can present with systemic manifestations such erythema nodosum, uveitis, and arthritis. None of these findings are present in this patient.
❌ Metastatic renal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Renal cell carcinoma frequently metastasizes to the lungs due to its relative ease of hematogenous spread via the inferior vena cava. It is more common in smokers and will almost always present with hematuria on urinalysis.

questions.text:
A 1-day-old girl is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for evaluation of jaundice and microcephaly. The infant was delivered by cesarean section at 36 weeks due to fetal growth restriction. Hepatosplenomegaly, intracranial calcifications and microcephaly were detected by ultrasonography during the patients gestation. The mother remained in the northeast United States for the duration of her pregnancy and did not travel. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates jaundice and widespread petechiae. The liver is palpable 5 cm below the costal margin. MRI brain reveals hydrocephalus and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Fundoscopy is notable for the finding as demonstrated below. Which of the following maternal exposures is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This premature neonate presents with jaundice, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, extramedullary hematopoiesis, petechiae (also commonly referred to as a “blueberry muffin” rash), hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications -- a presentation consistent with congenital toxoplasmosis. Infection with toxoplasmosis occurs by either consumption of tissue cysts present in raw or undercooked meat or by ingesting oocysts in the feces of cats, which can cross the maternal-placental barrier. One of the common features of this infection is chorioretinitis, a type of uveitis.  

Many of the TORCH infections can cause chorioretinitis as a complication. Chorioretinitis refers to a subtype of uveitis involving the posterior segment of the eye, inflaming the choroid and the retina of the eye. Toxoplasma gondii is the most common cause of infectious posterior uveitis worldwide. Ophthalmic examination of a patient with chorioretinitis will reveal inflammation of both retina and choroid, which appear as yellow-white lesions as above. Inflammation of these layers can lead to blindness if left untreated.    

Option Analysis

✅ Consumption of undercooked pork:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Consumption of raw fish:
Incorrect: Consumption of raw fish during pregnancy can expose the fetus to environmental pollutants, such as methylmercury. Mercury exposure can damage the developing fetal central nervous system. 
❌ Consumption of unpasteurized cheeses:
Incorrect: Listeria is a common contaminant found in processed/delicatessen meats and soft cheeses. Listeriosis in pregnancy most often occurs in the third trimester, resulting in fetal death, premature birth, or sepsis in the newborn. 
❌ Infected mosquitos :
Incorrect: The clinical features of congenital Zika syndrome includes microcephaly, facial disproportion, hypertonia/spasticity, hyperreflexia, seizures, ocular abnormalities, and sensorineural hearing loss. The mother has no history of travel, making Zika an unlikely source of this neonates congenital infection. 
❌ Exposure to blood products:
Incorrect: Exposure to contaminated saliva and blood is a potential source of infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). Congenital CMV typically causes intracranial calcifications limited to the periventricular regions.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with several days of malaise, nausea, and vomiting. He recently returned from a trip to Thailand one week ago where he was staying in crowded hostels and eating seafood from local vendors. He reports a new sexual partner while abroad, and they did not use protection. He is otherwise healthy and does not take medications daily. He smokes 3-4 cigarettes per day, although he reports he has not felt like smoking since onset of symptoms. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for scleral icterus and right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:


Which of the following describes the mechanism of transmission resulting in this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after recent travel to Thailand with associated malaise, jaundice, nausea and vomiting. The evaluation is notable for low-grade fever and a positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibody, consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A, which is spread via fecal-oral transmission.  

Hepatitis A is an RNA picornavirus that is transmitted via contaminated food or water—often raw oysters or crab meat—and is the most common form of acute hepatitis. At-risk individuals include those who travel frequently and daycare workers. After inoculation, symptoms develop within anywhere from one week to thirty days and include malaise, fevers, jaundice, nausea, vomiting and right upper quadrant pain. For unknown reasons, patients with hepatitis A also develop an aversion to smoking tobacco products.  

Hepatitis A carries an excellent prognosis, with most patients only requiring supportive care at home. In contrast to other hepatitis viruses, hepatitis A does not carry an increased risk of developing cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma and does not have a carrier state. Patients that test positive for anti-HAV (IgM) are said to have active infection, while anti-HAV (IgG) indicates prior infection or immunity.

Option Analysis

✅ Fecal-oral:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Unprotected sexual intercourse:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B and hepatitis C can be transmitted through unprotected sexual intercourse, although they are more commonly transmitted via contaminated blood or blood products. This patient’s evaluation, notable for low-grade fever and a positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibody, is consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A, which is spread via a different mode of transmission.
❌ Intravenous contamination:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B, C, and D can be transmitted through contaminated needles, accidental needlestick exposures, or contact with contaminated blood. This patient’s evaluation, notable for low-grade fever and positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibodies, is consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A, which is spread via a different mode of transmission.  
❌ Respiratory droplets:
Incorrect: This patient’s evaluation, notable for low-grade fever and a positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibody, is consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A. Hepatitis viruses are not transmitted through respiratory secretions.
❌ Vector borne transmission:
Incorrect: This patient’s evaluation, notable for low-grade fever and positive anti-HAV (IgM) antibodies, is consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis A; however, none of the hepatitis viruses are transmitted through vectors such as mosquitos.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the emergency room for evaluation of fever and a cough productive of thick, purulent sputum. The patient’s symptoms have been ongoing for the past two days. She has not experienced hemoptysis, unintentional weight loss, or night sweats. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes. She has a 15-pack-year smoking history and does not consume alcohol. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 122/88 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds over the right lung. Chest radiograph reveals a right lower lobe consolidation. Sputum Gram stain reveals gram positive diplococci. Which of the following is a feature of the organism most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Requires factors V and X for growth
Growth on charcoal yeast extract medium

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fevers, productive cough, and lobar consolidation. These findings are suggestive of typical pneumonia. Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is bile soluble and optochin-sensitive, is the most common cause of community acquired pneumonia (CAP) or “typical” pneumonia.  

Typical pneumonia is a term used to describe the classic findings associated with bacterial infection of the lung tissue. It is more commonly referred to as community acquired pneumonia (CAP). The condition is caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae or other bacterial pathogens such as Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Moraxella catarrhalis. It classically manifests with dyspnea, productive cough, fatigue, and fevers. Individuals may also experience pleuritic chest pain, which is a stabbing or burning chest pain exacerbated by breathing. Physical examination will reveal reduced breath sounds, crackles, and tactile fremitus over the affected area(s).  

If radiographic imaging is ordered, it may demonstrate a consolidation pattern consistent with bronchopneumonia (multiple patches of infiltrations) or lobar pneumonia (consolidation of a whole lobe). Sputum Gram-staining and culture can be used to isolate the underlying pathogen.  



Option Analysis

❌ Requires factors V and X for growth :
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative organism that requires culture on chocolate agar, which contains factors V (NAD+) and X (hematin). Although H. influenzae can cause community-acquired pneumonia, it is not the most common pathogen. 
❌ Catalase-positive:
Incorrect: Staphylococci are catalase-positive organisms. Although Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia, it is not the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. Gram stain would also reveal gram positive cocci in clusters. Furthermore, Staphylococcal pneumonia is often preceded by a viral respiratory tract infection (e.g. influenza). 
❌ Growth on charcoal yeast extract medium:
Incorrect:Legionella pneumophila is a Gram-negative rod that grows on charcoal yeast extract medium, which contains iron and cysteine. This pathogen can cause atypical pneumonia. However, this patient's symptoms of high fever, purulent cough, and lobar consolidation are more concerning for typical pneumonia.
❌ Complete hemolysis on agar:
Incorrect: Complete hemolysis (also termed β-hemolysis) is characteristic of organisms such as Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, and Group B streptococcus. However, none of these pathogens is a common cause of pneumonia in adults.
✅ Bile-soluble and optochin-sensitive:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the office for the evaluation of a rash. It started 2 days ago on the neck and trunk and then spread to the face and extremities. The patient had an emergency department visit 3 days ago because of a generalized-tonic clonic seizure. At that time, he had a temperature of 40°C (104°F). Today, temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 30/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows a blanching maculopapular rash that is most prominent on the neck, trunk, and buttocks.  A virus from which of the following classes is the most likely cause of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a history of febrile seizure, followed by appearance of maculopapular rash and resolution of fever, is consistent with roseola infantum (exanthem subitum), which is caused by Human Herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6). It belongs to the herpes virus family, which are enveloped, double-stranded, and linear DNA viruses.  

HHV-6 is most likely transmitted by asymptomatic shedding of virus in secretions of close contacts, though most cases occur sporadically without a known exposure. The typical presentation of roseola infantum involves a prodrome characterized by a 3-5 day history of high fever often exceeding 40°C (104°F) in a child 6 months to 3 years of age. During the febrile phase, other manifestations include febrile seizures, rhinorrhea, cough, vomiting, diarrhea, lymphadenopathy, and Nagayama spots (small red spots on soft palate and uvula). After the fever abates, the typical exanthem appears that is characterized by blanching erythematous macules and papules on the neck and trunk first, which then spread to the face and extremities. The rash usually lasts for 1 to 2 days, but sometimes it may go away within as little as 2 to 4 hours. The diagnosis is based on clinical findings, and the infection is typically benign and self-limited.


Option Analysis

❌ Togavirus:
Incorrect: Rubella (which belongs to the togavirus class) is a single-stranded RNA virus that causes a maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalo-caudal direction. Patients usually have a low-grade fever with the rash. Conversely, the appearance of a maculopapular rash after the resolution of fever is typical of roseola (Herpesvirus-6). 
❌ Reovirus:
Incorrect: A coltivirus in the Reovirus family can cause Colorado tick fever. It typically occurs in the Rocky Mountain states and is characterized by fever, myalgias, vomiting and weakness. A petechial or maculopapular rash is only observed in 15 percent of the patients. 
✅ Herpesvirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Calicivirus:
Incorrect: Norovirus in the Calicivirus family is the most common cause of gastroenteritis. A maculopapular rash is not usually seen.
❌ Parvovirus:
Incorrect: Parvovirus B19 is responsible for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). In children, it typically presents with a “slapped cheek” rash, followed by the appearance of a lacy rash on the trunk and extremities. Appearance of a maculopapular rash after the resolution of fever is typical of roseola (Herpesvirus-6).

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sore throat, shortness of breath, and chest discomfort. The patient’s symptoms began earlier in the week and initially consisted of sore throat and fever. Today, he began experiencing shortness of breath with exertion and chest pressure. The patient is otherwise healthy. However, he does not routinely visit medical doctors, since his parents prefer the advice of “naturopathic physicians.” Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 135/71 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

A screening electrocardiogram demonstrates first degree AV block with T-wave inversions in the lateral leads. Which of the following factors is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a gray-white pseudomembrane in the posterior pharynx and first degree AV heart block. In addition, the patient may have missed some of his childhood vaccines. In combination, these findings are concerning for disseminated infection by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which synthesizes an exotoxin encoded by the β-prophage gene.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a Gram-positive rod that induces a characteristic series of clinical findings in patients who are unvaccinated. The most common presenting symptoms include sore throat, malaise, cervical lymphadenopathy, and low-grade fever. In addition, the pathogen binds to pharyngeal epithelial cells and releases an exotoxin encoded by the β-prophage gene, which inhibits protein synthesis via ADP-ribosylation of elongation factors 2 (EF2). The exotoxin leads to cell death and formation of a pseudomembrane composed of necrotic fibrin, leukocytes, erythrocytes, epithelial cells, and bacteria. The pseudomembrane is susceptible to bleeding when scraped.

If left untreated at this stage, the toxin can reach the bloodstream, from where it can move to distant organs such as the heart, kidneys, and neural tissue. If the heart is affected, patients may develop heart block, myocarditis, or arrhythmias. Furthermore, renal involvement can cause acute tubular necrosis, and nerve involvement can result in demyelination and polyneuropathy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Exotoxin encoded by β-prophage gene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Toxin B:
Incorrect: Toxin B is associated with Clostridium difficile infection and results in destabilization of the actin cytoskeleton. The pathogen can result in abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. However, Clostridium difficile is not involved in the pathogenesis of diphtheria.
❌ Streptococcal erythrogenic toxin:
Incorrect: Streptococcal erythrogenic toxin is implicated in the pathogenesis of scarlet fever and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome. Both of these conditions can manifest with a diffuse, sandpaper-like rash, which is absent in this patient. In contrast, this patient has a pharyngeal pseudomembrane and AV heart block, which are more concerning for systemic diphtheria.
❌ IgA protease:
Incorrect: IgA protease is a virulence factor synthesized by organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, as well as Neisseria gonorrhoeae. IgA protease allows these pathogens to adhere and proliferate on mucous membranes. In contrast, IgA protease is not implicated in the pathogenesis of diphtheria.
❌ Streptolysin O:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O is a virulence factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. It can cause beta-hemolysis and cell membrane degeneration. However, it is not involved in the pathogenesis of diphtheria.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of progressive fatigue and dyspnea for several months. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Family history is unremarkable. He traveled to South America one year ago but does not recall any subsequent illnesses. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 131/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears visibly dyspneic. A systolic murmur is auscultated over the cardiac apex. Pulmonary auscultation reveals diffuse rales over both lung fields. The patient undergoes cardiac biopsy, with the findings demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical condition?


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This previously healthy patient presents with features of left heart failure and mitral regurgitation (systolic murmur over the apex). Cardiac biopsy demonstrates an Aschoff body (giant cell granuloma) and Anitschkow cells (macrophages with a wavy nucleus), favoring the diagnosis of rheumatic heart disease.

Acute rheumatic fever is an early sequela of untreated group A streptococcal throat infection that usually occurs two weeks following untreated group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis. Clinical manifestations include arthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules. Cardiac involvement typically involves all layers of the heart (pancarditis).

Damage to cardiac valves often becomes chronic and progressive, leading to mitral (most common), aortic, and, rarely, tricuspid valve damage. Rheumatic heart disease may manifest years after the initial episode of GAS pharyngitis. Regurgitation is the most common complication, but it may progress to stenosis. Pathogenesis involves antibody production and subsequent T cell response against myosin that shares similar epitopes with the M protein virulence factor of the bacteria (type II hypersensitivity).    

Option Analysis

❌ Parasitic infection:
Incorrect: Chagas disease is caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted to humans via the triatomine insect (kissing bug). Clinical manifestations include dilated cardiomyopathy, megacolon, and megaesophagus. Chagas disease leads to biventricular dysfunction with predominant right-sided heart failure (e.g., elevated JVP, peripheral edema) rather than left-sided (e.g., dyspnea and pulmonary crackles). This patient’s biopsy results favor a different diagnosis.
✅ Bacterial infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Viral infection:
Incorrect: Viral myocarditis should be suspected in patients who present with new unexplained cardiac symptoms and a recent upper respiratory tract infection (up to 3 months following the initial insult). Clinical presentation varies, ranging from asymptomatic to fatigue, chest pain, heart failure, arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or sudden death. Viral myocarditis could explain the patient’s symptoms; however, the biopsy results favor another diagnosis.
❌ Autoimmune granulomatous disease:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis is an autoimmune condition marked by a noncaseating granulomatous disease. Clinical manifestations include restrictive lung physiology, erythema nodosum, and arthropathy. Cardiac involvement may include heart failure, valvular dysfunction, conduction abnormalities, and pericardial effusion. Biopsy demonstrates noncaseating granulomas and contains both Schaumann and asteroid bodies.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department to assess sudden-onset right facial pain. The patient is unable to open his mouth due to pain. He has been taking diphenhydramine multiple times a day for seasonal allergies. Medical history is significant for allergies and hypertension. Temperature is 38.6°C (101°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 125/83 mmHg. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and tenderness over the right preauricular space. Laboratory studies demonstrate a leukocyte count of 16,200/mm<sup>3</sup>. Which of the following organisms is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute, unilateral facial pain, fever, and leukocytosis following recent sustained use of anticholinergics; he likely has acute suppurative parotitis.    

Acute bacterial suppurative parotitis occurs secondary to salivary stasis, which allows for retrograde seeding of the Stensen duct via mixed oral flora. Salivary stasis can be seen in patients who are dehydrated or have recently used anticholinergic drugs (e.g. diphenhydramine). Suppurative parotitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus but can also be caused by oral aerobes or anaerobes.  

Parotitis is characterized by the sudden onset of erythematous swelling of the preauricular areas that extend to the angle of the mandible. Patients also typically present with local pain and tenderness, often with trismus (e.g. reduced jaw opening) and dysphagia. Systemic findings of fever and chills may be present. Initial treatment of suppurative parotitis includes hydration and empiric antibiotics (e.g. nafcillin) directed against staphylococci and oral flora. 

Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcal aureus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: H. influenzae is a common cause of parotitis, but it is not the most commonly implicated organism. 
❌ Actinomyces:
Incorrect: Cervicofacial actinomycosis is a chronic disease characterized by abscess formation and draining sinus tracts. Dental infections and oromaxillofacial trauma are common preceding events. 
❌ Peptostreptococcus spp:
Incorrect: Oral anaerobes (e.g., Prevotella, Fusobacterium, Peptostreptococcus spp.) are less common causes of parotitis.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: S. pneumoniae is a rare cause of parotitis.

questions.text: A study is done to determine the pathophysiology of acute rheumatic fever after Streptococcus pyogenes infection. It was shown that antibodies against a protein from the bacteria could give rise to acute rheumatic fever due to molecular mimicry between this protein and human antigens. Which of the following best describes the function of this bacterial protein?

choices.text: It breaks down hyaluronic acid in the skin
It is responsible for the hemolysis of red blood cells
It is responsible for toxic shock syndrome
It helps invasion of the tissues
It inhibits phagocytosis of the bacteria

questions.solution:
Streptococcus pyogenes, known as group A strep (GAS), is a Gram-positive catalase-negative coccus that forms chains and pairs. It causes skin infections (e.g., impetigo, erysipelas, cellulitis) and pharyngitis. GAS also causes many diseases due to its toxins and sequelae of immunological reactions to the bacteria and its toxins (e.g., rheumatic fever, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis).

GAS is an encapsulated bacterium, and the capsule helps in evading phagocytosis. In addition, a structural protein found on the capsule of GAS called M protein helps prevent phagocytosis by binding to complement regulators and fibrinogen. M protein also helps in the attachment of the bacteria to host cells. Antibodies against M protein help in defense against the bacteria. These antibodies are implicated in the pathogenesis of acute rheumatic fever because the M protein structurally resembles specific structures in the human body, specifically myosin and glycogen in the heart and smooth muscles. This autoimmune attack of the antibodies against M protein on the heart and human tissues leads to rheumatic fever. This process is known as molecular mimicry.  


GAS also produces several exotoxins which help destroy tissue and allow GAS to invade – hyaluronidase, streptokinase, and streptolysin O and  S. Streptolysin O and S also mediate hemolysis of red blood cells.
 

The erythrogenic toxins (also known as streptococcal pyrogenic toxins) are responsible for the rash in scarlet fever and mediating toxic shock syndrome by acting as superantigens.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ It breaks down hyaluronic acid in the skin:
Incorrect: Hyaluronidase is an exotoxin produced by group A strep. It breaks down hyaluronic acid, helping the bacteria invade human tissue.  
❌ It is responsible for the hemolysis of red blood cells:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O and S are exotoxins that are responsible for causing the hemolysis of red blood cells.  
❌ It is responsible for toxic shock syndrome  :
Incorrect: Toxic shock syndrome (or toxic shock-like syndrome) is due to erythrogenic toxins, not M protein.  
❌ It helps invasion of the tissues  :
Incorrect: M protein does not help in the invasion of the tissues. Exotoxins produced by group A strep that helps in tissue invasion include hyaluronidase, streptokinase, and streptolysin.  
✅ It inhibits phagocytosis of the bacteria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with pain and discoloration of the right thigh. A week ago the patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident and suffered deep lacerations over the same region. The patient was evaluated at an urgent care facility afterward and a piece of scrap metal was removed from the right thigh. Currently, temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 70/44 mmHg and SpO2 is 93% of room air. The appearance of the right thigh is shown below. On palpation of the right thigh, there is tenderness and crepitus. Which of the following toxins is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
 

 Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with erythema, purple-black discoloration, bullae, and crepitus in the thigh most likely has gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens.

Clostridium perfringens produces an exotoxin known as alpha-toxin, or phospholipase/lecithinase, which breaks down phospholipids in cell membranes and leads to tissue necrosis. Soft tissue inoculation of C. perfringens is classically associated with trauma through the skin.

Symptoms of myonecrosis (muscle breakdown from this toxin) are extreme pain and swelling, and sometimes a thin, watery purulent leakage from the wound.  Crepitus is a classic sign of this and is due to gas buildup in the tissue.

The fast-moving infection and massive tissue destruction causes fever and tachycardia, and can quickly progress to shock (like this patient), and eventually death - within just a few hours.

Treatment of clostridial myonecrosis requires prompt and complete surgical excision of the necrotic tissue. This can sometimes include amputation of an affected extremity. Individuals typically need supportive care to help manage fluids and maintain their hemodynamic status. High-dose and often broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment is required. Sometimes hyperbaric oxygen is used.  


Option Analysis

❌ Tetanospasmin:
Incorrect: Tetanospasmin is the exotoxin causing tetanus. The underlying pathogen is Clostridium tetani. Patients can present with spastic paralysis, trismus (lockjaw), risus sardonicus (raised eyebrows and open grin), and opisthotonos (spasms of spinal extensors).  
✅ Alpha toxin:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Erythrogenic toxin:
Incorrect: Erythrogenic toxin is responsible for scarlet fever caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. Typical presentations include blanching, sandpaper-like body rash, strawberry tongue, and circumoral pallor in the setting of group A streptococcal pharyngitis.  
❌ Tracheal cytotoxin:
Incorrect: Tracheal cytotoxin is one of the three toxins released by Bordetella pertussis. It causes whooping cough followed by post-tussive vomiting.  
❌ Shiga toxin:
Incorrect: Shiga toxin is an enterotoxin produced by Shigella. It causes crampy abdominal pain followed by tenesmus and bloody mucoid stools.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a sore throat and fever. Physical examination of the oropharynx shows a grayish-white pseudomembrane and uneven soft palate elevation. The child immigrated from Asia 3 months ago and did not receive any childhood immunizations. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a club-shaped Gram-positive bacterium that causes diphtheria. It mainly causes diphtheria in unvaccinated or immunocompromised people. Most often the bacteria is transmitted from one person to another via respiratory droplets. The bacteria can also enter the body through open lesions on the skin, instead causing cutaneous diphtheria.

Following inhalation of infected respiratory droplets, C. diphtheriae attaches to the pharyngeal epithelial cells, where it releases DT toxin. This causes local inflammation that leads to necrosis of pharyngeal tissue and neck swelling. The necrotic tissue builds up over the pharynx and larynx, forming a gray adherent leathery membrane, commonly referred to as a pseudomembrane. In some cases, a portion of this pseudomembrane can detach and get lodged into the trachea or bronchi, potentially blocking the airways completely and causing death by asphyxiation.

If left untreated, the bacteria gradually invade deeper into the pharyngeal wall until they reach the bloodstream, from where they can move to distant organs such as the heart (myocarditis), kidneys (acute tubular necrosis), or nerves (demyelination causing polyneuropathy).

Regardless of the affected system, people with diphtheria infection present with symptoms of low grade fever, general malaise and weakness.

In pharyngeal diphtheria, people present with sore throat, a swollen neck that people commonly call “bull neck,” and the pharyngeal pseudomembrane formation that can cause difficulty breathing associated with respiratory wheezes or stridor.  


Option Analysis

❌ Bordetella pertussis:
Incorrect: Although pertussis can occur in unvaccinated children, it usually presents with low-grade fever and coryza followed by whooping cough and post-tussive vomiting. A grayish-white pseudomembrane is suggestive of an alternative etiology.  
❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae type b can cause epiglottitis, which usually presents with fever, dysphagia, drooling, and difficulty breathing. A grayish-white pseudomembrane is not usually seen.  
❌ Poliovirus:
Incorrect: Poliovirus can cause myalgia and paralysis in unvaccinated individuals. A grayish-white pseudomembrane is suggestive of an alternative etiology.  
✅ Corynebacterium diphtheriae:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Measles virus:
Incorrect: Measles virus usually causes a rash beginning at the head and moving down. A rash is usually preceded by cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots.  A grayish-white pseudomembrane is suggestive of an alternative etiology.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to progressively worsening confusion and inability to walk. She lives at home with her partner, who states that over the past week the patient has had worsening memory and trouble moving the right side of her body. The patient was diagnosed with HIV infection 3 years ago but has been non-compliant with antiretroviral therapy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg. Physical examination reveals oral thrush. The patient is not oriented to time, place, or person. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hyperreflexia and upgoing plantar reflex. CD4 count is 90/mm3. MRI shows multiple, nonenhancing white matter lesions. Reactivation of a pathogen from which of the following locations is most likely responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with AIDS is presenting with progressively worsening neurologic deficits and MRI showing multiple, nonenhancing white matter lesions. She likely has progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) due to reactivation of the John Cunningham (JC) virus.   

Most adults are exposed to JC virus at some point in their lives; normally, the virus remains latent in kidney epithelial cells in immunocompetent individuals. Immunosuppression, however, triggers reactivation of the virus and infection of oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system. Likewise, patients taking certain immune-toxic drugs (e.g., natalizumab, rituximab) are also at risk. Ultimately, failure of immune surveillance within the CNS allows for an uncontrolled viral replication.  

Patients with PML will develop focal and relentlessly progressive neurologic dysfunction. PML primarily involves the parietal and occipital areas of the brain, resulting in symptoms such as changes in speech and loss of vision. Other common symptoms include weakness, clumsiness due to lack of coordination, personality changes, and dementia. Imaging with CT or MRI will show multiple, nonenhancing white matter lesions, suggestive of demyelination.    

Option Analysis

✅ Kidney epithelial cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Trigeminal ganglion:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is a virus that remains latent in the trigeminal ganglion after primary infection. Reactivation of HSV-1 can be caused by immunosuppression, stress, or trauma. Although reactivation of HSV-1 can result in herpes simplex encephalitis, which would also present with focal neurological deficits, MRI would show hyperintense temporal lobe lesions. 
❌ Hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) can integrate itself into hepatocyte DNA, resulting in a carrier-state. Integration into regions that control cell growth and differentiation can result in dysfunction of cell cycle proteins, causing hepatocellular carcinoma. However, it is unlikely to result in neurological deficits, as seen in this patient.
❌ Sacral ganglion:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) is a virus that remains latent in the sacral ganglion after primary infection. Reactivation of HSV-2 can be caused by immunosuppression, stress, or trauma, and can present as genital herpes.
❌ Myeloid progenitor cells:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus (CMV), also known as human herpes virus 5, is a virus that remains latent in myeloid progenitor cells and can be reactivated in patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, post-organ transplantation). Clinical manifestations include CMV pneumonia, retinitis, and esophagitis. CMV encephalitis can also occur, which would result in impaired cognitive functioning and neurological deficits. However, symptoms would generally develop in patients with a CD4 count of 50/mm3 or less.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with a fever, chills, abdominal pain, and vaginal spotting that began this morning. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with primary syphilis and treated with intramuscular penicillin. She is sexually active with multiple sexual partners. She uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was three weeks ago. She has not received the human papillomavirus vaccination series. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Speculum examination reveals mucopurulent discharge with a friable erythematous cervix. Cervical motion tenderness and right adnexal tenderness are present on bimanual examination. An external genital examination is non-contributory. Urine pregnancy testing is negative, and a trans-vaginal ultrasound is pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who has multiple risk factors for a sexually transmitted infection (multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use) presents with symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, purulent vaginal discharge, right adnexal tenderness, and cervical motion tenderness. This presentation is most suggestive of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) complicated by a tubo-ovarian abscess.

Pelvic inflammatory disease involves the upper genital tract and often follows acute cervicitis. The condition is most commonly caused by the organisms Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis. Infection with these organisms results in disruption of the mucosal barrier, promoting transmission and colonization of the upper genital tract. Clinically, PID manifests with fever, abdominal pain, and purulent endocervical and/or vaginal discharge. On physical examination, cervical motion tenderness is often noted.

If untreated, or if there is a delay of treatment, pelvic inflammatory disease can result in long-term complications including tubo-ovarian abscesses, perihepatitis, salpingitis and infertility. A tubo-ovarian abscess refers to an abscess within the fallopian tube; the condition may present with adnexal tenderness on bimanual examination. Infertility may ultimately result as a sequelae of untreated PID as progressive scarring and adhesion formation within the fallopian tubes results in occlusion, fibrosis, and the loss of ciliary action.  

Option Analysis

✅ Tubo-ovarian abscess:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ovarian torsion:
Incorrect: Ovarian torsion presents with acute, lancinating pelvic pain with associated nausea and vomiting. Fever and mucopurulent discharge are atypical of this condition.  
❌ Condyloma lata:
Incorrect: Condylomata lata are raised gray to white lesions found in the mouth or perineum that present with secondary syphilis. This patient was appropriately treated for a syphilitic infection.  
❌ Ruptured ectopic pregnancy:
Incorrect: A ruptured ectopic pregnancy can present with acute abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding; however, this patient’s urine pregnancy test is negative.  
❌ Condyloma acuminata:
Incorrect: Anogenital warts (flat, flesh-colored papules) caused by the HPV virus are termed condylomata acuminata. However, fever and vaginal discharge are atypical of this condition.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic to evaluate perianal pruritus and genital lesions. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with acute cervicitis due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae and treated with outpatient antibiotics. She is sexually active and began a monogamous relationship with a new male partner three months ago. They use condoms inconsistently. The patient has had five sexual partners in her lifetime.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals several smooth, verrucous, skin-colored lesions over the labia majora and minora. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. Which of the following describes the microorganism most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several verrucous genital lesions, consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (a non-enveloped DNA virus). Condyloma acuminata is most commonly caused by HPV strains 6 and 11, transmitted via oral, vaginal, and anal intercourse.

Clinical manifestations of condylomata acuminata include the presence of cauliflower-shaped, fungating, or flat-topped lesions on the groin, perineum, or perineal skin that are occasionally pruritic. In individuals with male genitalia, condylomata acuminata also develop along the penile shaft, and in those with female genitalia, lesions also develop on the vulva. In most cases, diagnosis of condylomata acuminata is clinical; however, in cases of diagnostic uncertainty, a biopsy and histological examination should be performed. Histologic examination often reveals koilocytosis, which refers to the presence of multiple vacuolated epithelial cells with enlarged, irregular nuclei.

Option Analysis

❌ Gram-negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease, which typically presents with purulent cervical discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and intermenstrual spotting or bleeding. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.  
✅ Non-enveloped DNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anaerobic gram-variable rods:
Incorrect: Gardnerella vaginalis can cause bacterial vaginosis, which clinically presents with clear or watery vaginal discharge. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.  
❌ Motile, flagellated trichomonads:
Incorrect: Trichomonas vaginalis infection can cause mucopurulent vaginal discharge and an erythematous cervix. Infection with this organism does not result in the development of verrucous lesions. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.  
❌ Encapsulated single-stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: HIV is a single-stranded encapsulated RNA virus. Initial symptoms of infection with HIV include non-specific viral symptoms, including fevers and lymphadenopathy. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (which is a non-enveloped DNA virus).

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented to the emergency department due to diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past four days. Since symptom onset, the patient has had seven watery bowel movements per day. Temperature is 38.6 °C (101.5 °F), blood pressure is 99/73 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 16/min and SpO2 is 99% of room air. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and bilateral lower abdominal tenderness to palpation. Clostridioides difficile antigen test is performed and returns positive. Which of the following most likely predisposed this patient to this infection?
questions.solution:
This patient has abdominal pain, watery bowel movements, and a positive Clostridioides difficile (formerly Clostridium difficile) antigen test. These symptoms with the positive antigen test indicate an active C. difficile infection.

Around 5% of the population are asymptomatic carriers of C. difficile. These individuals do not develop colitis and diarrhea since other bacterial species that make up the intestinal microbiome prevent C. difficile from proliferating. However, if the diversity of the normal intestinal flora is disturbed, then organisms that are resistant to many antibiotics – like C. difficile – can thrive while other bacteria die out. The greatest risk factor for C. difficile diarrhea is the recent use of antibiotics, usually broad-spectrum antibiotics, fluoroquinolones, and clindamycin. Only a few specific antibiotics can treat C. difficile infection. Other risk factors include immunocompromised status (e.g. HIV, chemotherapy) and prolonged proton pump inhibitor use.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ingestion of contaminated foods:
Incorrect: This patient has watery bowel movements and a positive C. difficile antigen test. Normally, other bacteria in the intestines prevent C. difficile from proliferating, so it is mostly when other bacteria are killed (e.g. antibiotics) that C. difficile is able to proliferate and cause diarrhea.  
❌ Consumption of unfiltered water:
Incorrect: Pathogens such as Vibrio cholerae or Giardia lamblia can be acquired by consuming unfiltered water. In contrast, C. difficile diarrhea is typically associated with recent antibiotic use.  
❌ Initiation of famotidine therapy:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors can predispose individuals to C. difficile diarrhea, though recent antibiotic use is a much stronger risk factor. H2-receptor antagonists, compared to proton pump inhibitors, are much less likely to predispose to C. difficile.  
❌ Advanced age:
Incorrect: Advanced age and poor immune status can potentially predispose individuals to C. difficile diarrhea. However, recent antibiotic use is the leading risk factor.  
✅ Recent use of oral antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of left thigh pain, which has been ongoing for the last five days. The pain has been progressively increasing in severity. In addition, he has been experiencing fevers and chills. Physical examination reveals swelling, warmth, and erythema in the thigh above the knee joint. In addition, several track marks are noted on the forearms. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/minute, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Radiography reveals findings suggestive of osteomyelitis of the femur. The patient is subsequently started on antibiotics. The microorganism most likely responsible for this patient’s infection has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has osteomyelitis, and the most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus. Moreover, the patient likely has a history of intravenous drug use, as evidenced by the forearm track marks, which further predisposes him to infection by S. aureus.  
S. aureus is a Gram-positive cocci that grows in clusters. It is a facultative anaerobe, which can survive in aerobic and anaerobic conditions. It is part of the normal flora of the skin and can also be found in other parts of the body, such as the nostrils and oral cavity. However, if S. aureus can invade the blood and soft tissues, it can lead to various potentially severe diseases.
 

There are specific characteristics of S. aureus that distinguish it from other bacteria. These include:

  • Catalase positive: S. aureus can produce the catalase enzyme, which converts H2O2 to H2O and O2. This characteristic can be examined by adding a few drops of H2O2 to a culture of the bacteria, and bubbles will manifest due to O2 production. This test helps differentiate catalase-positive Staphylococcus species from catalase-negative Streptococcus species. 

  • Coagulase positive: S. aureus is coagulase-positive, producing the enzyme coagulase. Coagulase converts fibrinogen (soluble) to fibrin (insoluble). Therefore, if a few drops of fibrinogen are added to an S. aureus culture, then fibrin will precipitate and be visible. This test can help differentiate S. aureus from other Staphylococcus species (e.g., S. saprophyticus, S. epidermidis) that are coagulase negative.

  • Mannitol fermentation: S. aureus is a mannitol fermenting bacteria, which helps distinguish it from S. saprophyticus.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are Gram-positive, catalase-positive, and coagulase-negative bacteria. This patient has osteomyelitis, and Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism. S. aureus is coagulase positive, not negative.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Streptococcus species are Gram-positive, catalase-negative, and coagulase-negative bacteria. In contrast, this patient has osteomyelitis, and Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism. S. aureus is coagulase positive and catalase positive.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Eshcheria coli is a Gram-negative, catalase-positive, and coagulase-negative bacteria that can cause osteomyelitis, especially in children. However, this patient likely has osteomyelitis due to Staphylococcus aureus, given his suspected history of intravenous drug use, as evidenced by the track marks.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis, and Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism. The organism is a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, and coagulase-positive bacteria.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by family members due to altered mental status and fever. The patient’s symptoms started abruptly 24 hours ago with high fever and malaise. She then began experiencing abdominal pain and nausea and vomited twice. Past medical history is notable for recent trauma and nose bleeding after being hit in the face by a football five days ago, which was treated with nasal packings inserted into the left nostril. The packing is still inside the patient’s nose. She occasionally uses acetaminophen for headaches. The patient broke up with her boyfriend a week ago. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 88/60 mmHg, and pulse is 130/min. The patient is confused and unable to answer questions. Physical examination reveals a diffuse red macular rash. Liver enzymes are elevated, and platelet count is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Superantigen produced by colonizing bacteria that activates T-cells and macrophages
Type I hypersensitivity reactions to foreign antigens
Membrane toxin found on the surface of colonizing bacteria that activates macrophages
Antigen-antibody complex deposition in various organs

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely to have toxic-shock syndrome (TSS), which can cause fever, hypotension, diffuse macular rash, and multiorgan failure (e.g., low platelet count, elevated liver enzymes).

TSS is due to toxic-shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1) produced by Staphylococcus aureus. It is a superantigen that results in major activation of T-cells and macrophages, thereby causing massive cytokine release (cytokine storm).

Patients with TSS present with rapid onset fever, hypotension, rash, and multiorgan failure. The rash is a diffuse erythematous rash that resembles sunburn and can lead to desquamation (involving the palms and soles) after one to two weeks. Patients can also have nonspecific signs and symptoms, including gastrointestinal disturbance (e.g., nausea, vomiting), headaches, and fatigue. In addition, organ failure can manifest as liver failure (elevated liver enzymes), coagulopathy (low platelets count), renal failure (elevated creatinine), and neurological manifestations (altered mental status).

The major risk factor of TSS includes the use of nasal packing or tampons. These foreign objects act as sites where S. aureus can colonize, replicate, and produce TSST-1.

Finally, Streptococcus pyogenes produces a similar exotoxin called erythrogenic toxin A. Erythrogenic toxin A acts like TSST-1 by working as a superantigen and causing widespread activation of immune cells, thereby triggering a cytokine storm and leading to the toxic-shock-like syndrome. Clinically, toxic-shock-like syndrome and TSS present with similar symptoms.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Superantigen produced by colonizing bacteria that activates T-cells and macrophages:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type I hypersensitivity reactions to foreign antigens:
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions (also known as allergic reactions) are characterized by hypotension and rash. However, fever, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count are not typically present in patients with anaphylaxis. Instead, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with toxic shock syndrome.  
❌ Membrane toxin found on the surface of colonizing bacteria that activates macrophages:
Incorrect: Gram-negative bacteria can lead to septic shock due to endotoxins found on their outer membrane. However, this patient’s symptoms and in the setting of retained nasal packings are more suggestive of toxic-shock syndrome, which is caused by the Gram-positive bacteria Staphylococcus aureus.  
❌ Suicide attempt via acetaminophen overdose:
Incorrect: Although acetaminophen overdose can explain the patient’s gastrointestinal symptoms, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count, it is not associated with fever or diffuse macular rash. This patient is most likely to have toxic shock syndrome.  
❌ Antigen-antibody complex deposition in various organs:
Incorrect: Type III hypersensitivity reactions are characterized by skin rashes, joint pains, and possibly fever. However, elevated liver enzymes, low platelet count, and gastrointestinal symptoms are not expected.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of left leg pain and fever. The patient’s symptoms started 3 days ago when he was bitten by his friend’s dog. The dog is fully vaccinated. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and pulse is 85/minute. Examination reveals bite marks along the left shin with surrounding swelling and erythema. Laboratory testing reveals leukocytosis. Imaging of the affected limb reveals osteomyelitis of the tibia and soft tissue infection. Gram stain reveals a Gram-negative pathogen.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with soft tissue infection and osteomyelitis caused by a Gram-negative pathogen following a dog bite. The most likely cause of this patient’s presentation is Pasteurella multocida.

P. multocida is a Gram-negative encapsulated bacteria that is oxidase and catalase positive. It is one of the most common zoonotic infections and can be transmitted to humans following a cat bite, scratch, or dog bite.

P. multocida causes an acute infection that develops rapidly after a bite or scratch. It can lead to soft tissue infections such as cellulitis or deeper infections like necrotizing fasciitis. Additionally, it can spread to nearby bones causing osteomyelitis or joints causing septic arthritis. Finally, in immunocompromised patients, it can spread to cause endocarditis, sepsis, and sometimes death.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pasteurella multocida:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bartonella henselae:
Incorrect: Bartonella henselae is associated with cat scratch and bites, but not with dog bites.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus can cause soft tissue infection and osteomyelitis following a dog bite; however, it is a Gram-positive bacteria, as opposed to Gram-negative.  
❌ Francisella tularensis:
Incorrect: Francisella tularensis can lead to tularemia, which can manifest with symptoms including ulceration, lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis, and pneumonia. The pathogen is transmitted via contact with rodents (e.g. rabbits) or ticks, as opposed to dog bites.  
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes can lead to soft tissue infection and osteomyelitis after a dog bite; however, it is a Gram-positive organism, as opposed to Gram-negative.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with polysubstance use disorder presents to the emergency department with fever, dyspnea, and stridor. The patient is diagnosed with epiglottitis. He is started on intravenous antibiotics and later undergoes endotracheal intubation for airway protection. He did not receive most of the childhood immunizations. Blood and sputum cultures are collected. Which of the following agars is most likely to grow the organism responsible for this patient’s infection?
questions.solution:
Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative coccobacillus, meaning its shape is between a circle (“coccus”) and a rod (“bacillus”). It is a facultative anaerobe grown best on chocolate agar since it requires factors V and X, found within lysed red blood cells.

Most strains are encapsulated, such as type B (Hib), whereas some are not encapsulated and are referred to as “non-typeable.” Due to the widespread vaccination of children against Hib in developed countries, the incidence of severe H. influenzae disease has dramatically decreased.

Epiglottitis is most commonly caused by Hib and is most common in children who have not been vaccinated. In adults, it mainly occurs in those who did not receive childhood immunizations, but it can also occur in patients with substance use disorders or poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. While all strains can cause epiglottitis, meningitis, otitis media, and sinusitis, Hib tends to cause more severe symptoms when compared to the non-typable strains.

As the epiglottis becomes infected with H. influenzae, it develops severe swelling and can cause airway narrowing. Patients often present with fever, dyspnea, and stridor. Treatment involves intravenous antibiotics and potentially endotracheal intubation. A “thumbprint sign” may be present on lateral neck x-ray.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bile-esculin agar:
Incorrect: This patient presents with epiglottitis, most often caused by Haemophilus influenzae. Bile-esculin agar is not typically used to grow H. influenzae.  
✅ Chocolate agar:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cystine-tellurite-blood agar:
Incorrect: This agar is used to select Corynebacterium, as it does not allow for the growth of organisms outside this genus. C. diphtheriae causes diphtheria, which manifests with upper respiratory symptoms, but generally does not cause epiglottitis.  
❌ MacConkey agar:
Incorrect: This agar is used to differentiate between lactose-fermenting (e.g., Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species) and non-lactose-fermenting (e.g., Salmonella species, Shigella species) Gram-negative rods. These organisms are not implicated in epiglottitis.  
❌ Mannitol salts agar:
Incorrect: This agar is used mainly to differentiate between Staphylococcus species or to help differentiate between Staphylococcus and Streptococcus. These organisms are generally not implicated in epiglottitis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office to evaluate bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Stool culture grows a Gram-negative curved rod. Which characteristics are likely to be found on further evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bloody diarrhea and stool culture growth of a Gram-negative curved rod that is oxidase-positive. These findings suggest the underlying infection Campylobacter jejuni, which grows at 42°C.

Campylobacter jejuni is a food-borne pathogen that occurs after consuming contaminated poultry, meat, or unpasteurized milk. The incubation period is approximately three to seven days, followed by fever, colicky abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Notably, about half of the children with this infection will exhibit bloody diarrhea. Diagnosis is confirmed via stool culture, and most cases are self-limited.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Grows in 42°C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Grows in alkaline media:
Incorrect: Vibrio cholerae grows in alkaline media, whereas Campylobacter jejuni does not. Vibrio cholerae does not cause bloody diarrhea.  
❌ Produces urease:
Incorrect: Heliobacter pylori is an urease-producing organism, whereas Campylobacter jejuni is not.  H. pylori is a common cause of peptic ulcer disease, not bloody diarrhea.  
❌ Oxidase-negative:
Incorrect: Campylobacter jejuni does produce oxidase (meaning it can use oxygen as a terminal electron acceptor).  
❌ H2S production on TSI agar:
Incorrect: H2S production on TSI agar is a characteristic feature of Salmonella and Proteus, not Campylobacter jejuni.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for three days with fatigue, fever, and a sore throat. Past medical history is significant for Chlamydia urethritis as a teenager, and two months ago, he was diagnosed with herpes simplex genitalis. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and a well-circumscribed, oval-shaped maculopapular rash over the abdomen, trunk, and face. Oral examination reveals mucocutaneous ulcers on the tongue, oral mucosa, and palate. Pharyngeal edema and hyperemia are present without exudates or tonsillar enlargement. Abdominal examination is noncontributory. Heterophile antibody screening is negative. Which of the following best describes the most likely microbiological agent responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of sexually transmitted infections, presents with acute onset fever, myalgias, adenopathy (particularly posterior chain), and pharyngitis suggestive of an acute retroviral syndrome. The viral genome of HIV consists of two single strands of positive-sense RNA enclosed within a viral capsid envelope that consists of glycoproteins coded by the env gene. The env gene codes for the glycoprotein gp160, which is subsequently cleaved into gp120 and gp41--allowing for viral entry into cells. Gp120 binds to chemokine receptors on dendritic cells, macrophages (CCR5), and T lymphocytes ( specifically CXCR4). Upon binding to host cell receptors, gp120 undergoes a conformational change that exposes gp41, allowing for the fusion of the viral cell membrane and T cell membrane.

The pol gene codes for reverse transcriptase protein, integrase, and protease. Following viral entry, reverse transcriptase converts the viral genome to ds DNA and is incorporated into the host cell via integrase. The modified genome then gets transcribed into polyproteins cleaved into active proteins by the enzyme protease. The gag gene is the major structural protein of HIV and codes for structural proteins including p24 ( capsid protein) and p7 (nucleocapsid protein).
 
  

Option Analysis

✅ Enveloped, single-stranded, linear RNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gram-positive cocci in chains:
Incorrect: Group A streptococcus causes streptococcal pharyngitis, which presents with tonsillar exudates and swelling. Scarlet fever can occur in the setting of streptococcal pharyngitis and is associated with a sandpaper-like rash. Posterior chain lymphadenopathy and mucocutaneous ulcers are atypical of strep pharyngitis.  
❌ Nonenveloped, double-stranded, linear DNA virus:
Incorrect: Adenovirus can cause pharyngitis with tonsillar exudates and associated adenopathy. Infection with this virus does not cause mucocutaneous ulcers or a diffuse maculopapular rash.  
❌ Enveloped, double-stranded, linear DNA virus:
Incorrect: The Epstein Barr virus and CMV are both enveloped, double-stranded, linear DNA viruses and can cause mononucleosis-like syndrome ( fever, pharyngitis, adenopathy, and splenomegaly). A negative heterophile antibody effectively rules out both EBV and CMV.  
❌ Nonenveloped, single-stranded, linear DNA virus:
Incorrect: Parvovirus is a DNA virus that can cause arthralgias and fever in adults and erythema infectiosum (“slapped cheek”) in children. Mucocutaneous ulcers are not associated with this virus.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of fever, headache, and swelling in the right eye. The patient’s symptoms started a few days after he returned from a trip to South America. During the trip, he spent much time hiking outdoors and visiting rural towns. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, and pulse is 100/minute. Physical examination reveals swelling in the right orbital region and redness in the conjunctiva. A blood smear is obtained and shown below. If untreated, this patient is at risk of developing which of the following complications?
 

Image reproduced from CDC.gov
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has acute Chagas disease. Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted to humans via bites by the Triatomine “kissing bug”, which is a type of reduviid bug. Chagas disease is endemic in Middle and South America.

Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases. The acute phase begins after an incubation period of up to 2 weeks and is usually asymptomatic. Symptomatic individuals can present with nonspecific symptoms including fever, headaches, and fatigue. Moreover, swelling at the inoculation site or eye from self-inoculation is present. Eye swelling is known as the Romana sign.

The chronic phase begins years after infection and is characterized by damage to the heart and gastrointestinal tract. In the heart, protozoa causes myocarditis, which eventually leads to dilated cardiomyopathy, heart failure, and arrhythmias. In the gastrointestinal tract, Chagas disease is characterized by dilation of the esophagus (megaesophagus) and colon (megacolon) from damaged smooth muscle cells.

In the acute phase, diagnosis can be made by visualizing trypomastigotes on peripheral smear or by detecting T. cruzi DNA by polymerase chain reaction. The chronic phase is harder to diagnose as the blood levels of trypomastigotes drop; but, serology and imaging (to check for cardiomegaly, megacolon, etc) can be used.  

Option Analysis

✅ Heart failure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ascending aortic aneurysm:
Incorrect: Ascending aortic aneurysm is a complication of tertiary syphilis, which is caused by the bacteria Treponema pallidum. It is not a complication of Chagas disease.  
❌ No complications are expected:
Incorrect: Chronic Chagas disease is characterized by damage to the heart and gastrointestinal tract.  
❌ Colon cancer:
Incorrect: Chagas disease can lead to megacolon, but not colon cancer.  
❌ Mitral valve stenosis:
Incorrect: Mitral valve stenosis is a complication of rheumatic fever, which is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes infection. In contrast, chronic Chagas disease is characterized by damage to the heart and gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: An 18-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to fever and irritability. The boy was healthy at birth; however, 2-days ago, he developed a fever and decreased appetite. In addition, the patient has become increasingly irritable. Blood testing reveals leukopenia and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals low glucose concentration and elevated proteins. Gram culture of the blood and CSF is positive for Streptococcus agalactiae. Which of the following is true regarding this pathogen?

choices.text: Produces a factor that enhances Staphylococcus aureus hemolysis on blood agar
Produces an enzyme that hydrolyzes pyrrolidonyl-ꞵ-naphthylamide to ꞵ-naphthylamide
Produces an enzyme that converts hydrogen peroxide to oxygen and water

questions.solution:
This neonate has meningitis caused by Streptococcus agalactiae, which is also known as group B strep (GBS). GBS is an important cause of early (first seven days of life) and late (7 to 28 days) neonatal meningitis, as well as neonatal pneumonia and sepsis.

GBS is a Gram-positive cocci that grows in pairs and chains. It is a catalase-negative bacteria. It has a polysaccharide capsule that helps the bacteria evade phagocytosis. When grown on blood agar, GBS produces ꞵ-hemolysis (also known as complete hemolysis), similar to Streptococcus pyogenes, which is also known as group A strep (GAS).

There are few features that distinguish GBS from other bacteria such as GAS. First, GBS is bacitracin resistant whereas GAS is bacitracin sensitive. Second, GBS produces the CAMP factor. The presence of this factor is evaluated using the CAMP test, wherein colonies of GBS are grown with Staphylococcus aureus colonies on the same blood agar. The presence of CAMP factor produced by GBS enhances the ꞵ-hemolysis caused by S. aureus. This phenomenon occurs since the CAMP factor enhances the actions of S. aureus ꞵ-hemolysin. Finally, GBS is hippurate positive and PYR negative, while GAS is hippurate negative and PYR positive.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Produces a factor that enhances Staphylococcus aureus hemolysis on blood agar:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Produces an enzyme that hydrolyzes pyrrolidonyl-ꞵ-naphthylamide to ꞵ-naphthylamide:
Incorrect: The hydrolysis of pyrrolidonyl-ꞵ-naphthylamide to ꞵ-naphthylamide is mediated by the enzyme pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR). Streptococcus agalactiae does not produce PYR (PYR negative) whereas Streptococcus pyogenes is PYR positive.  
❌ Produces an enzyme that converts hydrogen peroxide to oxygen and water:
Incorrect: The enzyme catalase converts hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. This enzyme is not produced by Streptococcus agalactiae.  
❌ Demonstrates sensitivity to bacitracin:
Incorrect: Streptococcus agalactiae is resistant to bacitracin. In contrast, Streptococcus pyogenes is sensitive to bacitracin.  
❌ Produces ɑ-hemolysis on blood agar:
Incorrect: Streptococcus agalactiae causes ꞵ-hemolysis on blood agar.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man came to the physician due to severe left knee pain for the last three days. The pain started abruptly and is increasing in intensity. He has also noticed swelling in the knee. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.9°F), blood pressure is 138/80 mmHg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation. Both passive and active range of motion is decreased in the left knee. Laboratory testing reveals leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers. Arthrocentesis is performed, and the joint fluid is sent for culture, which reveals Gram-positive cocci in clusters that form golden colonies on the agar plates. Which of the following virulence factors does this microorganism possess, and what is the function of this virulence factor?
questions.solution:
